Title: Angry U.S.-Russia Exchange at U.N. Punctuates Deepening Ukraine Rift
Text: The United States and Russia bitterly attacked each other over the Ukraine crisis in a diplomatic brawl Monday at the U.N. Security Council, in a session replete with acidic exchanges that could have been lifted from the Cold War era.
Snippet: With vitriolic accusations that echoed the Cold War era, the United States and Russia sparred in a bitter debate over the Ukraine crisis in a Security Council meeting watched by the world on Monday.

Title: The U.S. orders families of its embassy staff in Belarus to leave the country.
Text: With large-scale Russian military exercises set to begin in Belarus, the United States has ordered the departure of family members of U.S. government employees, citing “an increase in unusual and concerning Russian military activity near the border with Ukraine.”
Snippet: Washington cited “an increase in unusual and concerning Russian military activity near the border with Ukraine.”

Title: With Low-Tech, Trench Warfare, Ukraine’s Army Isn’t NATO Caliber
Text: The soldiers live in dugout bunkers, and cook all their own meals. They dry their wet socks on clotheslines underground. Many of their weapons are remnants of the Soviet era, half a century old.
Snippet: The United States and its allies have trained and helped equip the Ukrainian army. But it has little resemblance to the kind of sophisticated, contemporary military that distinguishes NATO members.

Title: Hungary’s leader, visiting Moscow, calls Russian demands reasonable and says sanctions are pointless.
Text: Splitting sharply from his NATO allies, Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary said on Tuesday that proposed sanctions against Russia if it takes military action against Ukraine would be “doomed to failure” and that Russian security demands were reasonable.
Snippet: On a friendly visit to Moscow, Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary diverged sharply from his NATO and European Union allies.

Title: States Are Complicating Corporate Pandemic Planning
Text: Now that the Biden administration’s nationwide coronavirus vaccine mandate for large companies has been overturned by the Supreme Court, employers are left to navigate a thicket of state and local rules. In New York, that means private employers have to require vaccines. In Florida and Texas, laws limit the pandemic protocols they can put in place.
Snippet: Companies are wrestling with an array of state rules that makes designing pandemic policies tricky.

Title: Exxon Mobil reports a $8.9 billion fourth-quarter profit as oil prices soar.
Text: Exxon Mobil, the largest American oil company, reported its most robust earnings in seven years on Tuesday as it rode a wave of climbing oil and natural gas prices.
Snippet: The oil and gas giant said it would resume its stock buyback program by repurchasing $10 billion in shares over the next two years.

Title: Sundance Wrap-Up: 6 Movies We Like and One We Disagree on
Text: For the second year in a row, the Sundance Film Festival canceled its in-person plans and went virtual, wrapping up on Sunday evening. It was quite a feast, with more than 80 documentary and narrative features. Here are six our chief film critics especially liked, and one they disagree about.
Snippet: Even virtual, the festival gave our chief film critics a lot to talk about.

Title: Putin Signals Openness to Diplomacy While Blaming U.S. for Crisis
Text: President Vladimir V. Putin said on Tuesday that the United States was trying to pull Russia into an armed conflict over Ukraine that his government did not want and signaled he was prepared to engage in more diplomacy, even as he insisted that NATO’s presence in Eastern Europe threatened world peace.
Snippet: The Russian president seemed to be trying to ratchet down tensions in the standoff over Ukraine, while claiming the United States was seeking to goad Moscow into an invasion.

Title: The Morning at Night: A Virtual Event on Ukraine and Covid
Snippet: David Leonhardt hosted conversations about the latest from Ukraine and the state of the pandemic, and the actress Ariana DeBose shared readers’ Tiny Love Stories.

Title: U.S. Sends Top Security Official to Help NATO Brace for Russian Cyberattacks
Text: The White House dispatched its top cybersecurity official to NATO on Tuesday in what it described as a mission to prepare allies to deter, and perhaps disrupt, Russian cyberattacks on Ukraine, and to brace for the possibility that sanctions on Moscow could lead to a wave of retaliatory cyberattacks on Europe and the United States.
Snippet: Intelligence assessments suggest that a Russian invasion of Ukraine would most likely be preceded by cyberattacks on Ukraine’s electric grid, its communications systems and its government.

Title: In Clash With U.S. Over Ukraine, Putin Has a Lifeline From China
Text: As the United States moves to exert maximal pressure on Russia over fears of a Ukraine invasion, the Russian leader, Vladimir V. Putin, has found relief from his most powerful partner on the global stage, China.
Snippet: President Biden could find his plans to punish Russia undermined by Xi Jinping, a longtime ally of Mr. Putin. But China moves cautiously during crises.

Title: Why Are Oil Prices So High and Will They Stay That Way?
Text: Oil prices are increasing, again, casting a shadow over the economy, driving up inflation and eroding consumer confidence.
Snippet: Geopolitical tensions and a growing disparity between supply and demand have driven up prices. Here is what that means and what could happen next.

Title: With oil markets tightening, OPEC and its allies agree to a small increase in output.
Text: Officials from OPEC countries and their allies agreed on Wednesday to continue feeding a modest amount of additional oil into an increasingly tight market, a move that may add new uncertainty to energy markets.
Snippet: High prices and strong demand would suggest it was time for a major increase, but uncertainty around Ukraine leaves the oil producers in an awkward spot.

Title: A jump in European inflation adds pressure on the E.C.B. to act.
Text: The eurozone started 2022 much as it ended the previous year, with record-setting inflation that defied expectations. Now economists are wondering if the persistently high prices could pressure the European Central Bank to change its position that the situation is temporary.
Snippet: Inflation in the eurozone set its latest record, climbing to 5.1 percent in January, amid persistently high energy costs and tensions over Ukraine.

Title: Five Takeaways on Ukraine Crisis, After Putin Breaks Silence
Text: at least for the moment. But it also illustrated the vast gulf between Moscow’s demands and what Western nations are even willing to discuss.
Snippet: The threat of conflict may not have passed, despite a flurry of diplomacy in Moscow and Kyiv.

Title: In Responses to Russia, U.S. Stands Firm on Who Can Join NATO
Text: The confrontation between Russia and the United States over Ukraine deepened on Wednesday, as leaked documents confirmed the U.S. and NATO rejection of key Russian security demands, while the Biden administration ordered 3,000 additional troops into Eastern Europe.
Snippet: Leaked replies to Moscow’s security demands reinforced the intractability of a crisis that threatens to lead to war.

Title: As Boris Johnson Seeks a Reset, More Tory Lawmakers Defect
Text: Prime Minister Boris Johnson tried to change the subject on Wednesday, hoping to replace the public image of himself as a heedless partygoer with that of a confident global statesman and a farsighted nation builder.
Snippet: Britain’s prime minister tried to steer attention away from a damning report on Downing Street parties, but his support continued to erode.

Title: Vindman, Key Figure in Trump Impeachment, Alleges Retaliation in Lawsuit
Text: Alexander Vindman, the Army colonel who was a chief witness in President Donald J. Trump’s first impeachment trial, filed a lawsuit on Wednesday against Mr. Trump’s son, Donald Trump Jr.; Rudolph W. Giuliani; and two other top Trump White House aides, accusing them of running a coordinated intimidation and retaliation campaign to stop him from testifying.
Snippet: The former Army colonel, who worked on the National Security Council, said in a lawsuit that Donald Trump Jr. and others carried out a campaign of intimidation against him.

Title: How Spiking Energy Prices Complicate the Fight Against Global Warming
Text: While world leaders have vowed to scale back the use of fossil fuels to help keep a lid on global warming, a drastic upheaval in the markets for oil, natural gas and coal could complicate the shift toward cleaner sources of energy.
Snippet: Oil and gas prices are soaring, while coal use is reaching record highs worldwide. Here’s what the upheaval could mean for climate policies across the globe.

Title: Coronavirus Briefing: Omicron’s Death Toll
Text: and the data is sobering.
Snippet: Compared to other wealthy countries, the virus in the U.S. is killing people at much higher rates.

Title: Coronavirus Briefing: Omicron’s Death Toll
Text: and the data is sobering.
Snippet: Compared to other wealthy countries, the virus in the U.S. is killing people at much higher rates.

Title: Is Biden’s Strategy With Putin Working, or Goading Moscow to War?
Text: At key moments since the Ukraine crisis flared into the headlines two months ago, President Biden and his aides have worked to expose Russian President Vladimir V. Putin’s plans, declassifying intelligence about his next steps and calling him out as an “aggressor.”
Snippet: The Biden administration’s goal is to cut the Russians off at each turn by exposing their plans. But Russian President Vladimir V. Putin says that approach could spark a conflict.

Title: Natural Gas Shipments, Mostly From U.S., Ease Europe’s Energy Crunch
Text: Near the entrance to Rotterdam’s vast harbor in the Netherlands is a specialized port that is offering an alternative to the web of Russian pipelines that feed much of Europe’s hunger for natural gas.
Snippet: As Russia squeezes supplies, a parade of tankers carrying liquefied natural gas is coming to Europe’s rescue.

Title: How Malaysia Got in on the Secondhand Clothing Boom
Text: Maybe it was the pandemic, or growing concerns about the environment, or a bit of both, but one thing’s certain: People are doing a lot more secondhand shopping these days.
Snippet: Sellers from the country have become a reliable source of sought-after labels, finding high value in discarded items.

Title: On the eve of his meeting with Xi, Putin pledges to deepen ties with China.
Text: Ahead of his visit to Beijing for the opening of the Winter Olympics, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia pledged on Thursday to deepen his country’s diplomatic and economic ties with China in ways that would counter American power and influence.
Snippet: Russia’s president did not mention Ukraine, but said he and China’s leader would coordinate foreign policy “based on close and coinciding approaches.”

Title: Putin, Facing Sanction Threats, Has Been Saving for This Day
Text: Vladimir V. Putin’s posture toward the West through the recent Ukraine crisis seems unusually defiant, even for him. But there may be more behind his confidence than military power or empty bravado.
Snippet: Since paying the price for annexing Crimea in 2014, Russia has tried to make its economy sanctions-proof, hoarding currency to insulate the country.

Title: The European Central Bank keeps rates steady, despite record inflation.
Text: The European Central Bank on Thursday kept to its cautious approach in the face of record inflation in the eurozone, but Christine Lagarde, the bank’s president, acknowledged that “the situation has indeed changed” and refused to rule out a rate increase in 2022.
Snippet: The E.C.B. held to its policy of easing off support for the economy and tolerating record-high inflation in “the interim,” leaving its interest rate untouched.

Title: U.S. Exposes What It Says Is Russian Effort to Fabricate Pretext for Invasion
Text: The United States has acquired intelligence about a Russian plan to fabricate a pretext for an invasion of Ukraine using a faked video that would build on recent disinformation campaigns, according to senior administration officials and others briefed on the material.
Snippet: Officials said Russia was planning a fake video showing an attack by Ukrainians on Russian territory or Russian speakers in eastern Ukraine.

Title: Food Prices Approach Record Highs, Threatening the World’s Poorest
Text: Food prices have skyrocketed globally because of disruptions in the global supply chain, adverse weather and rising energy prices, increases that are imposing a heavy burden on poorer people around the world and threatening to stoke social unrest.
Snippet: The prices have climbed to their highest level since 2011, according to a U.N. index. It could cause social unrest “on a widespread scale,” one expert said.

Title: Once Again the Olympic Games Will Begin, Despite Everything
Snippet: neither the pandemic nor the shadow of doping scandals nor concerns over China’s human rights record — will deter the International Olympic Committee from staging the Beijing Games.

Title: Once Again the Olympic Games Will Begin, Despite Everything
Snippet: neither the pandemic nor the shadow of doping scandals nor concerns over China’s human rights record — will deter the International Olympic Committee from staging the Beijing Games.

Title: The coronavirus continues to sideline Olympic athletes as they gear up for competition.
Text: Coronavirus infections among athletes continue to jeopardize medal hopes in Beijing.
Snippet: Twenty-six new infections were reported as of Thursday, bringing the total number of confirmed positive cases to 287.

Title: Turkey, a Sometimes Wavering NATO Ally, Backs Ukraine
Text: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey agreed on Thursday to expand supplies of one of the Ukrainian Army’s most sophisticated weapons, a long-range, Turkish-made armed drone whose use in combat for the first time in Ukraine last fall infuriated Russian officials.
Snippet: In a public rebuke of Russia, Turkey will expand supplies of one of the Ukrainian Army’s most sophisticated weapons, a long-range, Turkish-made armed drone.

Title: Raid Targeting ISIS Leader Came After Months of Planning
Text: A risky predawn raid by U.S. Special Operations forces that resulted in the death of the Islamic State’s leader on Thursday was set in motion months ago with a tip that the top terrorist was hiding out on the top floor of a house in northwest Syria.
Snippet: President Biden said the attack on Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi was designed to minimize civilian casualties, but then the terrorist leader set off a bomb.

Title: Nathan Chen finishes first in skating’s team event, setting up the U.S. for a medal.
Text: Update: Kamila Valieva stumbles in return, then floats to first place.
Snippet: Chen skated in the short program, his first event in Beijing, and rebounded from a disappointing showing at the 2018 Games.

Title: On Ukraine, Many Russians Have No Doubt: It’s the Fault of the U.S.
Text: After touring the grand, marble-clad Victory museum in Moscow, dedicated to the Soviet Union’s triumph over Nazi Germany in World War II, the two visitors concluded that the situation today is not all that different: Russia is under attack again.
Snippet: The idea that the U.S. and NATO are fomenting the crisis between Russia and Ukraine is hammered home daily by the Kremlin’s propaganda machine.

Title: The Chinese language determines the order of the Parade of Nations.
Text: Jamaica between Eritrea and Belgium. Britain after Latvia. Madagascar at the beginning and Morocco at the end.
Snippet: What’s going on with the order of the parade of athletes at the opening ceremony?

Title: What Will Move Markets Now?
Text: for a while.
Snippet: Meta’s earnings led to a wild swing in stocks. The latest jobs numbers might trigger another.

Title: Five Takeaways From the U.S. Raid That Killed the Islamic State’s Leader
Text: The daring pre-dawn raid by U.S. Special Operations forces in Syria that resulted in the death of the Islamic State’s leader offered a vivid reminder that no matter how much the world might want to move on, the chaos in Syria continues to reverberate.
Snippet: A daring raid by U.S. Special Operations forces that resulted in the death of the ISIS leader offered a vivid reminder that the chaos in Syria continues to reverberate.

Title: In Beijing, Olympic Spectacle and Global Power Games
Text: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, opened an Olympic Games on Friday intended to celebrate his country’s increasingly assured global status standing defiantly with his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin, in an increasingly ideological contest with the United States and its allies.
Snippet: The opening of the Winter Games gave Xi Jinping and Vladimir V. Putin a chance to cement their partnership against Western censure.

Title: With a missile shot, Ukraine sends a public warning to Russia.
Text: With television cameras rolling, a Ukrainian soldier heaved an America-made missile launcher onto his shoulder and pressed a red button. The missile streaked out and blew a target — a pile of tires — to smithereens.
Snippet: As the United States and others step up military aid to Ukraine, the deliveries are more overt, and Ukraine is staging public weapons demonstrations for the media.

Title: Russian Troops in Final Stages of Readiness Add to Worries for Ukraine
Text: While Russia is not yet capable of mounting a total invasion of Ukraine, portions of its army have reached full combat strength and appear to be in the final stages of readiness for military action should the Kremlin order it, according to an assessment by the Ukrainian military’s high command.
Snippet: Though the Kremlin’s intentions are unclear, Ukrainian officials are newly worried about the Crimean Peninsula, where Russia has deployed 10,000 additional troops, they said.

Title: Nathan Chen finishes first in skating’s team event, setting up the U.S. for a medal.
Text: Update: Kamila Valieva stumbles in return, then floats to first place.
Snippet: Chen skated in the short program, his first event in Beijing, and rebounded from a disappointing showing at the 2018 Games.

Title: Russian Troops in Final Stages of Readiness Add to Worries for Ukraine
Text: While Russia is not yet capable of mounting a total invasion of Ukraine, portions of its army have reached full combat strength and appear to be in the final stages of readiness for military action should the Kremlin order it, according to an assessment by the Ukrainian military’s high command.
Snippet: Though the Kremlin’s intentions are unclear, Ukrainian officials are newly worried about the Crimean Peninsula, where Russia has deployed 10,000 additional troops, they said.

Title: Why ‘Trust Us’ Is Often Reason Enough Not to Trust the Government
Text: The dramatic national security stories recounted in two official news briefings on Thursday centered on very different subjects, but they featured the same indignant pushback to questioning reporters: just trust us, unless you are more inclined to believe America’s enemies.
Snippet: which sometimes turns out to be wrong. Yet officials can be defensive about skepticism from the news media.

Title: Ukraine Gave Up a Giant Nuclear Arsenal 30 Years Ago. Today There Are Regrets.
Text: At the end of the Cold War, the third largest nuclear power on earth was not Britain, France or China. It was Ukraine. The Soviet collapse, a slow-motion downfall that culminated in December 1991, resulted in the newly independent Ukraine inheriting roughly 5,000 nuclear arms that Moscow had stationed on its soil. Underground silos on its military bases held long-range missiles that carried up to 10 thermonuclear warheads, each far stronger than the bomb that leveled Hiroshima. Only Russia and the United States had more weapons.
Snippet: When the Soviet Union collapsed, Ukraine turned over thousands of atomic weapons in exchange for security guarantees from Russia, the United States and other countries.

Title: Facing Tough Election, Orban Turns to Putin for Support
Text: Facing a tough election in two months, Hungary’s far-right populist prime minister, Viktor Orban, last week opened the centerpiece of a new state-funded museum district celebrating his country’s role as an anchor of European culture and identity.
Snippet: The Hungarian leader made his name by defying Moscow. But he has increasingly turned toward Russia in an effort to secure the natural gas he needs to keep energy prices low and voters happy.

Title: All Options Are Not on the Table as Biden Moves Troops Closer to Ukraine
Text: President Biden flexed America’s military power in hopes of deterring a Russian invasion of Ukraine with his announcement this week that 3,000 U.S. troops were heading to Eastern Europe.
Snippet: The president’s opposition to sending U.S. troops into Ukraine reflects the mood of a war-wary Washington, as well as concerns about Russia’s nuclear arsenal.

Title: U.S. Warns of Grim Toll if Putin Pursues Full Invasion of Ukraine
Text: Senior Biden administration officials told lawmakers this past week that they believed the Russian military had assembled 70 percent of the forces it would need to mount a full invasion of Ukraine, painting the most ominous picture yet of the options that Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, has created for himself in recent weeks.
Snippet: Biden administration officials told lawmakers that a large-scale Russian invasion could kill as many as 50,000 civilians and prompt a refugee crisis in Europe.

Title: How Yiddish Scholars Are Rescuing Women’s Novels From Obscurity
Text: In “Diary of a Lonely Girl, or the Battle Against Free Love,” a sendup of the socialists, anarchists and intellectuals who populated New York’s Lower East Side in the early 20th century, Miriam Karpilove writes from the perspective of a sardonic young woman frustrated by the men’s advocacy of unrestrained sexuality and their lack of concern about the consequences for her.
Snippet: Works written decades ago, often by female Jewish immigrants, were dismissed as insignificant or unmarketable. But in the past several years, translators devoted to the literature are making it available to a wider readership.

Title: Germany’s ‘Invisible’ Chancellor Heads to Washington Amid Fierce Criticism
Text: One headline asked, “Where is Olaf Scholz?” A popular magazine mocked the German chancellor’s “art of disappearance.” And his ambassador in Washington wrote home that Germany was increasingly seen as an unreliable ally in a leaked memo that was all the buzz this past week and began with the words: “Berlin, we have a problem.”
Snippet: Olaf Scholz will try to repair Germany’s credibility in the Ukraine crisis when he meets President Biden on Monday. Next on his agenda: Kyiv and Moscow.

Title: Macron Tries to Avert a European War and Reshape European Security
Text: The standoff with Russia over Ukraine enters a critical phase this week. The United States has snapped NATO to attention and moved forces east. Moscow has readied still more forces on the Ukraine border. But beneath those tensions, diplomatic avenues are being feverishly explored and the outlines of potential solutions, still amorphous, may be taking form.
Snippet: The French president’s shuttle diplomacy this week in Moscow and Kyiv will be a delicate exercise, given European reservations and American resolve.

Title: The Crisis That Defined Blinken’s First Year
Text: The arc of Antony J. Blinken’s first year as secretary of state could be broken down into two distinct eras: before and after Afghanistan.
Snippet: As the secretary of state enters his second year in office, Russia threatens, China looms and Afghanistan remains a challenge.

Title: Biden says a Russia-to-Germany pipeline would not go forward if Moscow invades Ukraine.
Text: After meeting with the leader of Germany, President Biden said on Monday that a lucrative gas pipeline project connecting Russia and Germany would not go forward if Moscow were to invade Ukraine.
Snippet: After meeting with the German chancellor, Mr. Biden promised a united response to Russia.

Title: Both Sides of Taiwan Strait Are Closely Watching Ukraine’s Crisis
Text: With Russia massing troops along Ukraine’s borders, President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan felt compelled to act.
Snippet: Taiwan knows what it’s like to have an overbearing neighbor. China wonders how forcefully Western powers might react to a Russian invasion.

Title: Macron meets Putin in Moscow, aiming for a de-escalation.
Text: President Emmanuel Macron of France, who has positioned himself at the center of Europe’s furious diplomatic maneuvering over Ukraine, said on Monday that the continent was at a “critical crossroads” as he met in Moscow with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

Title: He Survived the Holocaust and Was Killed Crossing the Street at Age 99
Text: After surviving two wars, the Nazi invasion of Hungary and the Holocaust, a 99-year-old man died Saturday afternoon after a man driving a S.U.V. hit him on his way to synagogue, family members and the police said.
Snippet: Jack Mikulincer was on his way to synagogue to observe the Sabbath when he was hit by an S.U.V. in Brooklyn, the police and family members said.

Title: Putin Warns the West and Ukraine, but Keeps His Intentions a Mystery
Text: President Vladimir V. Putin said he was prepared to keep negotiating over Russia’s security demands in Eastern Europe but offered a stark warning over the possibility of a full-scale war between Russia and the West — using a five-hour meeting with his French counterpart on Monday to keep the world guessing about his intentions.
Snippet: President Vladimir Putin said diplomatic ideas raised in a meeting by French President Emmanuel Macron were worth pursuing, but did not rule out a Russian invasion of Ukraine.

Title: Is Russia Bluffing?
Text: If Russia invades Ukraine, it would be the largest and potentially deadliest military action in Europe since World War II.
Snippet: A full-scale invasion of Ukraine would most likely be bloody and expensive. Can the West find the unity needed to head off the danger?

Title: Macron meets Zelensky in Ukraine, as Russia keeps the world guessing.
Text: President Emmanuel Macron of France said on Tuesday that the Ukraine crisis could take months to resolve, but that his shuttle diplomacy this week between Russia and Ukraine had raised hopes of stabilizing the situation.

Title: Some in Ukraine, a former nuclear power, now regret disarmament.
Text: In a speech at the Munich Security Conference on Saturday, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine criticized Western countries for not living up to promises they made when the Soviet Union fell, when they persuaded Ukraine to give up what was then the world’s third largest arsenal of nuclear weapons.
Snippet: “Ukraine has received security guarantees for abandoning the world’s third nuclear capability,” Mr. Zelensky said. “We don’t have that weapon. We also have no security.”

Title: Europe Cuts Payments to Poland in Court Dispute Over Mine
Text: The European Union will withhold millions of euros in payments to Poland to recover unpaid fines, the bloc said on Tuesday, the first time it has used such a method to discipline a member country and deepening a rift when tensions in the region have been mounting over the crisis in Ukraine.
Snippet: For the first time, the E.U. executive arm said it would divert millions in grants to a member country to cover unpaid fines, escalating a confrontation despite jitters over Ukraine.

Title: What Is Peloton Worth?
Text: Where is Peloton headed? As its fortunes have waned, the once high-flying maker of connected fitness bikes faces pressure from activist investors to cut costs and frenzied speculation on Wall Street that it may need to sell itself.
Snippet: Rumors, restructuring and resignations loom over the former high-flying fitness company.

Title: Putin Is Operating on His Own Timetable, and It May Be a Long One
Text: The Ukraine crisis is here to stay.
Snippet: The standoff between Russia and the West over Ukraine could turn into a drawn-out and dangerous diplomatic slog toward a difficult settlement.

Title: What Are the Minsk Accords, and Could They Defuse the Ukraine Crisis?
Text: The Ukraine crisis is entering a critical phase this week.
Snippet: European diplomats are exploring whether a seven-year-old negotiating channel, initially intended to resolve a conflict in eastern Ukraine, can be repurposed to calm a wider crisis.

Title: A Once Firm Antiwar Alliance Splinters Over Ukraine
Text: An antiwar alliance of veterans that emerged from the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan and spanned the political spectrum is splintering badly over the U.S. response to the threatening moves of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia against Ukraine.
Snippet: The complex dynamics among veterans’ groups reflect general exhaustion with war among American voters and shifting domestic politics.

Title: ‘Finlandization’ of Ukraine is part of the diplomatic discourse. But what does that mean?
Text: President Emmanuel Macron of France invoked a Cold War-era term on Monday, telling reporters on his flight to Moscow that “Finlandization” of Ukraine was “one of the models on the table” for defusing tensions with Russia.
Snippet: the kinds of concessions Ukraine is resisting.

Title: Boris Johnson Shuffles Team to Tamp Down Mutiny Within His Party
Text: With more than a dozen Conservative lawmakers calling on him to quit, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain shuffled his top team on Tuesday and hired a new chief whip to contain a mutiny within his party over a swirling scandal over lockdown-breaking parties in Downing Street.
Snippet: The British prime minister shuffles his team to tamp down a growing mutiny within his Conservative Party over his leadership.

Title: Europe Calls for Peace, but Not at Any Price
Text: After two days of intense diplomacy on both sides of the Atlantic about the Ukraine crisis, the leaders of France, Germany and Poland said their overriding goal was the preservation of peace in Europe, but warned Russia of dire consequences if it launched further incursions into Ukraine.
Snippet: Two days of intense diplomacy on both sides of the Atlantic leave the standoff over Ukraine with Russia frozen in place.

Title: Life Under the Specter of War: Images From Ukraine
Text: The threat is menacing and all around. To the north, south and east, Russian combat battalions, infantry divisions and airborne units continue to mass with a mighty arsenal that includes hundreds of tanks, armor and artillery.
Snippet: With Russian forces menacing from three sides, Ukrainians are stoically keeping to their daily routines, but reminders of the looming threat are getting hard to avoid.

Title: The Environmentally Unfriendly Secret of the Beijing Olympics
Text: If you’ve been watching the Winter Olympics in Beijing, it’s hard to miss: Just beyond the white slopes for the ski and snowboard events lie brown hills barely touched by snow.
Snippet: The I.O.C. awarded this year’s Winter Games to a place almost completely lacking in snow. China’s water-scarce capital had to go to enormous lengths to make it.

Title: In Ukraine Crisis, Putin Faces a Stark Choice
Text: As he engages in coercive diplomacy with the West, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia faces a stark choice: He can move militarily to control Ukraine or preserve economic links to Europe. But it will be difficult for him to do both.
Snippet: Russia can seize control over Ukraine or keep strong economic ties to Europe. It will be hard to do both.

Title: Finns Don’t Wish ‘Finlandization’ on Ukraine (or Anyone)
Text: For decades, Finland survived as an independent and unoccupied democracy in the shadow of the Soviet Union by handing the Kremlin outsized influence over its politics and hewing to a delicate neutrality during the Cold War.
Snippet: The Cold War term for a kind of stifled sovereignty has gained attention as a possible solution to the standoff with Russia. But the nation it’s named for would rather forget about it.

Title: Corrections: Feb. 10, 2022
Text: An article on Wednesday about the dropping of mask mandates by Democratic governors misattributed a quotation about being photographed without a mask at an N.F.L. playoff game. It was Eric Garcetti, the mayor of Los Angeles, who said he held his breath during a photo, not Gov. Gavin Newsom of California.
Snippet: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Feb. 10, 2022.

Title: A ‘legal issue’ raises questions about the medals for team figure skating.
Text: More than two days after the team figure skating event ended with Russia winning, Olympics officials still have not handed out the medals as they investigate a “legal issue” that has generated questions in the sport.
Snippet: A spokesman for the I.O.C. would not elaborate on what is causing the delay of the award ceremony or comment on reports in the Russian news media that it involved questions about a banned substance.

Title: Top British officials lead diplomatic efforts on Thursday.
Text: Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Thursday pledged more military support to NATO allies amid the Russian buildup surrounding Ukraine, placing an additional 1,000 British troops “at readiness” to respond to a possible humanitarian crisis.

Title: European leaders say they seek peace, and warn Russia of retaliation for any aggression against Ukraine.
Text: After days of intense diplomacy over the Ukraine crisis, the leaders of France, Germany and Poland said this week that their overriding goal was the preservation of peace in Europe, but warned Russia of dire consequences if it launched further incursions into Ukraine.

Title: Boris Johnson warns that the Ukraine crisis is reaching a perilous moment.
Text: Emphasizing Britain’s “immovable” commitment to NATO, Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Thursday pledged more military support for the alliance and said he thought that Russia had not yet decided whether to invade Ukraine, but warned that the most perilous moment of the crisis was fast approaching.
Snippet: Britain said it was readying 1,000 more troops to support NATO allies in case of a humanitarian crisis caused by Russian aggression against Ukraine.

Title: France Announces Major Nuclear Power Buildup
Text: President Emmanuel Macron announced a major buildup of France’s huge nuclear power program on Thursday, pledging to construct up to 14 new-generation reactors and a fleet of smaller nuclear plants as the country seeks to slash planet-warming emissions and cut its reliance on foreign energy.
Snippet: President Emmanuel Macron outlined plans for a wave of new-generation atomic reactors as the country seeks to slash planet-warming emissions.

Title: With Buildup on Land and Sea, Russia Closes in on Ukraine
Text: Thousands of Russian troops on Thursday began 10 days of exercises in Belarus, and Ukraine warned of upcoming Russian naval drills so extensive they would block shipping lanes, as the Kremlin continued to tighten its military vise on Ukraine.
Snippet: Military drills in Belarus, deployments in western Russia and Crimea, and planned naval exercises in the Black Sea gave an ominous undertone to a continuing diplomatic scramble.

Title: Armed Nationalists in Ukraine Pose a Threat Not Just to Russia
Text: The Ukrainian political activist and militia member sat before his party’s flag leaving little doubt about his readiness for action. The flag depicted two axes crossed against a field of red.
Snippet: Kyiv is encouraging the arming of nationalist paramilitary groups to thwart a Russian invasion. But they could also destabilize the government if it agrees to a peace deal they reject.

Title: New satellite images show more Russian forces massing on three sides of Ukraine.
Text: Satellite images collected on Wednesday and Thursday reveal new deployment and positioning of Russian military equipment and troops in multiple locations around Ukraine, including Crimea, western Russia and Belarus, adding to an already ominous buildup that has fueled invasion fears.
Snippet: The Russian buildup includes more forces in Crimea, western Russia and Belarus, adding to fears that Russia could invade Ukraine.

Title: NASA-Funded Satellites Lost in Setback for Astra, a Small Rocket Launch Start-Up
Text: Four tiny NASA-funded satellites were lost on their way to space on Thursday after launching atop a rocket built by Astra Space, a small, publicly traded rocket start-up based in Alameda, Calif.
Snippet: The mission’s failure to reach orbit highlighted the challenges of breaking into the space business, especially for companies that are publicly traded on the stock market.

Title: Coronavirus Briefing: The School Unmasking Debate
Text: Now that Democratic states like Connecticut, Massachusetts and New Jersey are lifting their mandates, schools in liberal-leaning communities are being forced to decide: When should the masks come off?
Snippet: Without a statewide requirement, it’s up to individual school districts to set their own mask rules.

Title: Biden Warns U.S. Won’t Send Troops to Rescue Americans in Ukraine
Text: President Biden on Thursday warned Americans to leave Ukraine, saying that U.S. troops would not be dispatched to retrieve them should Russia invade.
Snippet: “American citizens should leave, should leave now,” the president said in an NBC interview, adding that rescues in a conflict zone during a Russian invasion would risk “world war.”

Title: As Other Hot Spots Boil, U.S. Shows Its Foreign Policy Focus Is Asia
Text: With Europe bracing for the possibility of its biggest ground war in decades, the American secretary of state, Antony J. Blinken, took a 27-hour flight this week in the opposite direction.
Snippet: and to competition with China.

Title: An Olympian’s Routine: Skiing, Shooting, Soldiering
Text: Sean Doherty, an American biathlete, has been prepping for the Beijing Olympics by training, getting ample rest and keeping an especially close eye on Russian military affairs.
Snippet: The Army National Guard finances the training of elite American biathletes if they agree to join full time.

Title: Shining a Spotlight on the Art of Translation
Text: When Jennifer Croft talks about translating the Polish novelist Olga Tokarczuk’s novel “Flights,” she sometimes affectionately refers to the book as “our love child.”
Snippet: Jennifer Croft, who translates the Nobel Prize-winning Polish novelist Olga Tokarczuk, is leading a push for her peers and their work to receive more recognition.

Title: White House Warns Russian Invasion of Ukraine Could Happen at Any Time
Text: Read our latest coverage of the Ukraine crisis.
Snippet: A host of countries, including the United States, has told their citizens to leave Ukraine immediately.

Title: U.S. intelligence says Putin has accelerated his timetable and could invade within days.
Text: The U.S. intelligence community has told the White House and American allies that there are signs that President Vladimir V. Putin has moved up his timetable and could launch an invasion of Ukraine within days, according three Western officials briefed on the discussions.
Snippet: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said at a news conference in Melbourne on Friday that a Russian invasion could even occur before the Winter Olympics in Beijing end on Feb. 20.

Title: An Olympian from Ukraine protests over war during his skeleton competition.
Text: A Ukrainian athlete displayed a “no war in Ukraine” sign after finishing a run in the men’s skeleton competition on Friday.
Snippet: Vladyslav Heraskevych held up a sign that said “no war in Ukraine.” It is unclear whether the I.O.C. will penalize him for making a statement during an event.

Title: How a Chechen Abduction Exposes Putin’s Problems at Home
Text: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is flexing his military and diplomatic muscle in a tense standoff with the West over Ukraine, projecting power and occasional menace in his pursuit of global influence. But the recent abduction of a 52-year-old diabetic woman in central Russia  has made clear that Mr. Putin still has vexing challenges in his own backyard that require a skillful political juggling act.
Snippet: A furor over the arrest of a woman by agents of the Chechen strongman Ramzan Kadyrov shows the internal challenges facing President Vladimir V. Putin, even as he tries to project global power.

Title: The Pentagon is sending 3,000 more troops to Poland.
Text: The Pentagon on Friday ordered 3,000 additional troops to Poland, bringing to 5,000 the total number of reinforcements sent to Europe in the past two weeks.
Snippet: The Biden administration has ruled out sending U.S. troops to defend Ukraine, but has increased deployments to NATO countries in Eastern Europe that are wary of Russia.

Title: Puzzle in Ukraine Crisis: Where’s the U.S. Ambassador?
Text: It is a puzzle at the heart of the crisis over Russia’s threat to invade Ukraine: Why has President Biden, more than one year into his presidency, failed to name an ambassador to Kyiv?
Snippet: Diplomats say President Biden’s 13-month delay in sending an envoy to a top crisis spot is impossible to explain.

Title: The Traveling Trump Show
Text: Organizers of the three-day We Stand America gathering were clearly frustrated on Day Two: In an arena built to accommodate thousands of spectators, only a few hundred people had shown up.
Snippet: Pro-Trump rallies and conferences have taken on the flavor of religious revival, a mix between protest and party.

Title: Is the Metaverse Just Marketing?
Text: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
Snippet: The metaverse doesn’t quite exist yet. But the hype still matters.

Title: Emmanuel Macron in His Labyrinth
Text: Around a table much smaller than the 20-foot-long oval slab across which he confronted President Vladimir V. Putin in Moscow, President Emmanuel Macron gathered a few journalists this week to confide that the crisis in Ukraine was taking up “more than half my time, the bulk of my time” because the world stands “at a tipping point” of history.
Snippet: The French leader recounted his face-off with Vladimir Putin and dismissed Washington’s exchange of letters with Moscow, gambling that his diplomacy could pay off before April elections.

Title: Running a Business Under the Shadow of War
Text: When I was flying to Kyiv from Odesa last month, I arrived at the airport to find a policewoman blocking an entrance to the terminal. A considerable crowd was gathered across the road. Apparently someone had called in a bomb threat.
Snippet: “When you’re constantly thinking about invading Russians you’re not going to go buy a new phone, or a car, or a house.”

Title: U.S. Battles Putin by Disclosing His Next Possible Moves
Text: After decades of getting schooled in information warfare by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, the United States is trying to beat the master at his own game.
Snippet: Declassified information is part of a campaign to complicate what officials say are Russia’s plans to invade Ukraine.

Title: U.S. Pulls Most Diplomats From Kyiv as Tensions Mount
Text: President Biden warned President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia that invading Ukraine would result in “swift and severe” costs to Russia, diminish his country’s standing and cause “widespread human suffering,” the White House said on Saturday, as Western officials made a forceful diplomatic push to dissuade Mr. Putin from pressing forward with an attack.
Snippet: Western officials made another diplomatic push on Saturday to dissuade President Vladimir V. Putin from invading Ukraine.

Title: Giuliani in Talks to Testify to House Jan. 6 Panel
Text: Rudolph W. Giuliani, who as former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyer helped lead the effort to overturn the results of the 2020 election, is in discussions with the House Jan. 6 committee about responding to its questions, according to three people familiar with the matter.
Snippet: It is not clear how much assistance he might provide in the investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to hold onto power.

Title: Inside the Bitcoin Laundering Case That Confounded the Internet
Text: When anonymous hackers infiltrated the cryptocurrency exchange Bitfinex in 2016, it shook the nascent world of digital currency and prompted speculation about who might have stolen what was then $71 million in Bitcoin.
Snippet: The arrests of Ilya Lichtenstein and Heather Morgan left the world of cryptocurrency incredulous: Could this goofy young couple have been Bitcoin’s Bonnie and Clyde?

Title: He Knows Putin Well. And He Fears for Ukraine.
Text: As the threat of a new Russian invasion of Ukraine grew, the European head of state with the longest and deepest experience dealing with Vladimir V. Putin fielded calls and doled out advice to President Emmanuel Macron of France and other world leaders desperate for insight into his difficult neighbor to the east.
Snippet: The Finnish president, Sauli Niinisto, has carved out a vital role as interpreter between East and West, and he is not optimistic about the prospects for peace.

Title: Ukraine’s President Tries to Avert Panic as Pressure Mounts
Text: Russian attack helicopters were spotted buzzing within miles of his country’s borders on Sunday. The last strands of diplomacy were unraveling. Allies evacuated their embassies, airlines canceled flights, and a large number of private jets departed from the capital.
Snippet: With Ukraine at the center of Europe’s most intense security crisis of the post-Cold War era, President Zelensky is driving home his message of optimism.

Title: Germany Tries to Loosen Its Ties to Russian Gas Pipelines
Text: For decades, Germany has been a steadfast consumer of Russian natural gas, a relationship that has seemingly grown closer over the years, surviving Cold War-era tensions, the breakup of the former Soviet Union and even European sanctions against Moscow over its annexation of Crimea. Until this winter.
Snippet: An increasingly belligerent Russia, an energy crunch and a new Green minister of economics all add up to a change of direction in Germany’s policy on natural gas.

Title: Energy Markets Are Jittery as Russia-Ukraine Tensions Drag On
Text: A Russian invasion of Ukraine could drive up already high oil and natural gas prices, prolonging elevated inflation around the world and dealing a blow to any country dependent on Russia for energy.
Snippet: Oil prices are well over $90 a barrel, and an invasion would most likely push them above $100. Reflecting the uncertainty, stock markets were sliding lower.

Title: A Dark Moment for Goldman Sachs Goes to Trial
Text: Today, the onetime banker Roger Ng is set to stand trial in a Brooklyn courtroom over allegations that he abetted the looting of the huge Malaysian state fund known as 1MDB. The legal proceedings will resurrect a scandal that saw $4 billion stolen from the Malaysian government and tarnished the reputation of Ng’s former employer, Goldman Sachs.
Snippet: Opening arguments in a case tied to the 1MDB bribery scandal will begin today.

Title: Germany’s chancellor promises support while in Kyiv, on the eve of a meeting with Putin.
Text: The day before he is scheduled to meet President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, Germany’s chancellor, Olaf Scholz, visited Kyiv on Monday to promise full support to Ukraine in the case of a Russian invasion.
Snippet: The German leader said he would encourage business to invest in Ukraine, but ruled out sending weaponry.

Title: ‘We Need to Oppose Russia’: Ukrainians Find Common Purpose
Text: Fishing on a marbled expanse of frozen river, dressed head to toe in camouflage, Viktor Berkut looked very much the Soviet-born Everyman, and has the biography to match. He joined the Red Army in 1970 and spent three decades building air defense and rocket systems directed against Moscow’s ideological enemies in the West.
Snippet: A trip along the Dnieper River explores what it means to be Ukrainian at a moment of extreme peril, as the country debates Russia’s place in its past, and its future.

Title: The U.S. relocates its C.I.A. station in Kyiv, after moving its embassy farther from the Russian border.
Text: The United States temporarily relocated its C.I.A. station in Kyiv on Tuesday, a day after the State Department announced its diplomatic corps would move to Lviv, a western city near the border with Poland, because of the Russian military buildup near Ukraine, according to officials briefed on the shift.
Snippet: The American secretary of state said the temporary embassy would remain engaged with the Ukrainian government.

Title: Tone of Ukraine Crisis Shifts as Russia Signals Openness to Talk More
Text: Follow the latest news on Ukraine and Russia.
Snippet: Diplomacy is “far from exhausted,” Russia’s foreign minister said, while President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said the prospect of his country joining NATO might be just a “dream.”

Title: How One of the Most At-Risk Democrats in Congress Hangs On
Text: Holding a blue seat in a red-tinged place like Iowa’s Third Congressional District takes discipline. It takes a relentless focus on the folks back home, which is why you won’t see Cindy Axne yukking it up on “Morning Joe” or rubbing elbows with Jake Tapper on CNN. It takes doing who-knows-how-many hits on rural radio stations that might reach just a few hundred people at a time.
Snippet: Meet Representative Cindy Axne of Iowa, who has some advice for the White House about how to talk to voters.

Title: Germany’s chancellor meets with Putin as the tone of the crisis shifts.
Text: With the Kremlin signaling an openness to further diplomacy and Ukraine hinting at concessions to avert war, Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany met with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow on Tuesday, becoming the latest Western leader to embark on shuttle diplomacy to defuse the crisis in Eastern Europe.

Title: Reporting on the Ground in Ukraine
Text: As Russian troops are dispatched to Ukraine’s borders, the threat of a major assault on the country continues to escalate. Ukrainian soldiers stand guard at possible points of invasion, including sections of irradiated zones near Chernobyl. The United States has sent troops to NATO countries and has pulled most diplomats from Kyiv, Ukraine and world leaders are in contact with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to try to negotiate peace in the region. In a one-hour phone call on Saturday, President Biden warned Mr. Putin that an invasion would result in “swift and severe” costs.
Snippet: Andrew E. Kramer, a Times Moscow correspondent currently based in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, shares what he is seeing in the city and at the country’s border.

Title: A World Away From Ukraine, Russia Is Courting Latin America
Text: In the midst of his brinkmanship over neighboring Ukraine in recent weeks, President Vladimir V. Putin has also been busy trying to expand Russia’s influence thousands of miles away: in Latin America.
Snippet: The Ukraine crisis has revived a struggle over Latin America between the U.S. and Russia, as Vladimir V. Putin seeks greater influence in the region.

Title: How Ukrainians View This Perilous Moment
Text: Officials in the United States say that Russia could invade Ukraine as early as this week, which raises the question: Should an attack come, how will the Ukrainian people respond?
Snippet: A Russian invasion of the former Soviet state may be imminent. How will Ukraine’s citizens respond if it happens?

Title: What is a triple axel?
Text: It is almost certainly something that you should not try.
Snippet: The jump involves a forward-facing takeoff and three and a half rotations.

Title: Who Got Elon Musk’s Billions?
Text: via a regulatory filing with the S.E.C. — Elon Musk disclosed that he gave nearly $6 billion worth of Tesla shares to charity last year, instantly propelling him into the upper ranks of philanthropic donors. But the document gave little information about where the Tesla C.E.O. directed his wealth.
Snippet: The Tesla chief quietly disclosed a huge donation, but didn’t say where it went.

Title: Stocks rebound and oil slides after tension over Ukraine eases.
Text: Stocks rose and oil prices sank on Tuesday, after Russia took a step back on its military standoff over Ukraine, easing concerns over disruptions in global energy supplies.
Snippet: The military standoff, which had dragged Wall Street lower in recent days, showed signs of de-escalating, easing concerns over disruptions in global energy supplies.

Title: Navalny Appears in Penal Camp Court to Face More Charges
Text: Aleksei A. Navalny, the most prominent challenger to the rule of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, appeared at a court hearing on Tuesday to face charges of embezzlement and contempt of court that could extend his imprisonment by 15 years.
Snippet: Aleksei A. Navalny, the jailed Russian opposition leader, faces charges of embezzlement and contempt of court that could extend his time in jail by 15 years.

Title: U.S. Arms Sent to Ukraine Would Blunt but Not Stop a Russian Invasion
Text: President Biden has ruled out sending U.S. troops to fight in Ukraine, but American-made weapons are already there in force and more will be on the way. How effective they would be in turning back a Russian invasion is another question.
Snippet: The effectiveness of the weapons against the better-equipped Russian Army depends on what Moscow orders its troops to do.

Title: A hack of the Defense Ministry, army and state banks was the largest of its kind in Ukraine’s history.
Text: A top Ukrainian cybersecurity official said on Wednesday that a cyberattack against the websites of Ukraine’s defense ministry and army, as well as the interfaces of the country’s two largest banks on Tuesday, was the largest assault of its kind in the country's history and  “bore traces of foreign intelligence services.”
Snippet: Ukraine’s minister of digital transformation, Mykhailo Fedorov, said the attack “bore traces of foreign intelligence services.”

Title: Family of Slain Cinematographer Sues Alec Baldwin and ‘Rust’ Producers
Text: The family of Halyna Hutchins, the cinematographer fatally shot by Alec Baldwin on the set of the movie “Rust” last year, filed a wrongful-death lawsuit on Tuesday in New Mexico against crew members and producers, including Mr. Baldwin.
Snippet: The suit charges that Baldwin “recklessly shot and killed Halyna Hutchins on the set” and that the production’s “aggressive cost-cutting” had endangered the crew.

Title: On Ukraine, U.S. and Russia Wage Signaling War to Avert Actual War
Text: As their standoff over Ukraine continues, Moscow and Washington are playing an increasingly high-stakes, increasingly complex game of signaling to try to secure their aims without firing a shot.
Snippet: Each side is trying to convince the other that the price of conflict is too high. It is a complex game played with deliberate ambiguity, raising the risk of lethal miscalculation.

Title: U.S. Intelligence Agencies Face Crucial Test in Deciphering Putin’s Motives
Text: At the height of the Russian effort in 2016 to manipulate the U.S. presidential election, the C.I.A. had a secret weapon: a mole with some access to the inner circle of Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, who was able to inform Washington about how the master tactician was thinking about his next move.
Snippet: Knowing the intentions of any autocratic leader is difficult, but President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who began his career as a K.G.B. officer, poses a particular challenge.

Title: As Russia Welcomes Talks, Biden Warns Invasion Is Still Possible
Text: President Vladimir V. Putin said on Tuesday that Russia would “partially pull back troops” deployed near Ukraine and was seeking a “diplomatic path” to resolving a tense standoff with the West, while President Biden welcomed further negotiations but warned that a Russian invasion “remains very much a possibility.”
Snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin said he was pulling some Russian troops back from areas close to Ukraine, hinting at cooling the crisis, but U.S. officials say it is too soon to gauge his intentions.

Title: Late Night Dunks on Trump for Getting Dumped During Tax Season
Text: and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
Snippet: “It’s like getting divorced on Christmas Eve,” Jimmy Kimmel joked.

Title: Top European Court Rules E.U. Can Freeze Aid to Poland and Hungary
Snippet: In a landmark decision, the European Court of Justice cleared the way for the bloc to cut billions in aid on the grounds that members are eroding rule-of-law checks and balances.

Title: A Blueprint for Suing Gun Makers Emerges
Text: The gun maker Remington yesterday agreed to pay $73 million to settle a lawsuit by families of nine Sandy Hook shooting victims over the AR-15-style rifle used in the 2012 massacre. It’s believed to be the largest such settlement by a gun manufacturer, but it also raises questions about whether these companies will be held accountable in future shootings.
Snippet: Remington’s settlement with Sandy Hook families shows how a federal shield for the gun industry could be circumvented.

Title: On the Edge of a Polish Forest, Where Some of Putin’s Darkest Fears Lurk
Text: Tomasz Czescik, a Polish archaeologist and television journalist, walks his dog each morning through a forest near his home here on NATO’s eastern flank, wandering along the edge of a green chain-link fence topped with razor wire.
Snippet: A U.S. missile facility in Poland is at the heart of an issue animating the Kremlin’s calculations over whether to go to war against Ukraine.

Title: In Pictures: Ukraine holds military drills.
Text: Ukraine has sought for weeks to tamp down the language regarding the peril the country finds itself in as Russia amasses forces to its north, south and east. At the same time, the armed forces have been actively preparing to defend the nation. President Volodymyr Zelensky attended military exercises on Wednesday at a base near Rivne, about 60 miles from the Belarus border.

Title: Who built Putin’s long table? Competing claims arise from Spain and Italy.
Text: With Ukraine’s fate uncertain, world attention has focused on urgent negotiations, troop movements, threats, high-profile meetings.
Snippet: The oval behemoth, where President Vladimir V. Putin has met with world leaders, has become a subject of memes and think pieces, and now of a disagreement between furniture makers.

Title: NATO plans to shift forces to counter Moscow’s troop buildup around Ukraine.
Text: Pointing to the “new normal” of Europe in the face of Russian military provocations, the secretary-general of NATO said on Wednesday the alliance was drawing up plans for new combat units in central and southeastern Europe, while Britain said it was doubling the size of its NATO deployment in Estonia.

Title: Fed officials discussed removing policy support more quickly if inflation continues to accelerate.
Text: Officials at the Federal Reserve expressed concern about inflation at their meeting in January, in particular that it had spread beyond pandemic-affected sectors into other areas, and agreed it would be warranted to begin scaling back their support for the economy faster than they previously had anticipated, minutes of the meeting released Wednesday showed.
Snippet: Minutes from the Federal Reserve’s meeting in January reflected ongoing concern about prices rising across the economy.

Title: U.S. Warns Americans Abroad Not to Count on a Rescue
Text: As U.S. officials grew convinced this month that Russia might invade Ukraine, they implored American citizens to leave the country immediately — and added a grim addendum.
Snippet: In Ukraine and Ethiopia, Biden officials have made clear that the 2021 Kabul airlift was a “unique” operation that won’t be repeated.

Title: U.S. and Russian warplanes flew dangerously close to each other.
Text: U.S. and Russian warplanes operating in the eastern Mediterranean Sea flew dangerously close to each other in three separate incidents last weekend, including one in which the aircraft came within about five feet of each other, Pentagon officials said on Wednesday.
Snippet: Aircraft flew close in three incidents in the eastern Mediterranean, including one in which planes came within about five feet of each other.

Title: After winning medals in men’s aerial skiing, a Ukrainian and a Russian athlete embrace.
Text: Oleksandr Abramenko of Ukraine took second in men’s aerial skiing on Wednesday, earning the country’s first medal of the Beijing Games.
Snippet: The Ukrainian Oleksandr Abramenko and the Russian Ilia Burov celebrated with a gesture that transcended the rising tensions between the two countries.

Title: Ukraine Tensions Spike as West Accuses Russia of Lying About Troop Withdrawal
Text: Tensions over Ukraine abruptly ratcheted up on Wednesday as Western officials accused Russia of lying about whether it had really begun pulling back troops from the Ukrainian border.
Snippet: As Russia stoked hopes of a diplomatic solution and claimed to be pulling back forces from the Ukrainian border, U.S. and NATO officials accused Moscow of building up troops instead.

Title: On Ukraine Crisis, Biden Seeks to Show His Mettle
Text: complete with camera-ready scenes of frantic civilians, harried U.S. Marines and helicopters hovering over an embassy roof.
Snippet: The confrontation with Russia is a chance for the president to win back credibility on foreign policy. Can he?

Title: France Announces Troop Withdrawal From Mali After 9-Year Campaign
Text: France announced on Thursday that it would pull out its troops from the West African nation of Mali, bringing to a bitter end a nine-year military mission that has failed to quash a terrorist threat in the increasingly unstable region and has undermined France’s once dominant standing in many of its former African colonies.
Snippet: The pullout came after a falling out between France and Mali, in West Africa, ending a military effort that failed to drive out violent extremists.

Title: Why U.S. Soldiers Won’t Come to Ukraine’s Rescue
Text: In the last 48 hours, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his officials say they have ordered back a good number of troops who were engaged in military exercises on the border with Ukraine. But there hasn’t been a lot of change on the ground.
Snippet: Throughout the threat of a Russian invasion, Washington has rejected using its most powerful tool: troops.

Title: ‘A whistling sound, then an explosion’: Shelling hits a kindergarten in Ukraine.
Text: The fighting between Russian-backed separatists and Ukrainian government forces has been flaring for eight years. Daily skirmishes, mostly low-level, had become routine.
Snippet: “We’ve said for some time that the Russians might do something like this in order to justify a military conflict,” said the U.S. defense secretary, Lloyd J. Austin III. “So we’ll be watching this very closely.”

Title: As Russian Wins Mount, So Does the Scrutiny
Text: Inside the Olympic bubble, everybody just calls them the Russians.
Snippet: The fallout from a doping scandal at the 2014 Sochi Games and a troop buildup on the Ukrainian border have kept Russia, and its athletes, under a microscope.

Title: Child Safety Is the New Tech Battleground
Text: Two senators from opposite sides of the aisle introduced sweeping legislation yesterday that would require online platforms to help parents better control their children’s online experience. The Kids Online Safety Act, which comes after months of news reports and Congressional hearings on social media’s impact on children’s mental health and safety, is lawmakers’ latest bid to limit the power of internet giants.
Snippet: A bipartisan bill would impose sweeping new restrictions on internet platforms.

Title: After 30 Years of Peace, Ukraine Crisis Shakes Europeans
Text: Ulrike Franke is a self-confessed German millennial, a defense analyst who worries about her generation’s allergy to the military, especially as it moves into positions of power.
Snippet: The happy complacency of post-Cold War peace is being shattered by Russia’s threats, demands and massive military buildup around Ukraine.

Title: Sell-off of stocks deepens as Ukraine adds to investors’ worries.
Text: Stocks slid on Thursday, extending a volatile stretch of trading brought on by uncertainty about inflation, rising interest rates and the potential for war in Europe.
Snippet: The broad nature of Thursday’s decline pointed to more than one reason. Oil prices and yields on government bonds also fell.

Title: 30 years of post-Cold War peace in Europe is being shattered by the Ukraine crisis.
Text: Ulrike Franke is a self-confessed German millennial, a defense analyst who worries about her generation’s allergy to the military, especially as it moves into positions of power.

Title: Belarusian leader says exercises with Russia are not a sign of an imminent invasion of Ukraine.
Text: Mocking the United States for spending billions on intelligence agencies that he said had wrongly predicted an attack on Ukraine, the autocratic leader of Belarus, Russia’s western neighbor and closest ally, said Thursday that joint military exercises now underway between the countries did not presage an invasion — at least not now.
Snippet: “There will be no invasion tomorrow,” the strongman leader of Belarus told reporters after watching artillery and warplanes from Russia and his country put on a noisy display of firepower.

Title: U.S. Army Troops Arrive in Poland to Reassure Allies
Text: The last of nearly 5,000 troops from the 82nd Airborne Division arrived in Poland on Thursday, Pentagon officials said, providing reassurance to a pivotal NATO ally and expertise in assisting with the possible evacuation of Americans and others should Russia invade Ukraine.
Snippet: Nearly 5,000 soldiers from the 82nd Airborne Division are now in Poland in response to the Russian deployments on Ukraine’s borders.

Title: Artillery Exchanges in Eastern Ukraine May Presage Invasion, U.S. Warns
Text: Residents near Ukraine’s front line rushed into basements for cover Thursday as exchanges of artillery fire with Russian-backed separatists reached their most intense level in months, an ominous development amid Western fears that Russia might use the fighting as a pretext to invade Ukraine.
Snippet: As shelling intensified in the east, officials warned that Moscow might use false claims of “genocide” against Russians in the region as a pretext for an attack.

Title: The United States’ Message to Russia: Prove Us Wrong
Text: President Biden and his top aides acknowledge they are risking American credibility as they constantly renew the alarm that Russia is only “several days” away from triggering an unprovoked land war in Europe that could kill tens of thousands of Ukrainians in its opening hours, and plunge the world back into something resembling the Cold War.
Snippet: “If Russia doesn’t invade Ukraine, then we will be relieved that Russia changed course,’’ Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said at the United Nations.

Title: Tense fighting in Ukraine sets off a diplomatic scramble.
Text: As fears of a Russian invasion of Ukraine mount, President Biden is set to speak with global allies on Friday afternoon about Moscow’s buildup of military troops, in a continued effort to deter any hostile advances on its neighbor.

Title: What Australia’s Success at the Winter Olympics Does (and Doesn’t) Tell You
Text: On Sunday, the 2022 Winter Olympics will conclude. For Team Australia, its medal tally is small but significant. It has won four as of Friday, its most ever in the Winter Games, putting Australia 17th on the medals table, six spots higher than its final position in 2018. The haul includes a number of firsts for the country. Jakara Anthony’s gold in women’s moguls, Jaclyn Narracott’s silver in women’s skeleton, and Tess Coady’s bronze in women’s slopestyle are the first Olympic medals Australia has won in those disciplines.
Snippet: Australia has won more medals than ever at the 2022 Winter Games, but it’s hard to tell if global respect can turn the country into a winter sports wonderland.

Title: Trevor Noah: Russia Loves Playing Chess
Text: and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
Snippet: Noah said Russia has been preparing to play chess while Americans “love dumb games now,” poking fun at a preference for Wordle.

Title: ‘A whistling sound, then an explosion’: Shelling hits a kindergarten in Ukraine.
Text: The fighting between Russian-backed separatists and Ukrainian government forces has been flaring for eight years. Daily skirmishes, mostly low-level, had become routine.

Title: Stocks fall again as investors watch Ukraine developments cautiously.
Text: Stocks fell again on Friday, capping another down week as continued concerns about a Russian invasion of Ukraine added to Wall Street’s already-fragile sentiment.
Snippet: Concerns over a Russian troop buildup on the border with Ukraine continued to weigh on sentiment. The S&P 500 fell for the second consecutive week.

Title: The U.S. says it’s willing to risk being wrong over its warnings of an invasion.
Text: President Biden and his top aides acknowledge that they are risking American credibility as they constantly renew the alarm that Russia is only “several days” away from triggering a land war in Europe that could plunge the world back into something resembling the Cold War.

Title: What is the Munich Security Conference?
Text: In most years, the Munich Security Conference has focused on crises far away, like those in Afghanistan or Iraq. But for this year’s gathering, which begins Friday, the topic will be Europe itself, as one of its largest nations faces a potentially catastrophic invasion.
Snippet: The gathering was founded in 1963 as a way for Western leaders to discuss threats and dangers in an informal setting. This year’s focus is on the fabric of Europe.

Title: Vladimir Putin: Crafty Strategist or Aggrieved and Reckless Leader?
Text: At this moment of crescendo for the Ukraine crisis, it all comes down to what kind of leader President Vladimir V. Putin is.
Snippet: Analysts puzzling over the Russian leader’s intentions say that his troop buildup around Ukraine could be a convincing bluff, but also posit that he could have fundamentally changed during the pandemic.

Title: Russia sends mixed signals as tensions rise.
Text: Tensions between Russia and the West ratcheted up on Friday as Moscow announced plans to test nuclear-capable missiles and held war games on NATO’s doorstep in Belarus, while the United States said more Russian forces continued to take positions menacing Ukraine in a crisis that risks erupting into the biggest conflict in Europe in decades.

Title: Amid Ukraine tension, oil traders are betting on an Iran deal.
Text: Oil prices slumped on Friday, falling more than 3 percent before recovering lost ground later in the day, as Western leaders sounded the alarm about an imminent Russian invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: Prices fell, and then recovered, as speculation grew that a revived nuclear deal with Tehran could free millions of barrels of oil.

Title: A Quiet Exit for a ‘SPAC King’
Text: Virgin Galactic announced today that Chamath Palihapitiya, whose SPAC took the space tourism company public three years ago, has stepped down as its chairman. It’s a low-key and sudden departure for the outspoken financier, and another sign of the bad times that have hit the market for blank-check funds.
Snippet: Chamath Palihapitiya, a prolific sponsor of blank-check funds, is stepping down as chairman of Virgin Galactic.

Title: With French Election Looming, It Is Macron Against the Right
Text: France faces an unusual presidential election in seven weeks, with no credible left-wing contender, an electorate so disenchanted that abstention could be high, and a clear favorite who has not even announced his candidacy.
Snippet: The president, not even a formal candidate yet, seems to benefit from standing above the anti-immigrant fray.

Title: Kazakhstan’s Internet Shutdown Offers Lessons for Russia-Ukraine Crisis
Text: As Almaty, Kazakhstan’s largest city, spiraled into chaos last month over rising energy costs and anger at the government, the country’s leaders took a drastic step to quell protests: They blocked the internet.
Snippet: Control of the internet is increasingly part of any modern conflict.

Title: How Putin Has Already Weakened Ukraine’s Economy
Text: Pavlo Kaliuk, a freelance property broker in Ukraine’s capital, used to sell and rent properties to clients from the United States, France, Germany and Israel. Then in November, when Russia first began posting troops along the country’s border, the deals quickly dried up.
Snippet: Flights have been canceled, commercial shipping is threatened, and people fear an invasion is not far off.

Title: Biden says the U.S. believes Putin has decided to invade Ukraine.
Text: President Biden said on Friday that the United States had intelligence showing that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had made a final decision to invade Ukraine.

Title: A timeline of the tensions between Russia and Ukraine.
Text: Russia and Ukraine — are once again in conflict. Here are some pivotal moments in the years leading up to Moscow’s decision to invade the country on Feb. 24, as well as a brief look at relations between Russia and Ukraine in the 20th century.
Snippet: Here is a look at some key events in the run-up to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

Title: As Shelling Picks Up, Eastern Ukrainians Are Cowering
Text: Artillery shells struck a ring of frontline towns in eastern Ukraine Friday, blowing out windows, hitting schools, homes and military positions — and stirring fears that the escalation here is only the prelude to direct Russian military action.
Snippet: With nowhere to go, many are increasingly fearful that their villages could become the flash point for a wider war.

Title: CNN Executive Was Ousted After Discussing Interview Topics With Governor
Text: On a Saturday in March 2020, as Covid-19 was invading the United States, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo went on CNN for a live interview. Among other topics, he was asked about a possible government-enforced quarantine of New York that had been floated by President Donald J. Trump.
Snippet: An internal investigation found that a top executive, Allison Gollust, had extensive communications with then-Gov. Andrew Cuomo.

Title: Unable to Agree on Russia Sanctions Bill, Senate Settles for a Statement
Text: For weeks, as President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia signaled he was moving closer to invading Ukraine, members of Congress in both political parties vowed that the Senate would pass a “mother of all sanctions” bill targeting Moscow that would prove the overwhelming, bipartisan American resolve to stand with Kyiv against Russian aggression.
Snippet: A bipartisan push to pass the “mother of all sanctions” collapsed after Republicans insisted on imposing broad penalties before an invasion and Democrats, backing the White House, refused.

Title: Multinationals in Ukraine are ready for a conflict but staying put.
Text: Big American and European companies operating on the ground in Ukraine said Friday that they had contingency plans at the ready in case of a Russian invasion but so far had not ordered the relocation of employees.
Snippet: Despite warnings by Western leaders of an imminent Russian attack, U.S. and European companies say they see a low risk of an invasion.

Title: Celebrating 5 Years of The Daily
Text: On the morning of Feb. 1, Michael Barbaro sent an email to the Daily team with the subject line “5 Years!” For those of us still waking up bleary-eyed after producing that morning’s episode, it was a reminder: The Daily was having a birthday.
Snippet: The host, Michael Barbaro, reflects on half a decade of the show.

Title: What videos show about disputed claims in eastern Ukraine.
Text: Allegations of a car bomb and unsubstantiated claims of an imminent attack by Ukrainian forces have heightened tensions in areas of Ukraine held by pro-Russian separatists. The New York Times collected footage from the day to analyze some of the claims:

Title: Explaining Putin’s Decades-Long Obsession With Ukraine
Text: Winston Churchill once described Russia as “a riddle, wrapped in a mystery, inside an enigma.” It’s a phrase that could equally apply to Vladimir Putin, the Kremlin’s leader, as the world awaits his next move on Ukraine.
Snippet: We spoke with Fiona Hill, a former Trump adviser, about how the Russian leader’s view of history has led him to the brink of war.

Title: Videos show reported explosions near Luhansk.
Text: Two explosions were reported Friday near the city of Luhansk, capping off a volatile day in the pro-Moscow separatist regions of Donetsk and Luhansk in eastern Ukraine.

Title: Biden Says Putin Has Chosen ‘Catastrophic’ War Over Diplomacy
Text: President Biden said on Friday that the United States has intelligence showing that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has made a final decision to reject diplomatic overtures and invade Ukraine, in what Mr. Biden said would be a “catastrophic and needless war of choice” in Eastern Europe.
Snippet: President Biden spoke amid fears that Russia was setting the stage for an invasion that could ignite the biggest conflict in Europe in decades.

Title: As warnings of war grow louder, Ukrainians try to keep their bearings.
Text: Every February seems to be difficult for Julia Po. It is the month she had to leave her home in Crimea in 2014 after Russian troops annexed it and pro-Moscow separatists took control of parts of eastern Ukraine.
Snippet: The crisis has taken a toll on many Ukrainians.

Title: President Zelensky asks the West to make no deals ‘behind our back’ as the threat to Ukraine grows.
Text: As shelling hammered towns in eastern Ukraine on Saturday and civilians boarded buses to evacuate the region, Russia engaged in a dramatic display of military theater, test-firing ballistic and cruise missiles in a reminder to the West that a conflict over Ukraine could quickly escalate.

Title: Zelensky leaves Ukraine, heading to Munich to rally Western support.
Text: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine chose not to cancel his scheduled trip out of the country Saturday to attend a security conference in Munich, even as warnings from the West about a Russian invasion of his country grew increasingly urgent.

Title: Once He Kept Russia at a Distance. Now He Is a Docile Putin Satrap.
Text: In a winter military coat trimmed with fur, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko stepped out of his white presidential helicopter for a morning of geopolitical theater. His presidential limousine quickly delivered him to his waiting generals as aides and heavily armed bodyguards fluttered around him, shivering in the icy rain.
Snippet: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus once skillfully managed Moscow, but now he is doing the Kremlin’s bidding in Russia’s confrontation with Ukraine.

Title: The Ukraine Crisis: What to Know About Why Russia Attacked
Text: Follow live coverage on Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
