Snippet: Removing access to the financial messaging service would be the most severe penalty but could have unwanted consequences, including compromising energy exports to Europe.

Title: CPAC: From ‘City Upon a Hill’ to ‘Anti-Anti-Putin’
Text: In 1974, Gov. Ronald Reagan of California addressed a new conference of insurgent conservatives. But before he jumped into what would become one of his most famous speeches, laying out his vision of the nation as “the last best hope of man” and “a city upon a hill,” he introduced a young Navy pilot who had been recently released from a North Vietnamese prison.
Snippet: An annual meeting of conservatives was a launchpad for Ronald Reagan’s American idealism. Today, it’s a platform for a very different view of the world.

Title: Russian forces are meeting more resistance near Kyiv and Kharkiv than farther south, analysts say.
Text: Independent security analysts said Russian forces in the east and the south of Ukraine were maneuvering with less resistance than those forces that were farther north and approaching the cities of Kyiv and Kharkiv, where the attacks were less sophisticated and the Ukrainian military had succeeded in engaging Moscow’s army.

Title: Zelensky says Russian saboteurs are in Kyiv and he is Moscow’s prime target.
Text: Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, said that Russian saboteurs had entered Kyiv, the capital, and that he was “target No. 1” for Russian forces, followed by his family.

Title: ‘Putin Chose This War’: Biden Denounces Russia’s Actions in Ukraine
Text: President Biden on Thursday denounced President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his “sinister vision for the future of our world,” vowing that Mr. Putin and his country would pay as the United States imposed a new round of economic sanctions over Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: President Biden announced new sanctions but conceded that they would not immediately prevent President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia from continuing his military assault.

Title: Russia Batters Ukraine With Artillery Strikes as West Condemns Invasion
Text: Russia continued its attack on Ukraine early Friday, one day after it invaded the country by land, sea and air, killing more than 100 Ukrainian soldiers and civilians and ominously touching off a pitched battle at the highly radioactive area around the Chernobyl nuclear reactor that melted down in 1986.
Snippet: Explosions were reported over Kyiv, the capital. Several countries announced severe new sanctions, as Vladimir Putin remained resolute about his decision to invade.

Title: Another casualty of Russia’s invasion: Ukraine’s ability to contain the coronavirus.
Text: While Ukraine is under attack by Russia, Ukraine’s civilian population is also under siege from the coronavirus, a situation only likely to worsen.
Snippet: The fighting in Ukraine’s east is forcing a hurried mass migration that leaves little room for pandemic considerations.

Title: Trump Praises Putin, Leaving Republicans in a Bind
Text: As Russia prepared to strike Ukraine and the United States rushed to defend neighboring allies in Europe, former President Donald J. Trump had nothing but admiration for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
Snippet: G.O.P. leaders, while condemning Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, were silent on comments made by the former president. Some figures on the right amplified them.

Title: Russian invasion forces penetrate Ukraine on multiple fronts and close in on Kyiv.
Text: The Russian military plunged into Ukraine by land, sea and air on Thursday, killing more than 100 Ukrainian soldiers and civilians, and ominously touching off a pitched battle at the highly radioactive area around the Chernobyl nuclear reactor that melted down in 1986.

Title: Biden Hits Russia With Broad Sanctions for Putin’s War in Ukraine
Text: President Biden, vowing to turn President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia into a “pariah,” announced tough new sanctions on Thursday aimed at cutting off Russia’s largest banks and some oligarchs from much of the global financial system and preventing the country from importing American technology critical to its defense, aerospace and maritime industries.
Snippet: The penalties will affect Russia’s biggest banks, its weapons industry, its largest energy company and families close to President Vladimir V. Putin. The country’s stock market has plummeted.

Title: Ukraine Under Attack: Documenting the Russian Invasion
Text: Atrocities against civilians. Hundreds of casualties, with the toll rising. Millions of refugees. Thriving cities besieged and reduced to rubble.
Snippet: Photographers in and around Ukraine have captured the horrors of war.

Title: Biden will announce his Supreme Court nominee on Friday.
Text: President Biden will announce his Supreme Court nominee on Friday, according to two people familiar with his plans who were not authorized to speak publicly.
Snippet: President Biden’s decision ended a monthlong search to replace Justice Stephen G. Breyer, who is retiring.

Title: Covid Drove More Australians Away From Cities. Will They Go Back?
Text: If during the last two years you thought of leaving your locked-down Australian city for the freedom of a country town, you weren’t alone. A report released last week by the Regional Australia Institute found that in 2020 and 2021, net migration from state capitals to regional areas was more than twice as high as in 2018 and 2019.
Snippet: As restrictions ease, will the appeal of fewer people, a lower risk of transmission and more personal space prove to be enduring?

Title: Late Night Gets Serious About Ukraine
Text: and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
Snippet: Hosts did their best to bring levity to their shows on an otherwise somber day.

Title: Why the Toughest Sanctions on Russia Are the Hardest for Europe to Wield
Text: The punishing sanctions that the United States and European Union have so far announced against Russia for its invasion of Ukraine include shutting the government and banks out of global financial markets, restricting technology exports and freezing assets of influential Russians. Noticeably missing from that list is the one reprisal that would cause Russia the most pain: choking off the export of Russian fuel.
Snippet: Moscow relies on the money it makes by selling oil and gas, but that energy fuels Europe’s economy and heats its homes.

Title: Everything Looks Different Now
Text: Backstage at the Moschino show on Thursday, the day Russia attacked Ukraine, the designer Jeremy Scott was standing amid models dressed in clothing made to resemble the furnishings of a grand manse — a lampshade hat that was an actual lampshade; a satin bedspread coat complete with pillow as collar; a grandfather clock gown — and discussing what happens when crisis and fashion collide. Nearby, the milliner Stephen Jones was attaching an entire candelabra to one model’s head.
Snippet: Crisis and fashion collide at Moschino and Prada.

Title: European Leaders Agree to a Second Wave of Russia Sanctions
Text: European leaders meeting into the early hours of Friday hammered out an agreement over a new set of sanctions aimed more broadly at the Russian economy and at President Vladimir V. Putin himself, as his troops advanced in their invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The E.U. agreed to freeze the assets of President Putin and foreign minister Sergey Lavrov, while other measures will hit Russia’s access to technology

Title: Champions League Final Will Be Played in Paris, Not Russia
Text: Follow live updates of the UEFA Champions League final.
Snippet: European soccer officials stripped the game from St. Petersburg as punishment for Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and said they would not host games on Russian soil “until further notice.”

Title: U.S. Officials Repeatedly Urged China to Help Avert War in Ukraine
Text: Over three months, senior Biden administration officials held half a dozen urgent meetings with top Chinese officials in which the Americans presented intelligence showing Russia’s troop buildup around Ukraine and beseeched the Chinese to tell Russia not to invade, according to U.S. officials.
Snippet: Americans presented Chinese officials with intelligence on Russia’s troop buildup in hopes that President Xi Jinping would step in, but were repeatedly rebuffed.

Title: A Key Inflation Gauge Is Still Rising, and War Could Make It Worse
Text: A measure of inflation that the Federal Reserve watches closely accelerated again in January, hitting a new 40-year high and speeding up on a monthly basis as food and energy prices climbed sharply.
Snippet: The Federal Reserve’s preferred measure is at a four-decade high. Rising gas prices tied to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine could push it up further.

Title: Ukrainians’ Choice: Fight or Flee?
Text: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is the biggest in Europe since World War II.
Snippet: An exploration of the significance of Russia’s invasion and the decisions Ukrainians must now make.

Title: Stocks climb, erasing their losses for a tumultuous week.
Text: Investors pushed past Russia’s invasion of Ukraine to focus on a sliver of good news on Friday: that President Vladimir V. Putin might engage in talks with his Ukrainian counterpart. That hope drove stocks up, and the S&P 500 closed a rollercoaster week with a gain.
Snippet: Investors shrugged off the latest inflation data, focusing on the war in Ukraine and the possibility of talks with Russia.

Title: Russia says it won’t enter talks until Ukraine stops fighting.
Text: Russia on Friday rejected talks with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and made it clear that it was seeking to topple his democratically elected government, which Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov said was steered by “neo-Nazis” and the West.
Snippet: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey Lavrov, made clear that Russia was seeking to topple the democratically elected government of Ukraine.

Title: Russia confirms that it controls the former Chernobyl nuclear plant.
Text: Russia’s Defense Ministry said in a statement on Friday that its paratroopers had taken control of the territory around the former Chernobyl nuclear plant in northern Ukraine and were working with Ukrainian guards to ensure the safety of its facilities, contradicting Ukrainian claims that Russian forces were holding the plant’s personnel hostage.
Snippet: Russia’s Defense Ministry said it was working with Ukrainian guards to ensure the safety of the former plant, while Ukraine said Russian forces were holding the facility’s personnel hostage.

Title: Sanctions and Consequences
Text: Some Russian troops have entered Kyiv, with missile strikes also reported in the Ukrainian capital. President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said in a televised address that he was a primary target, and called on all Ukrainians to fight “the occupier.”
Snippet: The ripple effects of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine are coming into focus.

Title: Biden Picks Ketanji Brown Jackson for Supreme Court
Text: Follow the latest updates on Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s Supreme Court confirmation hearings.
Snippet: If confirmed, Judge Jackson, who drew the support of three Republicans in the Senate when elevated to a federal appeals court last year, would become the first Black woman on the Supreme Court.

Title: ‘Abrupt Changes’: China Caught in a Bind Over Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine
Text: that sovereignty is sacrosanct — in order to shield Moscow.
Snippet: China has presented itself as a defender of sovereign independence. But its reluctance to denounce Russia’s aggression forces it into an awkward position.

Title: A Humorous Ukrainian Writer, With Nothing to Laugh About
Text: Andrey Kurkov, one of Ukraine's most renowned authors, is often called a comic novelist for books like “Death and the Penguin,” about an obituary writer who takes in a penguin from a failing zoo.
Snippet: Andrey Kurkov wrote about fighting between Russia and Ukraine long before Thursday’s invasion. But now, more than ever, he wants to explain it to the world.

Title: Democrats are aiming for confirmation by early April.
Text: President Biden’s nomination of Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson to the Supreme Court immediately touched off intense Senate scrutiny of her record and initiated a well-established confirmation process that has become as much about politics and ideology as judicial record and professional background.
Snippet: Despite the goal of speedy approval, the outbreak of war in Ukraine could shift the timetable and the Senate’s attention.

Title: How the World Is Seeking to Put Pressure on Russia
Text: The United States, the European Union and several other countries and entities have expanded their economic sanctions against Russia as punishment for its invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: Several countries and the European Union have imposed a variety of sanctions in response to Vladimir V. Putin’s decision to invade Ukraine.

Title: Pope Francis Told to Sit Out Ceremonies Because of Knee Pain
Text: Pope Francis has abandoned plans for a trip to Florence this weekend and will be unable to preside over Ash Wednesday services next week because of acute knee pain, the Vatican said on Friday.
Snippet: A doctor recommended that Francis should take “a period of greater rest.”

Title: Ukraine War Bares U.S. Army Delay in Creating New ‘Monuments Officers’
Text: the cathedrals of Kyiv, the historic buildings of Lviv, museums across the country and the ancient burial sites that dot its steppes.
Snippet: Civilian specialists are tracking the threat to landmarks in Ukraine as the U.S. Army struggles after more than two years to appoint new cultural heritage preservation specialists modeled after the “Monuments Men.”

Title: Putin claims Russia has been fighting ‘nationalist groups,’ not the Ukrainian army.
Text: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia urged Ukrainian soldiers to lay down their arms, while describing the government of President Volodymyr Zelensky as “a band of drug addicts and neo-Nazis.”
Snippet: Russian state television aired brief remarks by Mr. Putin as he spoke by video to his Security Council.

Title: Soccer, Russia and a Line Drawn Too Late
Text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
Snippet: Soccer did not have to allow itself to be the field in which geopolitical rivalries played out, or the stage on which oligarchs sought power and prestige.

Title: Scenes from Kharkiv: Battle wreckage, the boom of artillery, and people sheltering in the subway.
Text: The thuds of artillery start as a low-decibel rumble, but rattle the rib cage as you get closer. A crossroads at the northern entrance of Kharkiv is about as close to the front lines as anyone would wish to be on Friday, as Ukrainian soldiers waged a fierce battle to push Russian forces away from the city.
Snippet: Ukrainian troops dug in around the nation’s second-largest city a day after a fight to push back advancing Russian forces.

Title: Ukraine on TV: We’ve Seen This Before. And We’ve Never Seen Anything Like It.
Text: If you are more than a few decades old, the invasion of Ukraine was horrific but familiar. It was what TV had taught you to expect since childhood.
Snippet: As the invasion unfolded, images straight out of Cold War nightmare dramas butted up against 21st-century politics.

Title: A Fraudster Who Just Can’t Seem to Stop … Selling Eyeglasses
Text: What if they can’t help it?
Snippet: Consider the case of an online retail bully who appears to keep harassing his customers.

Title: Ukraine and the Mirage of Energy Independence
Text: It may be time to pluck that old cardigan out of the closet.
Snippet: Domestic oil and gas production in the U.S. boomed in recent years. But the country and its allies remain reluctant to impose sanctions on Russian energy that would damage their economies.

Title: ‘I’ll Stand on the Side of Russia’: Pro-Putin Sentiment Spreads Online
Text: The day before Russia invaded Ukraine, former President Donald J. Trump called the wartime strategy of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia “pretty smart.” His remarks were posted on YouTube, Twitter and the messaging app Telegram, where they were viewed more than 1.3 million times.
Snippet: After marinating in conspiracy theories and Donald J. Trump’s Russia stance, some online discourse about Vladimir Putin has grown more complimentary.

Title: Russia says it will limit access to Facebook, a major platform for dissent.
Text: The Russian government said it was partially limiting access to Facebook for restricting some pro-Kremlin news media accounts, a move that could make it harder for Russians to share their anger over their country’s invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: Since President Vladimir V. Putin launched his attack on Ukraine, many Russians have taken to social media to express their anger.

Title: Far-right militias in Europe plan to confront Russian forces, a research group says.
Text: The Russian attack on Ukraine has prompted a flurry of activity among far-right European militia leaders, who have taken to the internet to raise funds, recruit fighters and plan travel to the front lines to confront the country’s invaders, according to a research group.
Snippet: The apparent mobilization of far-right groups could be problematic for the Ukrainian government

Title: A Canadian leader with Ukrainian roots puts Putin in the ranks of ‘reviled European dictators.’
Text: In Canada, a country with one of the world’s largest Ukrainian diasporas, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has been met with particularly visceral emotion, including from the deputy prime minister, Chrystia Freeland, the daughter of a Ukrainian-Canadian mother.
Snippet: Canada has a large population with Ukrainian roots, including Chrystia Freeland, the deputy prime minister, whose interest in Ukrainian independence dates to the Soviet era.

Title: Eurovision bars Russia from this year’s song contest.
Text: The Eurovision Song Contest, a cultural phenomenon that was the springboard for Abba and Celine Dion and is watched annually by 200 million people, has decided that no Russian act will be allowed to participate in this year’s contest.
Snippet: “The inclusion of a Russian entry in this year’s contest would bring the competition into disrepute,” the organizers said on Friday.

Title: The International Energy Agency ponders market intervention over the Ukraine invasion.
Text: The International Energy Agency said representatives from its 31 member countries met Friday to discuss the impact of the Russian invasion of Ukraine on global energy markets.
Snippet: A meeting discussed “increased concerns” in energy markets, and appeared to signal the group was getting ready to intervene, perhaps with a release of oil.

Title: Valery Gergiev Faces Removal From Podiums Over Support for Putin
Text: including the Munich Philharmonic, of which Mr. Gergiev is chief conductor — threatening to sever ties with him unless he denounced Mr. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The Munich Philharmonic and other institutions threatened to cut ties with the Russian conductor unless he denounced the invasion of Ukraine.

Title: In North Africa, Ukraine War Strains Economies Weakened by Pandemic
Text: On the way to the bakery, Mona Mohammed realized Russia’s war on Ukraine might have something to do with her.
Snippet: Egypt imports most of its wheat from Russia and Ukraine, and is looking for alternative suppliers. And Tunisia was struggling to pay for grain imports even before the conflict.

Title: Jackson had long been at the top of Biden’s short list.
Text: When President Biden and his advisers began planning for a possible Supreme Court vacancy during the presidential transition, Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson was brought up as one of the likeliest possibilities.
Snippet: Judge Jackson’s ability to garner Republican votes made her an attractive candidate, but President Biden’s advisers said that he wanted to choose someone in the mold of the justice she would be replacing.

Title: The U.S. and Europe target Putin with sanctions.
Text: The United States and Europe moved on Friday to personally penalize President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for his invasion of Ukraine, imposing sanctions aimed at freezing his wealth while continuing to try to cripple his military and economic capabilities through other new restrictions.
Snippet: The new penalties are a provocative step given how rarely governments, including the United States, take aim at foreign leaders.

Title: OPEC Plus meets, and the Fed chair testifies: the week ahead in business.
Chernobyl Plant Is Unharmed Despite Russian Invasion of Ukraine, Scientists Say
Text: The failed Chernobyl nuclear power plant in northern Ukraine as well as the nation’s 15 operating reactors are safe and secure amid Russia’s invasion, according to nuclear experts and the International Atomic Energy Agency, an arm of the United Nations that sets safety standards for the world’s nuclear reactors and inspects them for compliance.
Snippet: at least for the moment.

Title: How to Talk to Kids About Ukraine
Text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
Snippet: Young people have access to more news streams than ever, and many are concerned. Here’s how to address their questions.

Title: Will Kyiv Fall?
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict. I’m your host, Carole Landry. Here’s the latest.
Snippet: Ukrainians are battling to defend their capital against advancing Russian troops.

Title: This Is Just the Beginning
Text: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
Snippet: Bombs are falling in Europe. And the future is uncertain.

Title: At the Polish Border, Tens of Thousands of Ukrainian Refugees
Text: Cradling her 3-year-old son, who was gravely ill with cancer, the 25-year-old Ukrainian mother staggered into Poland on Friday.
Snippet: They have been warmly welcomed in a country whose border guards last year beat back mostly Afghan and Middle Eastern migrants with batons.

Title: Russia’s Assault in Ukraine Slows After an Aggressive Start
Text: For the Russian military, the difficult part came quickly.
Snippet: The invading forces have faced stiff resistance, but President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia could quickly send in more troops, Pentagon officials said.

Title: In Video, a Defiant Zelensky Says, ‘We Are Here’
Text: As Russian missiles bombarded the Ukrainian capital Kyiv on Friday, President Volodymyr Zelensky seemed to go missing. Italy’s prime minister even told his own parliament, in a tremulous voice, that Mr. Zelensky had missed a planned call with him.
Snippet: The 44-year-old president of Ukraine videotaped himself in Kyiv as Russian forces closed in on the capital, vowing to fight them to the end.

Title: As Democrats Cheer Jackson Pick, Republicans Pledge Respectful Review
Text: Democrats on Friday promised a swift confirmation process for Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, celebrating President Biden’s pick for the Supreme Court as Republicans signaled that they had little appetite for a toxic battle over the first Black woman to be nominated for the post.
Snippet: The showdown over Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s nomination could be less toxic than other recent Supreme Court confirmations.

Title: Biden Made a Historic Supreme Court Pick. What Now?
Text: When word first leaked Friday that President Biden had chosen Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson as the first Black woman to serve on the Supreme Court, Democrats and civil rights activists were ecstatic.
Snippet: Nominating the first Black woman is both bold and politically savvy, Democrats told us. Republicans are divided over how much of a fight to put up.

Title: Ukraine Girds for Kyiv Attack Amid Signs of Slowing Russian Advance
Text: Ukraine braced for an all-out assault on its capital early Saturday, after a day in which the military blew up a bridge to slow the advance of Russian soldiers, street fights erupted in a northern district of the city, and the nation’s leaders warned residents that Russia wanted to “bring the capital to its knees.”
Snippet: President Volodymyr Zelensky warned in a video address that Russian “sabotage groups” had entered Kyiv with the aim of decapitating his government by “destroying the head of state.”

Title: State Dept. Says Moscow’s Ukraine Diplomacy Was a ‘Pretense’
Text: The Biden administration said on Friday that Russia was never serious about finding a diplomatic solution to the crisis over Ukraine, and that weeks of back-and-forth between Washington and Moscow amounted to a sham as the Kremlin prepared for war.
Snippet: Officials in the Biden administration met repeatedly with Russian emissaries as the threat of an invasion of Ukraine grew more apparent.

Title: Russia vetoes a U.N. Security Council resolution calling on it to withdraw from Ukraine.
Text: Russia on Friday vetoed a United Nations Security Council resolution of which it was the target, effectively blocking action by the panel, which is responsible for protecting and maintaining international peace.
Snippet: Eleven countries voted in favor of the U.S.-backed measure, and three abstained.

Title: Landmarks in New York and elsewhere use lights to show support for Ukraine.
Text: Several New York landmarks are being illuminated in blue and yellow, the colors of the Ukrainian flag, through the weekend as a show of solidarity for the people of Ukraine, Gov. Kathy Hochul said on Friday.
Snippet: The landmarks include the World Trade Center, the Eiffel Tower and more.

Title: They Do Business in Russia, and Now They May Pay a Price
Text: French energy companies operating in Russia’s Arctic Sea. Italian luxury boutiques near Red Square. German auto factories around the Russian south.
Snippet: European companies that have operations in Russia are preparing for collateral damage as Western sanctions aim to penalize Russia’s economy.

Title: On both sides of the Korean Peninsula, eyes are on Washington’s response to Russia.
Text: Both North and South Korea are likely to be closely watching the American response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, though for different reasons, analysts say.
Snippet: North Korea might decide it’s time to resume weapons tests, to gain more diplomatic leverage with Washington.

Title: Worried About Stocks? Think of Ukrainians Under Siege First.
Text: In the days since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, plenty of people have tried to predict what it will mean for gas prices or interest rates or your investments.
Snippet: If you have an investment portfolio or own a home, you’ve probably experienced big gains. Here’s how to use those winnings to help.

Title: Video shows a missile hitting a residential building in Kyiv.
Text: Videos and photos verified by The New York Times showed a residential building struck by a missile in southwestern Kyiv, about 1.5 miles from Sikorsky Memorial Airport, on Saturday morning. Videos showed rescue and evacuation efforts underway.
Snippet: The missile hit a building about 1.5 miles from Sikorsky Memorial Airport.

Title: U.S. Oil Industry Uses Ukraine Invasion to Push for More Drilling at Home
Text: Russian troops hadn’t yet begun their full-on assault on Ukraine late Wednesday when the rallying cry came from the American oil and gas industry.
Snippet: The goal is “energy security,” lobbyists said, although clean-energy advocates counter that wind and solar provide more protection from boom-and-bust oil markets.

Title: Before Ukraine Invasion, Russia and China Cemented Economic Ties
Text: As Russia wreaks havoc in Ukraine, Moscow has a powerful economic ally to help it resist Western sanctions: China.
Snippet: Facing a wary United States and worried about depending on imports by sea, China is buying more energy and food from its northern neighbor.

Title: Russia Intensifies Censorship Campaign, Pressuring Tech Giants
Text: As Russia attacks Ukraine, the authorities in Moscow are intensifying a censorship campaign at home by squeezing some of the world’s biggest tech companies.
Snippet: Google, Apple and others were warned that they must comply with a new law, which would make them more vulnerable to the Kremlin’s censorship demands.

Title: The Trucks Are Gone From Ottawa, but Their Aftermath Lingers
Text: With the protesters who blocked its streets and disrupted life in Ottawa for three weeks routed and the Russian invasion of Ukraine underway, attention to the blockade of the Canadian capital by truckers and other protesters who rejected pandemic measures is fast fading. But while the protest may be over, its effects continue to linger in the city’s downtown and much remains to sort out in its aftermath.
Snippet: Streets remained blocked in Ottawa, and many issues, including compensation for those who lost income during the protests, are unresolved.

Title: Ukrainian forces slow Russian advance as the U.S. and its allies take action on Russian banks.
Text: Through intense fighting in the streets of Kyiv and other cities on Sunday, Ukraine’s defense forces and civilian volunteers resisted Russia’s invasion for a fourth day, battling for control of the capital as international pressure mounted on Moscow and support for Kyiv’s besieged government grew.

Title: Russia’s Ukraine Invasion Raises Questions About Energy Policy
Text: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
Snippet: Daniel Yergin, the author of several books about geopolitics and oil, talked with DealBook about the complicated relationship between renewable energy and energy security.

Title: For Ukraine’s Refugees, Europe Opens Doors That Were Shut to Others
Text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
Snippet: Thousands of Ukrainians will end up in countries led by nationalist governments that have been reluctant to welcome refugees in the past.

Title: Putin’s Aggression Leaves His Right-Wing Fan Club Squirming
Text: For years, a global choir of right-wing politicians have sung the praises of Vladimir V. Putin. They looked up to the Russian strongman as a defender of closed borders, Christian conservatism and bare-chested machismo in an era of liberal identity politics and Western globalization. Fawning over him was a core part of the populist playbook.
Snippet: The Russian strongman has for years been idolized by a Who’s Who of populist, nationalist leaders. They are now stumbling over what to say.

Title: As battle for Kyiv rages, Ukraine’s president tries to rally his people.
Text: As Russian troops lay siege to Kyiv, the president of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, again appeared on camera on Saturday to furnish proof of his continued presence in his country’s capital, praise his outgunned and outmanned military and beseech Western countries for more support.
Snippet: “We have withstood and successfully repelled enemy attacks,” President Volodymyr Zelensky said in the video. “The fighting continues in many cities and districts of our state, but we know that we protect the country, the land, the future of childr...

Title: Putin’s War Ushers In Crisis for Russia
Text: President Vladimir V. Putin has ushered in a crisis for his country — in its economy and identity.
Snippet: Despite the Kremlin’s efforts to obscure the offensive in Ukraine, the costs of the war were already evident in both economic and social turmoil.

Title: Chris Licht, a Creator of ‘Morning Joe’ and ‘Colbert’ Producer, Is Set to Run CNN
Text: Chris Licht, a veteran television producer who helped create “Morning Joe” at MSNBC and later successfully retooled morning and late-night programming at CBS, is set to be the next leader of CNN, according to three people with direct knowledge of the decision.
Snippet: He will take over CNN as the network gets a new corporate owner. He replaces Jeff Zucker, the network president who abruptly resigned this month.

Title: Biden and Putin, Children of the Cold War, Face Off in New Conflict
Text: As President Biden tells the story, he was blunt with Vladimir V. Putin during a meeting in Moscow more than a decade ago. “I’m looking into your eyes, and I don’t think you have a soul,” Mr. Biden recalled telling the K.G.B. veteran. Mr. Putin smiled. “We understand one another,” he said.
Snippet: Not since John F. Kennedy and Nikita S. Khrushchev confronted each other over Berlin and Cuba have an American president and Russian leader gone eyeball to eyeball in quite such a dramatic fashion.

Title: Russia Advances on 3 Ukrainian Cities, but Meets Fierce Resistance
Text: The Ukrainian military, outmanned and outgunned, waged ferocious, close-range battles on Saturday to maintain control of the capital, Kyiv, and other cities around the country as intense street fighting broke out on the third day of the Russian invasion.
Snippet: Ukraine’s leader said his forces had “repelled” the Russian army’s assault. Moscow claimed it had merely “paused” for the possibility of peace negotiations.

Title: Putin Faces Sanctions, but His Assets Remain an Enigma
Text: When Western governments announced on Friday their intention to freeze assets belonging to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as punishment for invading Ukraine, there was no indication they knew of significant holdings that could be tied to him.
Snippet: On paper, the Russian president appears to own very little. Yet estimates put his hidden wealth well over $100 billion.

Title: For Some Americans, Ukraine’s Fight Feels Close to Home
Text: They refreshed their newsfeeds and prayed. They tried to sleep, and didn’t. Some feared for loved ones they worried over by name. Others felt the conflict in Ukraine filtered through their own experiences, shifting their plans and their sense of stability.
Snippet: The Russian invasion deeply affects Ukrainians in the United States, but it also resonates with a 100-year-old Holocaust survivor in Texas and a Taiwanese American family in Georgia.

Title: Stranded Players, Desperate Calls and a Race to Flee Kyiv
Text: mortar fire, rocket blasts, screeching warplanes — provided a near constant reminder of their precarious circumstances.
Snippet: “We are here asking for your help,” one Brazilian soccer player pleaded. “There’s no way we can get out.”

Title: ‘Everybody in Our Country Needs to Defend’
Text: Glass shards, bits of metal and shell casings, the detritus from a fierce and lethal street fight in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, lay scattered over hundreds of yards of pavement. Leading away from the site were bloody footprints.
Snippet: Civilian volunteers and paramilitary groups are taking the fight to the Russian army in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.

Title: In Mideast, After Decades of War, the Mass Flight From Ukraine Resonates
Text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
Snippet: Many in the region took to social media to express sympathy for Ukrainians forced to flee, though their warm welcome in Europe evoked a tinge of bitterness over the treatment of Arab and Muslim migrants.

Title: Putin Seems to Sideline Advisers on Ukraine, Taking a Political Risk
Text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
Snippet: Authoritarian leaders rely on elite support to govern. Jeopardizing those relationships in wartime could be risky, experts say.

Title: At CPAC, Ukraine and Policy Take a Back Seat to Cultural Grievances
Text: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has much of the world transfixed and on edge. President Biden announced a new Supreme Court appointment who is unlikely to get any significant Republican support.
Snippet: The annual gathering of American conservatives reflected the G.O.P’s shift away from policy issues that had traditionally animated the party.

Title: The U.S. and Europe will bar some Russian banks from SWIFT.
Text: The Biden administration and key allies announced on Saturday that they would remove some Russian banks from the SWIFT financial messaging system, essentially barring them from international transactions. They also said they would impose new restrictions on Russia’s central bank to prevent it from using its large international reserves to undermine sanctions.
Snippet: The move, along with new restrictions on Russia’s central bank, represented a significant escalation in the effort to impose severe economic costs on Russia for its invasion of Ukraine.

Title: Sheltering in Kyiv While Showing in New York
Text: In a showroom in the NoHo section of Manhattan, a laptop sat on a table, tucked behind a rack of knitwear by the Ukrainian label 91 Lab. The computer streamed CNN silently. Ominous footage from the streets of Kyiv, the capital of Ukraine, caught the eye of Alina Bairamova, the fashion industry coordinator for Ukrainian Fashion, a showcase for Ukrainian designers.
Snippet: A showroom in NoHo highlights six designers with roots and family in the country.

Title: Putin’s critics call for boycotts of Russian vodka.
Text: Vodka, a drink that was popularized in the West by James Bond and that has long been one of Russia’s most visible exports, is now the target of international anger over the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The governors of New Hampshire and Ohio announced measures aimed halting the sales of Russian-made and Russian-branded spirits.

Title: Ukrainians escape to neighboring Poland.
Text: More than 150,000 refugees have fled Ukraine this week, according to the United Nations, with many heading toward Polish border crossings.

Title: North Korea Launches a Ballistic Missile, South Korea Says
Text: North Korea on ​Sunday launched​ a ballistic missile toward the sea off its east coast in its eighth missile test of the year, the South Korean military said.
Snippet: Flight data suggested that the missile launched Sunday was less powerful than the last one the North tested, four weeks ago.

Title: At CPAC, Trump Misleads About Biden, a Russian Pipeline and Gas Prices
Text: Former President Donald J. Trump repeated familiar boasts and grievances in a keynote speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference on Saturday.
Snippet: The former president made inaccurate claims about his border wall, the Biden administration and a Russian pipeline, among other topics.

Title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Pays Tribute to Ukraine
Text: This weekend, “Saturday Night Live” faced two questions of significantly different orders of magnitude: Would the show try to find topical humor in the Russian invasion of Ukraine?
Snippet: This week’s episode, hosted by John Mulaney, began not with a comedy sketch but with a performance by a Ukrainian chorus.

Title: Why the Chinese Internet Is Cheering Russia’s Invasion
Text: If President Vladimir V. Putin is looking for international support and approval for his invasion of Ukraine, he can turn to the Chinese internet.
Snippet: As the world overwhelmingly condemns the assault on Ukraine, online opinion in China is mostly pro-Russia, pro-war and pro-Putin.

Title: The Week in Business: With Ukraine Invasion, Volatile Markets
Text: Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine whipsawed global markets amid uncertainty over the conflict’s potential impact on inflation, the operations of multinational corporations, energy prices and the flow of energy to Europe. In recent years, Europe has received nearly 40 percent of its gas and more than a quarter of its oil from Russia. In addition, Ukraine and Russia together produce nearly a quarter of the world’s wheat, and Russia is a key supplier of other major commodities. The fallout from the conflict is likely to continue to push up inflation. That creates an economic pickle for the Federal Reserve and its plans to begin raising interest rates in March. Pulling back support for the economy may help reduce inflation, but it also could weigh on economic growth if consumers reduce their spending. Several Fed officials have signaled that they are unlikely to change course.
Snippet: The U.S. and the European Union have imposed a range of financial penalties on Russia. Companies are again setting dates for return to the office. And the February jobs numbers come out.

Title: Ukraine’s pipeline operator says gas continues to flow after an explosion near a Kharkiv facility.
Text: Ukraine’s gas pipeline operator said on Sunday that the transmission of natural gas through its system was continuing “normally” and that it had not recorded a drop in pressure after an explosion in the area of Kharkiv, the country’s second-largest city. The Gas Transmission System Operator of Ukraine added that it was unable to visually inspect the site because of military activity in the city.
Snippet: Ukraine is one of the major transmission routes for Russian gas to Europe.

Title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 28, 2022
Text: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
Snippet: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.

Title: More countries ban Russian flights from their airspace.
Text: A growing number of countries announced on Sunday that they were closing their airspace to Russian planes in response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The E.U. and Canada barred Russian planes in response to the invasion of Ukraine.

Title: Russia’s invasion prompts Germany to beef up military funding.
Text: In an extraordinary address to a special session of Parliament on Sunday, Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced a significant increase in military spending, reversing the country’s longstanding policy that has favored deterrence over conflict.
Snippet: Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced a major increase to Germany’s defense budget, a shift in longstanding policy.

Title: Britain’s top diplomat says she would support people going to fight for Ukraine.
Text: Britain’s foreign secretary, Liz Truss, said on Sunday that she would support Britons who want to go to Ukraine to take up arms to resist the Russian invasion, in an intervention likely to escalate tensions with Moscow.
Snippet: Britain’s foreign secretary said people should “absolutely” go to Ukraine and fight “if that is what they want do to.”

Title: Ukraine Invasion Tests the Ties That Bind Putin and Xi
Text: They visited a hockey rink in Beijing and the panda enclosure at the Moscow Zoo. They shared blinis layered with caviar in Russia and, reciprocally, the popular variant in China, jianbing. They have shared birthday cakes and exchanged toasts with shots of vodka, while demurring that neither would dare go overboard with the stuff.
Snippet: The two autocrats have brought their countries closer together than ever. But for China, the costs of Russia’s adventurism could be high.

Title: U.S. deflects Putin’s nuclear alert as another effort at escalation.
Text: The White House avoided a heated response to President Vladimir V. Putin’s announcement that he was putting Russia’s nuclear forces on alert, casting it as another example of Mr. Putin’s moves to imagine a threat and escalate the confrontation with the West.
Snippet: Both countries have various levels of alert, and it was unclear how Putin’s wording would be implemented by Russian nuclear forces.

Title: BP to ‘Exit’ Stake in Russian Oil Giant Rosneft
Text: The British oil giant BP said on Sunday that it would “exit” its nearly 20 percent stake in Rosneft, the Russian state-controlled oil company, making it one of the first large companies to abandon Russia after its invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: Russian holdings may become toxic for the Western oil industry.

Title: Europe escalates measures against Russia with flight bans and weapons for Ukraine.
Text: European countries under the banner of the European Union banded together for the first time to finance the provision of lethal weapons to Ukraine, in what the bloc’s top official called “a watershed moment.”

Title: Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine: A Forum for Young People to React
Text: Update, March 3: Thank you for your thoughtful and heartfelt posts. Our editors have read the 900-plus comments that have come in so far, and have created a roundup featuring a selection of your reactions.
Snippet: We invite teenagers to share what they have felt, discussed and wondered in the days since Russia attacked Ukraine.

Title: How Volodymyr Zelensky rallied Ukrainians, and the world, against Putin.
Text: Before Russia invaded Ukraine, President Volodymyr Zelensky was often derided as a comic turned unlikely politician. But with the help of social media, he has become the leader Ukraine did not know it needed.
Snippet: Mr. Zelensky’s decision to remain in the capital, Kyiv, while it’s under Russian attack has moved many.

Title: FIFA Proposes Penalties for Russia but No Ban, Yet
Text: a ban on Russia’s name, flag and anthem and a neutral site for its games — do not include the all-out ban on Russia’s national team that its opponents are demanding, making it unclear if the punishments will resolve the confrontation, or if the games will be played at all.
Snippet: The restrictions proposed by soccer’s governing body for a World Cup playoff next month stopped short of the all-out ban Russia’s opponents have demanded.

Title: Once Sleepy and Picturesque, Ukrainian Villages Mobilize for War
Text: The villagers appeared as silhouettes in the headlights of cars and trucks, a few carrying guns and others clubs, as if they were gangsters roaming the streets.
Snippet: While Russian assaults on Ukrainian cities have drawn most of the attention in the war’s early days, civilians in country towns have joined the fight, putting aside the routines of daily village life.

Title: Barr Rebukes Trump as ‘Off the Rails’ in New Memoir
Text: Former Attorney General William P. Barr writes in a new memoir that former President Donald J. Trump’s “self-indulgence and lack of self-control” cost him the 2020 election and says “the absurd lengths to which he took his ‘stolen election’ claim led to the rioting on Capitol Hill.”
Snippet: William P. Barr’s memoir of his time as attorney general under George H.W. Bush and then again under Donald J. Trump defends his more recent leadership of the Justice Department.

Title: Alexei Ratmansky, With Family in Kyiv, Leaves His Ballet in Moscow
Text: The choreographer Alexei Ratmansky, the former artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet who is now artist in residence at American Ballet Theater, was preparing a new ballet at the Bolshoi in Moscow when President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia made his announcement, early Thursday morning, that he had launched an invasion of neighboring Ukraine.
Snippet: The New York-based choreographer, who was working on a new ballet for the Bolshoi, said he doubted he would return to Russia to work “if Putin is still president.”

Title: The European Union will ask states to grant asylum to Ukrainian refugees for up to 3 years.
Text: More than 300,000 Ukrainians have fled to the European Union since the Russian invasion of Ukraine began on Thursday, and the bloc is bracing itself for the arrival of up to four million Ukrainian refugees, E.U. officials said on Sunday.
Snippet: More than 300,000 people have fled into the European Union since Russia invaded Ukraine on Thursday, the bloc said, and it is expecting millions more.

Title: Norway’s sovereign wealth fund plans to divest from the Russian market.
Text: Norway’s sovereign wealth fund is freezing its assets in Russia and plans to divest from the Russian market, a spokeswoman for the fund said Sunday.

Title: Ukraine War Forces Hungary’s Orban Into Political Contortions
Text: A dusty border town with a train station in northeastern Hungary, near the border with Slovakia and Ukraine, has become a transit point for people fleeing Russia’s war against Ukraine. It also has thrown a wrench into the political calculations of Prime Minister Viktor Orban, Hungary’s illiberal, Russia-friendly, anti-immigrant strongman.
Snippet: The pro-Russia, anti-immigrant Hungarian prime minister, who denounced any sanctions against Russia just weeks ago, has been forced to reverse himself as an election looms.

Title: Ukrainians in Britain Take Up the Cause Back Home
Text: A Ukrainian deliveryman in the English town of Basildon watched the first days of the Russian invasion of his country on television before deciding he had seen enough.
Snippet: Whether vowing to kill Russians or offering medical supplies, Ukrainian citizens are too impatient to sit idly by.

Title: ‘I’m a Soldier Now.’ Even in Untouched Villages, Ukrainians Prepare to Fight
Text: Outside the large military hospital in the central Ukrainian city of Dnipro, people lined up on Sunday to donate warm clothes and water, while a priest moved among the crowd offering sips of holy wine from a silver chalice. He allowed those waiting to kiss the large silver cross he wore on a chain around his neck.
Snippet: In cities and towns in Central Ukraine that have not yet heard the boom of Russian artillery fire, residents spent the weekend preparing furiously for the possibly of an attack.

Title: War in Ukraine Forces Israel Into a Delicate Balancing Act
Text: On the day Russia invaded Ukraine, Israel’s prime minister, Naftali Bennett, did not mention Russia once. Mr. Bennett said he prayed for peace, called for dialogue and promised support for Ukrainian citizens. But he did not hint at Moscow’s involvement, much less condemn it — and it was left, as preplanned, to Mr. Bennett’s foreign minister, Yair Lapid, to criticize Moscow in a separate statement that day.
Snippet: Israel is a strong ally of the United States, and its leaders have a good relationship with Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine’s Jewish president. But Israel also doesn’t want to provoke Russia.

Title: Ukraine Agrees to Talks With Russia, but Fighting Still Rages
Text: As Russian forces bore down on Ukraine’s capital and officials put the toll of civilian dead at more than 350 since the invasion began, the two countries agreed Sunday to sit down for talks “without preconditions,” but hopes were not high for a peaceful resolution of the conflict.
Snippet: Putin, accusing the West of “aggressive statements,” puts nuclear forces on alert. Kyiv remains in Russian cross-hairs as Ukrainians push back.

Title: In Foreign Policy U-Turn, Germany Ups Military Spending and Arms Ukraine
Text: It took an invasion of a sovereign country nearby, threats of nuclear attack, images of civilians facing off against Russian tanks and a spate of shaming from allies for Germany to shake its decades-long faith in a military-averse foreign policy that was born of the crimes of the Third Reich.
Snippet: Germany agrees to strengthen its military in the latest foreign policy about-face amid pressure from allies and horror at Russia’s attack on Ukraine.

Title: Oil prices climb as Ukraine crisis deepens.
Text: Oil prices jumped on Monday, as President Vladimir V. Putin’s saber-rattling order to put his country’s nuclear forces on high alert overshadowed hopes for negotiations between Russia and Ukraine.
Snippet: A nuclear threat, and skepticism at potential talks.

Title: ‘Ukrainian People Don’t Give Up Hope’: U.S. Rallies Express Solidarity
Text: Bearing blue and yellow Ukrainian flags, singing patriotic songs and shouting chants against Russia’s president, thousands of protesters gathered at rallies across the country on Sunday in a show of support for Ukraine.
Snippet: At events in Washington, Chicago, Boston and other cities on Sunday, demonstrators expressed their love for the country, anger at Vladimir Putin and hope for peace.

Title: Metropolitan Opera Says It Will Cut Ties With Pro-Putin Artists
Text: The Metropolitan Opera said on Sunday that it would no longer engage with performers or other institutions that have voiced support for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, becoming the latest cultural organization to seek to distance itself from some Russian artists amid Mr. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The decision comes as arts institutions seek to distance themselves from some Russian performers amid the invasion of Ukraine.

Title: 10 Consequential Days: How Biden Navigated War, Covid and the Supreme Court
Text: Ron Klain, the White House chief of staff, gave a pep talk early on Feb. 18 at the daily gathering of the president’s most senior aides: The next 10 days, he said, will be the most consequential of the Biden presidency.
Snippet: The dizzying events of the past week have pushed to the sidelines the congressional squabbling over President Biden’s domestic agenda, and are already redefining the arc of his presidency.

Title: Putin Declares a Nuclear Alert, and Biden Seeks De-escalation
Text: When Vladimir V. Putin declared Sunday that he was putting his nuclear forces into “special combat readiness” — a heightened alert status reminiscent of some of the most dangerous moments of the Cold War — President Biden and his aides had a choice.
Snippet: When the Russian leader ordered his nuclear forces into “special combat readiness,” the U.S. could have gone on high alert. Instead, the administration tried not to inflame him.

Title: Daniil Medvedev Intrudes on the Big Four’s No. 1 Perch
Text: Daniil Medvedev was 7 years old and living with his family in Moscow when Roger Federer rose to No. 1 in the ATP rankings on Feb. 2, 2004.
Snippet: After nearly two decades of four men trading places at tennis’s top slot, Russia’s Medvedev put an end to their reign on Monday.

Title: Quotation of the Day: Armed or Not, Villagers Rush to Join Fight
Text: “The Russian leadership does not understand that it is at war not only with the armed forces of Ukraine, but with the entire Ukrainian people.”
Snippet: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 28, 2022.

Title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘After Yang’ and the State of the Union
Text: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Feb. 28-March 6. Details and times are subject to change.
Snippet: Colin Farrell, Jodie Turner-Smith and Justin H. Min star in a new sci-fi movie on Showtime. And President Biden delivers a State of the Union address.

Title: Here’s the latest news from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
Text: As Ukraine’s second largest city reeled under a barrage of Russian rockets that left dozens of people dead, officials said, a Ukrainian delegation met counterparts from Russia on Monday in Belarus for talks that held little hope for an immediate end to the fighting that has sparked a nationwide resistance in Ukraine and left Russia’s economy increasingly isolated from the world.

Title: The ruble crashes, the stock market closes and Russia’s economy staggers under sanctions.
Text: The ruble cratered, the stock market froze and the public rushed to withdraw cash on Monday as Western sanctions kicked in and Russia awoke to uncertainty and fear over the rapidly spreading repercussions of President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The hectic moves were the first signs that Western sanctions were shaking the foundations of Russia’s economy.

Title: The West’s Plan to Isolate Putin: Undermine the Ruble
Text: By targeting Russia’s central bank with sanctions, experts said, American and European leaders have taken aim at what could be one of President Vladimir V. Putin’s greatest weaknesses: the country’s currency.
Snippet: Measures announced over the weekend aimed at restricting the Russian central bank’s ability to support the ruble appear to be having an immediate impact.

Title: The Battle for Kyiv
Text: This episode contains strong language.
Snippet: Reporting from the Ukrainian capital as the once vibrant, bustling city is turned into a war zone.

Title: Markets are turbulent as sanctions start to isolate Russia’s economy.
Text: Stocks on Wall Street fell on Monday and commodity prices rose as the war in Ukraine entered its fifth day and a widening array of sanctions aimed at punishing Russia for its invasion began to bite.
Snippet: Energy prices jumped and stocks on Wall Street fell. The New York Stock Exchange halted trading in shares of Russian companies.

Title: U.S. escalates sanctions with a freeze on Russian central bank assets.
Text: The Treasury Department on Monday moved to further cut off Russia from the global economy, announcing that it would immobilize Russian central bank assets that are held in the United States and impose sanctions on the Russian Direct Investment Fund, a sovereign wealth fund that is run by a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin.
Snippet: The action is likely to fuel rapid inflation in Russia as it wages war in Ukraine.

Title: Zelensky, in a passionate speech, urges the E.U. to admit Ukraine immediately.
Text: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged the European Union on Monday to grant his country immediate accession to the bloc in response to Russia’s invasion.

Title: How Economic Warfare Is Battering Russia
Text: As the Russian military meets stiff resistance on the ground in Ukraine, the U.S. and its allies are aggressively escalating financial sanctions. The effects on the Russian economy could be devastating, and the global reverberations of the punishments, unheard-of in severity and scope for an economy of Russia’s size and interconnectedness, are destabilizing, too.
Snippet: “Completely unprecedented” financial sanctions against Russia are taking a global toll.

Title: Russia Faces Global Sports Crackdown After Invasion of Ukraine
Text: that athletes should not be punished for the actions of their governments — crumbled on Monday, when executives worldwide moved to banish Russians from competitions and deepen the country’s isolation for its invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The International Olympic Committee recommended that Russian and Belarusian athletes be barred from competitions.

Title: Toyota stops production in Japan after a cyberattack at a supplier.
Text: Toyota, the world’s largest automaker, said on Tuesday that it would restart production in Japan after a cyberattack at a major supplier had forced the company to shut down its domestic production.
Snippet: A supplier to the automaker shut down its computer network in response to a hack.

Title: Switzerland says it will freeze Russian assets, setting aside a tradition of neutrality.
Text: Switzerland, a favorite destination for Russian oligarchs and their money, announced on Monday that it would freeze Russian financial assets in the country, setting aside a deeply rooted tradition of neutrality to join the European Union and a growing number of nations seeking to penalize Russia for the invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The decision came amid mounting public anger at Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

Title: Volvo Cars halts sales to Russia, citing Ukraine sanctions and ‘potential risks.’
Text: Volvo Cars said on Monday that it would stop selling vehicles in Russia because of sanctions imposed by the United States and European Union, and because doing business there had become too risky after the invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The Swedish carmaker’s move is a sign of how businesses may decide the hazards of doing business in Russia outweigh the risks.

Title: The One Item They Had to Take When These 6 Afghans Fled
Text: If you were leaving home forever and had just a few hours to collect your thoughts and most precious belongings, items that would have to fit into a knapsack or purse, or just your pockets, what would you choose?
Snippet: More than 120,000 people were airlifted out of Afghanistan last August, most with just a few hours to gather their belongings. Here are some of the keepsakes they chose.

Title: FIFA Suspends Russia, Ejecting It From World Cup Qualifying
Text: World soccer’s global governing body suspended Russia and its teams from all competitions on Monday, ejecting the country from qualifying for the 2022 World Cup only weeks before it was to play for one of Europe’s final places in this year’s tournament in Qatar.
Snippet: The decision to bar Russian clubs and national teams came a day after FIFA was criticized for not going far enough to punish Russia for invading Ukraine.

Title: Initial talks between Russia and Ukraine yield no resolution.
Text: Initial talks between Russia and Ukraine concluded without result on Monday evening, with both delegations returning from the site of the negotiations in Belarus to their capitals for consultations.
Snippet: Russia’s delegation leader said the next meeting would take place once more along the Ukraine-Belarus border in the “coming days.”

Title: Russian Artists Speak Out Against War, but Fear Reprisals
Text: The young Russian artists Kirill Savchenkov and Alexandra Sukhareva were set to represent Russia in April at the Venice Biennale, the art-world jamboree that can turn little-known artists into global stars.
Snippet: Two Russian artists have pulled out of the Venice Biennale and thousands are signing antiwar petitions.

Title: Treasured Paintings Burned in Russian Invasion, Ukrainian Officials Say
Text: Roughly 25 paintings by the celebrated Ukrainian artist Maria Primachenko were burned as a result of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the country’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement posted to social media on Monday.
Snippet: Roughly 25 works by the painter Maria Primachenko were destroyed at a museum in Ivankiv, Ukraine’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs said.

Title: European Sanctions Could Strand Leased Planes in Russia
Text: Western sanctions meant to punish President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for invading Ukraine may have also dealt a big blow to European companies that leased commercial aircraft to Russian airlines.
Snippet: European companies that have leased hundreds of planes to Russian airlines must now find a way to fly them out.

Title: After a Fumbled Start, Russian Forces Hit Harder in Ukraine
Text: When Russia launched its invasion of Ukraine with nearly 200,000 troops, many observers — and seemingly President Vladimir V. Putin himself — expected that the force would roll right in and the fighting would be over quickly. Instead, after five days of war, what appears to be unfolding is a Russian miscalculation about tactics and about how hard the Ukrainians would fight.
Snippet: After days of miscalculation about Ukraine’s resolve to fight, Russian forces are turning toward an old pattern of opening fire on cities and mounting sieges.

Title: Uber distances itself from Yandex.Taxi, the Russian ride-sharing service.
Text: Uber said Monday that it was trying to “accelerate” its divestment from the Russian internet company Yandex, which operates a ride-hailing service in Russia, in light of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: Uber said it would try to ‘accelerate’ the planned sale of its shares in the Russian service.

Title: Pakistan Will Cut Energy Prices to Offset Rising Costs After Invasion
Text: Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan announced Monday that he was slashing fuel and electricity prices to help offset rising global energy prices because of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: Critics said the move by Prime Minister Imran Khan was aimed at stemming increasing criticism of his handling of the economy and would provide only temporary relief.

Title: As Sanctions Batter Economy, Russians Face the Anxieties of a Costly War
Text: For two decades under President Vladimir V. Putin, Russians reaped the bounties of capitalism and globalization: cheap flights, affordable mortgages, a plethora of imported gadgets and cars.
Snippet: The ruble plunged, the stock market was shuttered and foreign investors shed holdings in Russian companies, deepening the concern among citizens who had become accustomed to the perks of globalization.

Title: Shell Quits Russia, Joining BP as Oil Giants Object to Attack on Ukraine
Text: Shell, Europe’s largest oil company, said on Monday that it would exit its joint ventures with Gazprom, the Russian natural gas giant. It is joining BP, which said on Sunday that it would sell its nearly 20 percent stake in Rosneft, the Russian state-controlled oil company.
Snippet: Shell said it would exit its investments in Russia, a day after BP said it would do the same. Now companies like TotalEnergies and Exxon will face questions.

Title: E.U. sees adequate winter energy, but seeks longer-term independence.
Text: Europe’s energy supply is sufficient to get through the winter, but the Russian invasion of Ukraine has exposed vulnerabilities that need to be addressed, the European Union's energy commissioner said Monday.
Snippet: The organization’s energy commissioner said the Russian invasion of Ukraine had exposed vulnerabilities in European energy supplies.

Title: Invasion Brings Russia Global Repudiation With Cold War Echoes
Text: In Switzerland, the Lucerne music festival canceled two symphony concerts featuring a Russian maestro. In Australia, the national swim team said it would boycott a world championship meet in Russia. At the Magic Mountain Ski Area in Vermont, a bartender poured bottles of Stolichnaya vodka down the drain.
Snippet: From culture to commerce, sports to travel, the world is shunning Russia in myriad ways to protest President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.

Title: Mission to Mars with Russia this year is now ‘very unlikely,’ European Space Agency says.
Text: The planned launch in 2022 of a European space mission with Russia to land a robot on Mars is now “very unlikely,” the European Space Agency said on Monday.
Snippet: The ExoMars mission, postponed in 2020 because of the pandemic and technical issues, may miss its window to launch this year because of sanctions imposed against Russia over the invasion of Ukraine.

Title: Ukraine War Tests the Power of Tech Giants
Text: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has become a defining geopolitical moment for some of the world’s biggest tech companies, as their platforms have turned into major battlefields for a parallel information war and their data and services have become vital links in the conflict.
Snippet: Google, Meta, Twitter, Telegram and others are levers in the conflict, caught between demands from Ukraine, Russia, the European Union and the U.S.

Title: New York City’s Next Chapter
Text: Mayor Eric Adams said today that he was preparing to eliminate school mask mandates and indoor proof-of-vaccine requirements by March 7 if new coronavirus cases in the city remain low.
Snippet: The new mayor is rolling back virus mandates.

Title: In Miami, a Ukrainian Art Show Becomes Unintentionally Timely
Text: and the run of their pop-up exhibition there — was extended.
Snippet: A Kyiv couple stage a socially charged exhibition in South Florida as their Voloshyn Gallery back home becomes a bomb shelter.

Title: Biden administration faces pressure to let Ukrainians stay in the U.S.
Text: The Biden administration is facing mounting pressure from lawmakers and advocates to allow thousands of Ukrainians who are temporarily working or studying in the United States to remain, rather than force them to return to their war-torn country.
Snippet: Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, has called on the administration to offer Temporary Protected Status to Ukrainians who are on short-term visas or have no documentation.

Title: What Questions Do You Have About Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine?
Text: Times journalists covering the war in Ukraine are witnessing events on the ground as they unfold, reporting from battlefields, hospitals, improvised bomb shelters and contested cities. We also have journalists covering the conflict from numerous world capitals.
Snippet: New York Times reporters will answer reader questions about the war, the world’s response and the effects of sanctions against Russia.

Title: A Barrage of Rockets Hits Kharkiv
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Snippet: Russian forces escalate their attacks.

Title: Russian Rocket Barrage Kills Civilians as First Talks Show No Progress
Text: The first talks between Ukraine and Russia aimed at halting the Russian invasion were eclipsed Monday by a deadly Russian rocket assault on Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city, that raised new alarms about how far the Kremlin was willing to go to subjugate its smaller neighbor.
Snippet: The deadly rocket assault on a residential area of Ukraine’s second-largest city signaled an escalation of Russian tactics, and overshadowed efforts at diplomacy.

Title: Democratic Governors Look to Biden for a Political Reset
Text: Democratic governors and their allies are expressing deep anxiety about the political conditions facing their party as President Biden’s approval rating slumps in a year when three dozen governorships are on the line, including in some of the nation’s most important battleground states.
Snippet: At a weekend fund-raising retreat, a group of governors worried about voters’ frustrations with Democrats. They hoped President Biden’s State of the Union speech would be a pivot point.

Title: What We’re Watching in Tuesday’s Texas Primary Election
Text: Follow our live updates on the Texas primary election and election results.
Snippet: The first election night of the 2022 midterms has some famous names and crowded primary races. Here’s a rundown.

Title: In State of the Union, Biden Will Focus on Economy and Global Response to Russia
Text: President Biden will use his first State of the Union address on Tuesday to claim credit for a robust economy and a unified global response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, even as he acknowledges the pain of inflation and the struggle between “democracy and autocracy” around the world, administration officials said on Monday.
Snippet: The speech was originally going to center primarily on the president’s domestic agenda. But the war in Europe has forced the White House to change gears.

Title: G.O.P. Leaders Condemn Lawmakers’ Appearance at White Nationalist Conference
Text: Republican congressional leaders on Monday broke their silence about the participation of two House Republicans at a far-right conference with ties to white supremacy, denouncing the actions of Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia and Representative Paul Gosar of Arizona.
Snippet: The participation of Representatives Marjorie Taylor Greene and Paul Gosar at a far-right event renewed calls for Republican leaders to root out extremism in their party.

Title: A few members of the Russian Parliament speak out against the war.
Text: Three members of Russia’s rubber-stamp Parliament have criticized their country’s war in Ukraine, a rare episode of dissent from within the Russian establishment.
Snippet: In a rare show of dissent, three deputies of the State Duma have expressed regret about the attack.

Title: Republicans Block Abortion Rights Measure in Senate
Text: Republicans on Monday blocked the Senate from taking up sweeping abortion rights legislation as Democrats sought to put lawmakers on the record on the issue in advance of the midterm elections and a coming Supreme Court ruling on access to abortion.
Snippet: With a Supreme Court ruling looming, both parties expect the issue to resonate in this year’s midterm elections.

Title: The U.S. expels 12 Russian diplomats for spying as Ukraine dominates action at the U.N.
Text: With Russia’s invasion of Ukraine the center of attention at the United Nations, the United States said Monday that it would expel 12 Russian diplomats from Moscow’s U.N. mission, saying they were actually intelligence operatives who had spied on the United States.
Snippet: The move is part of a larger effort to isolate Russia diplomatically and economically since it invaded Ukraine last week.

Title: Ukraine Gets $22 Million in Crypto Donations to Fight Invasion
Text: As Russia’s invasion escalated over the weekend, Ukrainian officials made an unusual request on Twitter: Send us your crypto.
Snippet: Cryptocurrency has provided a way for investors to quickly move funds to Ukrainian fighters.

Title: As Tanks Rolled Into Ukraine, So Did Malware. Then Microsoft Entered the War.
Text: Last Wednesday, a few hours before Russian tanks began rolling into Ukraine, alarms went off inside Microsoft’s Threat Intelligence Center, warning of a never-before-seen piece of “wiper” malware that appeared aimed at the country’s government ministries and financial institutions.
Snippet: After years of talks about the need for public-private partnerships to combat cyberattacks, the war in Ukraine is stress-testing the system.

Title: Disney and Warner Bros. will pause theatrical movie releases in Russia.
Text: Disney said on Monday that it was “pausing” the release of films in Russia, becoming the first Hollywood studio to weigh in publicly on the matter. Warner Bros., which had vowed to press on with the release of “The Batman,” reversed course soon after Disney’s announcement and said it, too, would enact a pause.
Snippet: Affected films include “The Batman” from Warner and “Turning Red” from Disney-Pixar.

Title: Satellite internet terminals, sent by Elon Musk, arrive in Ukraine.
Text: Ukraine’s vice prime minister said on Monday that internet terminals sent by Elon Musk, which were designed to work with satellites orbiting in space to provide online access, had arrived in the country.
Snippet: Responding to a plea by a Ukrainian official, Mr. Musk delivered an unknown number of his Starlink terminals, which offer online connection via orbiting satellites, bypassing conventional providers.

Title: Trevor Noah Reviews Putin’s Attempt at a Soviet Reunion
Text: and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
Snippet: If bringing back the Soviet Union is Putin’s goal, the “Daily Show” host joked, long lines are a good start.

Title: Within Days, Russia’s War on Ukraine Squeezes the Global Economy
Text: In the span of just a few days, the global economic outlook has darkened while troops battled in Ukraine and unexpectedly potent financial sanctions rocked Russia’s economy and threatened to further fuel worldwide inflation.
Snippet: The price of energy has already shot higher, and the conflict imperils supply chains, factors that could exacerbate inflation and suppress growth.

Title: Valery Gergiev, a Putin Ally, Fired as Chief Conductor in Munich
Text: Valery Gergiev, the star Russian maestro and prominent supporter of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, was removed Tuesday from his post as chief conductor of the Munich Philharmonic after he refused to denounce Mr. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The conductor was dismissed from the Munich Philharmonic after he refused to denounce Putin’s invasion of Ukraine. He and Anna Netrebko, the Russian diva, were also fired by the Bavarian State Opera.

Title: Seeking Truth and Justice, Chinese See Themselves in a Chained Woman
Text: The Chinese government faces a quandary: how to convince its people that what it said about a chained woman is true.
Snippet: The woman became a symbol of injustice and authorities’ incompetence in fighting human trafficking, posing a credibility challenge to an omnipotent government.

Title: N.Y. Republicans Back Rep. Lee Zeldin, a Trump Ally, for Governor
Text: Four months after Republicans scored upset victories around the country and in local races across New York, the state’s party leaders gathered at a plush hotel in a Long Island village this week, painting a bleak picture of life under Democratic rule.
Snippet: The Republican State Convention is giving party leaders a chance to test messages about crime, inflation and Democratic leadership.

Title: Watching the War in Ukraine, Taiwanese Draw Lessons in Self-Reliance
Text: Since Russia invaded Ukraine, Justin Huang, a 23-year-old recent university graduate in Taiwan, has been gripped by news of the crisis, just like many other people around the world. He has pored over reports about Ukrainians signing up for the military and scrutinized video footage of Russian missiles hitting residential buildings. He has been deeply disturbed by Russia’s brazen disregard for global norms.
Snippet: Many in Taiwan see parallels with Ukraine. “We must use this time of peace to prepare for the worst,” says a nonprofit working to promote civil defense.

Title: In Ukraine, the Men Who Must Stay and Fight
Text: This episode contains strong language.
Snippet: As hundreds of thousands of citizens flee the Russian advance, the country’s government has ordered men ages 18 to 60 to remain.

Title: Geopolitical Risk Returns for Global Markets
Text: As severe sanctions against Russia take shape, economists, executives and investors around the world are trying to gauge the effects. Europe and its allies will wage “total economic and financial war,” Bruno Le Maire, France’s economy minister, said today. “We are going to cause the Russian economy to collapse.”
Snippet: and a new Cold War.

Title: Countries rush to release emergency reserves as oil prices soar.
Text: As oil prices soared in the sharpest one-day jump since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine last week, more than two dozen countries agreed on Tuesday to release 60 million barrels of oil from their emergency reserves, aiming to send a “strong message” that there will be “no shortfall as a result of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.”
Snippet: The announcement was aimed to assure markets that there would be “no shortfall” as a result of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but oil prices kept rising, closing above $100 a barrel.

Title: As World Rebukes Russia, India Tries to Stay Above the Fray
Text: When India abstained from a United Nations vote and the chorus of Western condemnation against the Ukraine invasion, it appeared to be taking sides: offering tacit support for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
Snippet: A nation isolated in a hostile region increasingly dominated by China, its challenge is to engage the West while not abandoning ties with an old ally.

Title: Joining Sanctions on Russia, Italy Risks More Than Most
Text: As Italian skiers kicked the snow off their boots and warmed up in the lobby of his lodge in the Apennine Mountains, the hotel owner worried what European sanctions on Russia would do to his already astronomically high heating bills.
Snippet: at an outsize cost.

Title: Diplomats walk out of Lavrov’s speech at the U.N. in Geneva.
Text: About 100 diplomats, many from Western countries, walked out of a speech by Russia’s foreign minister at the United Nations Human Rights Council on Tuesday in protest over his country’s invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: Sergey Lavrov accused Ukraine of seeking to acquire nuclear weapons, an unsubstantiated claim that Moscow has used as justification for its invasion.

Title: TotalEnergies, a French oil company, will limit its investment in Russia.
Text: TotalEnergies, the French oil company with large natural gas investments in Russia, said on Tuesday that it would no longer provide capital for new projects in the country in response to the invasion of Ukraine.
