Snippet: Facing disputes over how to cover the cost of the pandemic response effort, Democrats dropped it rather than jeopardize legislation that includes aid for Ukraine and other top priorities.

Title: Help Wanted
Text: UPDATE: I have added a comment about 47D in the Tricky Clues section. It is indeed tricky, but there is really only one answer.
Snippet: John Westwig, a software engineer with New York Times Games, encourages solvers to change careers.

Title: Here are the latest developments in the war on Ukraine.
Text: The top diplomats from Ukraine and Russia failed to reach an agreement on Thursday to calm the fighting in Ukraine or even to ease the worsening humanitarian crisis, dashing hopes for a swift end to a two-week-old conflict that has killed hundreds and displaced millions.

Title: Stephen Colbert: Major Food Brands Are ‘Russian’ for the Exits
Text: and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
Snippet: “Yesterday, Coca-Cola and Pepsi announced that they will suspend business in Russia. Your move, Shasta!” Colbert said.

Title: Russia’s War Is Raising Gas Prices and Roiling Financial Markets
Text: It’s getting to the point where you’re better off filling up your gas tank in the morning because the price will be higher by the time you drive home.
Snippet: The price of gasoline is climbing and the markets are adjusting to gloomier prospects as the war in Ukraine grinds on.

Title: Surging U.S. Inflation Raises Stakes as War Pushes Up Prices
Text: along with many developed economies — as the conflict promises to drive costs higher.
Snippet: Consumer Price Index inflation has been boosted by gas prices but also by increases across a wide variety of products and services.

Title: An Urgent Mission for Literary Translators: Bringing Ukrainian Voices to the West
Text: As Russian forces breached the border with Ukraine late last month, Kate Tsurkan issued an urgent call for help on social media.
Snippet: a project as political as it is cultural, authors and translators say.

Title: Thinking of Going to Southeast Asia? Here’s What to Expect.
Text: Their flights were more expensive and took longer, their favorite restaurant was shuttered and they had to take coronavirus tests on the first and fifth days of their trip. But the biggest hassle for Brian Lamberty and Paola Laird, retirees from London, in their long-awaited return to Phuket Island in Thailand was the paperwork.
Snippet: at least for the short-term.

Title: A Waiter. A Cab Driver. An Engineer: The U.S. Fighters Bound for Ukraine
Text: Last week, Yuriy Blazhkevych, a taxi driver who lives in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, stood in his garage, scrolling through images of Ukraine on his phone that showed buildings with blasted-out windows, tanks rolling over cars and people fleeing for their lives.
Snippet: Ukrainians across the U.S., many of whom have never fired a weapon, have put their lives on hold to defend their homeland.

Title: Australia Asks: How Far Is Too Far in Making China a Campaign Weapon?
Text: A group of middle-aged Chinese Australians logged onto Zoom to step, kick and punch through their regular exercise class one day late last month. Then they lingered online to despair at the government’s attempt to turn China into a campaign weapon.
Snippet: Australia’s conservative government has claimed, without evidence, that the political opposition would cozy up to Beijing. To many, it has crossed a red line.

Title: Britain Freezes Assets of Roman Abramovich, Creating Crisis at Chelsea
Text: For Chelsea F.C.’s players and coaches, the first snippets of information arrived in the text messages and news alerts that pinged their cellphones as they made their way to a private terminal at London’s Gatwick Airport on Thursday morning.
Snippet: The Premier League club will be allowed to continue operating, but it cannot sell tickets or merchandise and is blocked from buying or selling players.

Title: Europe prepares for reverberations of war: a slower economy and faster inflation.
Text: Just as Europe was emerging from a downturn caused by the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, Russia’s war against Ukraine has sent energy prices soaring and shaken forecasts of the region’s economic health.
Snippet: The European Central Bank is moving ahead with plans to end its bond-buying programs amid rising inflation.

Title: ‘Free Ukraine Street’: Russian Embassies Get Pointed New Addresses
Text: The unassuming intersection in front of the Russian Embassy in central Oslo didn’t really have a name until Tuesday, when its local council bestowed on it a particularly pointed one: “Ukrainas Plass,” or Ukraine’s Square.
Snippet: Officials in many European cities are giving streets, squares and intersections in front of Russian missions names with pro-Ukraine themes.

Title: Inside Ukraine’s Embattled Cities
Text: It has been two weeks since the beginning of the war in Ukraine and Russia’s high-tech army of nearly 200,000 soldiers has not taken control of any major cities, except the southern port of Kherson. The Ukrainian resistance has been too strong.
Snippet: Dispatches on two cities in Ukraine’s south that are surrounded by Russian forces and under attack.

Title: Here are the latest developments in Ukraine.
Text: The top diplomats of Russia and Ukraine failed to make even a hint of progress Thursday in their first face-to-face meeting since the Russian invasion began, while Russian bombardments spread more carnage in a two-week-old war that Ukraine estimated had already caused $100 billion in damage.The fighting has deepened suffering in the country, especially in besieged cities like Mariupol in the southeast and Chernihiv in the north. Russians forces also were reported to have gained ground in some smaller cities near Kyiv, the capital.

Title: The Hunt for Oligarchs’ Money
Text: Britain imposed severe new sanctions today on seven Russian billionaires it said have ties to Vladimir Putin, including the aluminum magnate Oleg Deripaska and Roman Abramovich, the owner of the soccer club Chelsea F.C. It’s part of a widening crackdown on Russian oligarchs, which also includes greater scrutiny of the investment, law and lobbying firms that help these billionaires manage their wealth.
Snippet: More Russian billionaires are hit with sanctions, and their advisers face greater scrutiny.

Title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Extreme Temperatures
Text: Special Announcement for March: The American Statistical Association is now running its annual This is Statistics Spring Contest. Students can showcase their statistical literacy and journalism skills by submitting their clear and compelling headlines for New York Times graphs in March’s four weekly challenges. To learn more, visit This Is Statistics.
Snippet: How have extreme temperatures in the United States changed over time?

Title: Coached by an Enigmatic Russian, China Emerges as a Sled Hockey Power
Text: All the Russian athletes were kicked out of the Paralympics before the Games began last week, but there is still a Russian here, and he has a chance to win a medal.
Snippet: Only five years after creating the program, China’s team has reached the semifinal round at the Beijing Paralympics. Players credit their little-known coach as their “spiritual support.”

Title: 4 Falsehoods Russians Are Told About the War
Text: Russia’s international disinformation campaign seemed to flounder in the early days of the invasion, as narratives about Ukrainian bravery dominated the internet. But in Russia, the country’s propaganda machine was busy churning out a deluge of misinformation aimed at its own citizens.
Snippet: Russia’s disinformation machine is working in overdrive inside its own borders.

Title: Russian forces are laying siege to the northern Ukraine city of Chernihiv, the mayor says.
Text: Russian forces have encircled and are laying siege to the ancient city of Chernihiv in northern Ukraine, the mayor said, adding that critical infrastructure for its 300,000 residents was rapidly failing as it came under repeated bombardment.
Snippet: Ukrainian forces are battling to keep some roads open, as Russia tightens its cordon around the battered city. “We are surrounded,” the mayor said.

Title: Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase are winding down in Russia.
Text: Goldman Sachs on Thursday became the first big American bank to say it would exit Russia after Western governments imposed a raft of sanctions intended to cripple its economy. Hours later, JPMorgan Chase, the biggest bank in the United States, said it was winding down there, too.
Snippet: At the end of 2021, Goldman Sachs had more than $700 million in exposure to Russia, just a sliver of its total operations. Russia was not among JPMorgan’s top 20 markets.

Title: Major Music Companies Pause Business in Russia
Text: the three major record conglomerates, and the touring giant Live Nation — are cutting ties with Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, and artists like Green Day and AJR have canceled concerts in Russia.
Snippet: The three major record conglomerates and the touring giant Live Nation are suspending operations over Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, while individual artists have canceled tour dates.

Title: Harris, in Poland, Seeks to Present United Front Against Russia
Text: Vice President Kamala Harris called Thursday for an investigation into whether Russia had committed war crimes in Ukraine during a visit to a key NATO ally that has taken in more than one million refugees from the invasion.
Snippet: Vice President Kamala Harris visited Warsaw a day after U.S. officials said they were blindsided by Poland’s offer to provide jet fighters to Ukraine. Washington rejected it, fearing it could escalate the conflict.

Title: In a reversal, Uniqlo’s owner pulls out of Russia.
Text: In an about-face, Fast Retailing, the clothing giant that owns Uniqlo, said on Thursday that the brand would stop operating in Russia. Just days earlier, the company’s founder had said it would continue to do business in the country, drawing backlash.
Snippet: Tadashi Yanai, the founder of Fast Retailing, had faced backlash for his decision to stay in Russia.

Title: Remembering Avicii by Stepping Into His Bewildering World
Text: Visitors filed one by one into a dark, 6 foot by 12 foot room at the Space exhibition center here last Friday, where they were greeted by a mix of ringing and muddled noises: camera clicks, audience cheers, plane engine roars. Strobe lights bounced off a ceiling-high screen showing the interiors of cars, paparazzi flashes and the reaching arms of a festival crowd in quick succession. Jagged mirrors in the ceiling reflected the chaos below.
Snippet: The Avicii Experience offers a taste of the pressures that led up to the D.J.’s death. It’s the latest immersive exhibition trying to find the line between emotional engagement and entertainment.

Title: Microsoft’s Pursuit of Climate Goals Runs Into Headwinds
Text: Microsoft has an ambitious plan to cut its carbon emissions. But on Thursday, the company reported a big increase in the greenhouse gases emanating from its operations and its products, a reminder of the challenges that companies face as they try to clean up their businesses.
Snippet: The company aims to be “carbon negative” by the end of the decade, but its emissions rose sharply in the most recent year measured.

Title: Iraqi minister says high oil prices, if they last, could speed the shift to E.V.s.
Text: Even with boycotts upending supplies from Russia, major oil-producing countries are likely to hold the line on output for now, keeping prices high and reaping the benefits. But that course could prove detrimental in the long run.
Snippet: Whatever the short-term benefits for producers, the market upheaval could accelerate the transition away from oil, he says.

Title: As War Rages, a Struggle to Balance Energy Crunch and Climate Crisis
Text: As the world reels from spikes in oil and gas prices, the fallout from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has laid bare a dilemma: Nations remain extraordinarily dependent on fossil fuels and are struggling to shore up supplies precisely at a moment when scientists say the world must slash its use of oil, gas and coal to avert irrevocable damage to the planet.
Snippet: Rising oil prices and increased demand for expanded production come at a time when scientists say nations must sharply cut the use of fossil fuels.

Title: An Exiled Theater With a Warning for Europe
Text: When the players of the Belarus Free Theater began working on “Dogs of Europe” three years ago, they thought it was a play about a dystopia.
Snippet: The Belarus Free Theater’s members fled repression at home. The company’s latest show imagines a nightmare future of authoritarian Russian rule.

Title: Stellantis stops car shipments to and from Russia.
Text: Stellantis, the maker of Jeep, Fiat and Peugeot vehicles, has suspended exports of cars from Russia and imports of vehicles into the country, the company said Thursday.
Snippet: The automaker has been making delivery vans in Russia, but its chief has said production is likely to halt because of a lack of parts.

Title: The war in Ukraine is likely to slow global growth, the I.M.F. warns.
Text: The war in Ukraine and the associated sanctions that countries around the world have imposed on Russia are likely to cause a downgrade of the International Monetary Fund’s global economic growth forecast, Kristalina Georgieva, the I.M.F.’s managing director, said on Thursday.
Snippet: The economic fallout from Russia’s invasion will depend on the outcome of the war and the duration of the sanctions.

Title: U.S. Says North Korea Is Testing a New Intercontinental Missile
Text: Follow the latest news on North Korea’s ICBM launch.
Snippet: The missile, first displayed in 2020, was tested twice in recent days. While it is unclear whether it can reach the U.S., it poses a new military challenge to President Biden in the midst of the Ukraine war.

Title: What Students Are Saying About Ignoring Text Messages, Sharing Their Lives Online and a “Melting Man”
Text: This week on The Learning Network, one of our writing prompts asked teenagers if it is acceptable to ignore texts and other forms of online communication. We also wanted to know how much of their personal lives they share online. And, as one of our Picture Prompts, we invited them to interpret an image of a liquefying figure.
Snippet: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.

Title: Film Club: ‘‘I Must Save My Mom’: The Women Returning to Ukraine’
Text: The Russian invasion has upended the lives of 44 million Ukrainians. More than two million Ukrainians have fled to neighboring countries, according to the United Nations. A million more have been internally displaced. Aid groups have described it as one of the biggest humanitarian crises in recent memory.
Snippet: How has the Russian invasion of Ukraine affected ordinary citizens?

Title: ‘You Just Have to Open the Door and Help People’: Poland’s Tourism Industry Aids Refugees
Text: Tourism in Poland’s historic city of Lublin was in a deep off-season lull last month when Russia invaded neighboring Ukraine, sending tens of thousands of people fleeing across the country’s eastern border, about 60 miles away.
Snippet: As Ukrainians flood into Poland, the travel industry has become part of an effort to supply transportation, accommodations and more to people fleeing the Russian invasion.

Title: Two Weeks of War
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Snippet: Russia is slowly making gains but the destruction is growing.

Title: In Democratic Bastion, Liberal Rhetoric Is Out. ‘Affordability’ Is In.
Text: Gas prices are soaring. The war in Ukraine has rattled the stock market. And, months ahead of midterm elections, voters in key suburban swing districts in New Jersey are restive, contributing to increased dissatisfaction with the state’s Democratic leader, Gov. Philip D. Murphy.
Snippet: In the first budget address of his second term, Gov. Philip Murphy responded to New Jersey voters’ discontent at a time of surging gas costs and high taxes.

Title: Facing economic calamity, Putin talks of nationalizing Western businesses.
Text: Besieged by an onslaught of sanctions that have largely undone 30 years of economic integration with the West in the space of two weeks, President Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday opened the door to nationalizing the assets of Western companies pulling out of Russia and exhorted senior officials to “act decisively” to preserve jobs.
Snippet: With the ruble collapsing, the economy contracting and people abandoning the country, Russia’s leader talks of a Western plot to destroy the country.

Title: Why Senate Republicans Are Feuding Over Their Midterm Message
Text: Republican insiders have long worried that they could blow a golden opportunity to retake the Senate this year. And while most are confident that a red wave will still wash enough of their candidates ashore in November to win a majority, some doubt occasionally creeps in.
Snippet: Senator Rick Scott has an 11-point plan to “rescue America.” Senator Mitch McConnell would rather he not.

Title: Biden Urges Americans to Blame Rising Prices on Putin. Many Do, for Now.
Text: The price of gasoline has risen every day since Russia invaded Ukraine. Record-high inflation in the United States is causing sticker shock. And now, President Biden is blaming the pinch on Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian president.
Snippet: News that inflation has hit a 40-year high is another blunt reminder of just how much the president is asking voters to sacrifice in an election year.

Title: Russia Batters and Encircles Ukrainian Cities, as Diplomacy Falters
Text: The top diplomats of Russia and Ukraine failed to make even a hint of progress Thursday in their first face-to-face meeting since the Russian invasion began, while Russian bombardments spread more carnage in a two-week-old war that Ukraine estimated had already inflicted $100 billion in damage.
Snippet: The first meeting during the war of the two countries’ foreign ministers yielded no cease-fire. The Russian side signaled that its invasion would not stop until Ukraine surrendered.

Title: U.S. Fights Bioweapons Disinformation Pushed by Russia and China
Text: One of Russia’s most incendiary disinformation campaigns ramped up days ago, when its defense and foreign ministries issued statements falsely claiming that the Pentagon was financing biological weapons labs in Ukraine.
Snippet: The Biden administration says the two countries’ promotion of anti-U.S. conspiracy theories might be cover for lethal Russian military operations.

Title: What’s the Best Way to Cope in an Anxious World? Do Something.
Text: Many people are experiencing a jumbled mix of emotions right now. There’s sadness and a feeling of helplessness about the brutal attacks against the people of Ukraine, as well as anxiety and fear about the threat of nuclear weapons. Add to that exhaustion after two years of worrying about a deadly virus. And for some, there’s also guilt, for the indulgence of talking about anxious feelings at a time when others are suffering far more.
Snippet: One way to loosen the grip of anxiety is to focus on helping someone else.

Title: Congress Clears $1.5 Trillion Spending Bill, Including Ukraine Aid
Text: Congress cleared the first major federal spending legislation of President Biden’s administration on Thursday, approving a $1.5 trillion measure with substantial increases for domestic and national security programs, along with $13.6 billion in emergency aid for Ukraine as it battles Russia’s invasion.
Snippet: President Biden is expected to sign the measure, the first major spending bill since he took office.

Title: Climate Change’s Threat to the Glorious Redwood, Both Here and Afar
Text: Framed by native eucalyptuses and ferns in a shady glade near Victoria’s famed Great Ocean Road, a group of Californian giants rises into the Australian sun.
Snippet: In 1936, foresters planted California redwoods in Victoria. How long will they grow in peace?

Title: Russia-Ukraine talks come to nothing as bombardment of cities continues.
Text: Russian and Ukrainian foreign ministers failed to make any progress Thursday in their first face-to-face meeting since the Russian invasion began two weeks ago, while Russian bombardments spread more carnage, having caused an estimated $100 billion in damage so far.
Snippet: Thousands of people fled through ‘humanitarian corridors’ as Vice President Kamala Harris said that Russia should be investigated for war crimes. U.S. officials warned that Putin’s threat to seize businesses would lead to more ‘economic pain.’

Title: Congress approves $13.6 billion in emergency aid for Ukraine.
Text: Congress passed a major spending bill on Thursday that includes $13.6 billion in emergency aid for Ukraine as it battles Russia’s invasion.

Title: Biden will call for suspending normal trade relations with Russia.
Text: President Biden will announce on Friday that the United States will join the G7 and the European Union in calling for the suspension of normal trade relations with Russia, according to a person familiar with the announcement, a change that would raise tariffs for many Russian products.
Snippet: The move, expected to be joined by the G7 and the European Union, would result in higher tariffs on Russian products being sent to the United States.

Title: Late Night Casts Doubt on the Russian-Ukrainian Peace Talks
Text: and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
Snippet: Trevor Noah warned viewers not to get their hopes up: “Not only did Russia not agree to end the war; it wouldn’t even admit that it started a war.”

Title: Chinese stocks listed in U.S. tumble over fears of potential delisting
Text: Chinese stocks listed in the United States saw their worst day of trading since 2008 on Thursday, driven by fears of potential delisting in U.S. markets under a law that requires the companies to hand over audit information to American regulators. Reverberations were felt in Chinese markets on Friday, where many shares had sharp declines.
Snippet: The S.E.C. specified five U.S.-traded Chinese companies required to turn over audit information to regulators. The news reverberated in Asian markets Friday.

Title: Russian Sanctions Snarl Shipping Even as Pandemic Pressure Eases
Text: Russian ships banned from docking in Britain. Cargo containers piling up at European ports. Airfreight rerouted around Ukraine and Russia.
Snippet: Global disruptions from the war on Ukraine and uncertainty due to the sanctions have led to pileups at ports and could delay cargo longer.

Title: China Has Tools to Help Russia’s Economy. None Are Big Enough to Save It.
Text: When the United States and its allies declared a financial war on Russia after its invasion of Ukraine, the world turned to see what China would do.
Snippet: Any financial lifeline that Beijing can offer Moscow involves taking on risk and won’t have the power to reverse the damage of sanctions imposed by the United States and its allies.

Title: Is This Finally the Year of the Electric Car?
Text: Last summer, Hank Gutman, serving as New York’s transportation commissioner, encountered a couple in the Bronx who were charging their Nissan Leaf, running an extension cord out of their apartment window and across the sidewalk. Mr. Gutman was already very concerned about current infrastructure supporting electric vehicles in the city, but this moment had a crystallizing effect. To convert New York City into an electric-car mecca was a very different prospect from turning the tides in suburban New Jersey.
Snippet: New York lags far behind most cities in electric-vehicle infrastructure, but changes are coming.

Title: As the Omicron Wave Subsides, Travel Insurance Claims Crawl
Text: twice for weather delays and once because her travel companion tested positive for the virus. Two are still under review, and the first took nearly two months from claim to reimbursement.
Snippet: Getting a decision on a claim has become the latest problem consumers are experiencing with travel insurance. Here’s how to avoid delays.

Title: Bracing for Losses, Democrats Look to Biden for a Reset
Text: House Democrats planned a retreat here this week hoping for a reset after a difficult period during which President Biden has been buffeted by rising gas prices, soaring inflation and sagging approval ratings.
Snippet: At a party retreat in Philadelphia, House Democrats hoped the president would offer a winning strategy heading into a challenging midterm election season.

Title: Even Before War, Thousands Were Fleeing Russia for the U.S.
Text: Last fall, Iuliia Shuvalova and Sergei Ignatev, a young Russian couple, sold their car and took out a loan to pay for a holiday at a beach resort on Mexico’s Riviera Maya.
Snippet: Political activists, L.G.B.T.Q. people and Jehovah’s Witnesses in Russia are crossing the southern border from Mexico in greater numbers. More Ukrainians are also heading to the United States.

Title: Putin’s Endgame: A Conversation With Fiona Hill
Text: Ending the war in Ukraine very much depends on how and when President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia allows it to end.
Snippet: A discussion on the Russian president’s motivations, the West’s response and how the conflict could play out.

Title: Russian Demands to Ease Sanctions Halt Nuclear Talks With Iran
Text: Russian demands that a revised nuclear agreement with Iran shield it from sanctions imposed because of its war in Ukraine halted efforts to revive the deal on Friday, just as negotiators said they had all but finalized the agreement.
Snippet: Russia has injected its fight against sanctions into talks aimed at restoring a nuclear agreement with Iran. The Russian demands have delayed the prospect of a deal.

Title: Wall Street Joins the Unbanking of Russia
Text: Goldman Sachs yesterday became the first major global bank to say it was quitting Russia, followed shortly after by JPMorgan Chase. The Wall Street giants join a growing list of multinational companies that have pledged to stop doing business in Russia. “None of us can fail to see this for what it is: the invasion of a sovereign state,” David Solomon, Goldman’s C.E.O., wrote in a memo to employees.
Snippet: Goldman and JPMorgan are the first big U.S. lenders to pull out of the country.

Title: Europe’s Trains Take Fighters to Ukraine, and Bring Back Refugees
Text: On the 12th night of the war, on a platform at Prague’s central train station, Vitali Slobodianiuk and Volodymyr Kotsyuba met for the first time.
Snippet: Built up over 150 years of conflicts that defined modern-day Europe, railways have played a central role in the continent’s peacetime integration. Now they’re back on a war footing.

Title: The Mafia’s View of ‘The Godfather’ and the W.N.B.A. Star Detained in Russia: The Week in Narrated Articles
Text: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
Snippet: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

Title: Roman Abramovich and the End of Soccer’s Oligarch Era
Text: There were, over the years, three stories that explained how Roman Abramovich washed ashore at Chelsea. Each one, now, serves as a kind of time capsule, a carbon-dated relic from a specific period, capturing in amber each stage of our understanding of what, precisely, soccer has become.
Snippet: Stripped of its Russian benefactor, Chelsea now faces a reckoning. Soccer’s will come next.

Title: U.S. and Allies Move to Further Isolate Russia From Global Economy
Text: President Biden and other Western leaders moved on Friday to further isolate Russia from the global trading system, saying they would strip the country of normal trade relations and take other steps to sever its links to the world economy in response to President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The Biden administration said it would join Europe and other allies in stripping Russia of permanent normal trade relations, another step to inflict economic damage on the country over its invasion of Ukraine.

Title: Bitcoin Was Made for This Moment. So Why Isn’t It Booming?
Text: For years, Bitcoin buffs who were questioned by skeptics about the value of the cryptocurrency would respond by saying: just wait.
Snippet: Long hailed by its advocates as a safe hedge during uncertain times, Bitcoin’s value has fallen steadily in recent weeks.

Title: ‘This Is Everyone’s Culture’: Ukraine’s Architectural Treasures Face Destruction
Text: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine brought searing images of human tragedy to witnesses around the world: thousands of civilians killed and injured; broken families, as mothers and children leave in search of refuge while fathers and other men stay behind to defend their country; and millions of refugees having already fled to neighboring countries, after just two weeks of war.
Snippet: The country’s vast array of historic buildings, artworks and public squares are an integral part of Ukraine’s cultural identity. Amid the violence of war, many are being reduced to rubble.

Title: Theory About U.S.-Funded Bioweapons Labs in Ukraine Is Unfounded
Text: Prominent social media users and conservative voices have amplified a baseless theory promoted by Russian state media accusing the United States of funding biological weapons laboratories in Ukraine.
Snippet: Prominent conservative voices have mischaracterized remarks from American officials to amplify baseless claims promoted by Russian state media.

Title: Over Ukraine, Lumbering Turkish-Made Drones Are an Ominous Sign for Russia
Text: Ukraine’s most sophisticated attack drone is about as stealthy as a crop duster: slow, low-flying and completely defenseless. So when the Russian invasion began, many experts expected the few drones that the Ukrainian forces managed to get off the ground would be shot down in hours.
Snippet: The Bayraktar TB2 has become a rallying symbol for Ukrainians, who are singing songs about them and posting videos of their success.

Title: Roman Abramovich’s Fortune Bought Him Good Will, and Made Him a Target
Text: As Russian troops massed near the border with Ukraine last month, the American ambassador to Israel received an appeal on behalf of Roman Abramovich, the most visible of the billionaires linked to President Vladimir V. Putin.
Snippet: The oligarch’s billions and his Kremlin connections secured him favors and elite status in the West. Now they’ve landed him on a sanctions list.

Title: How We Verify Our Reporting on the Ukraine War
Text: The Times has deployed dozens of reporters, photographers, videographers, audio journalists, writers and others to Ukraine and the countries bordering it to deliver real-time, independent, in-depth coverage of the conflict and its reverberations across the region. Times journalists are witnessing events on the ground as they unfold, reporting from battlefields, hospitals, improvised bomb shelters and contested cities.
Snippet: To cut through the fog of propaganda and misinformation on both sides, The Times has deployed dozens of  journalists  to Ukraine to witness events as they unfold.

Title: Harris Tells Americans They Will Have to Pay More for Gas to Punish Russia
Text: Vice President Kamala Harris said Friday that Americans will have to bear the burden of higher gas prices, but insisted that it was a cost worth paying to punish Russia for waging war on Ukraine.
Snippet: Vice President Kamala Harris, visiting NATO ally Romania, insisted that the higher costs of energy associated with sanctions imposed on Moscow over its war on Ukraine would be worth the pain.

Title: At Indian Wells, Ukrainian Tennis Stars Take Their Fight to the Court
Text: The Ukrainian teenager Marta Kostyuk and the Belgian veteran Maryna Zanevska played for more than three hours in the sun and a swirling wind.
Snippet: Playing through fear of the war, Marta Kostyuk said that she must show “what it’s like having a Ukrainian heart” and that it “hurts” to see Russian players at the tournament.

Title: The global supply chain’s pandemic recovery is another casualty of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
Text: Just as the global economy was on track to emerge from the coronavirus pandemic, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and global sanctions against Moscow are rippling through logistics and supply chains, creating bottlenecks in the transport of goods and commodities and threatening fresh economic pain for countries and businesses near the conflict zone.

Title: Russian Sieges of Ukrainian Cities Provoke Bitter Recollections for Syrians
Text: Huda Khayti endured years of deprivation under siege by Syrian government forces in a rebel-held Damascus suburb. The thing she says she remembers most is the screams of her neighbors’ hungry children in the middle of the night.
Snippet: “We feel for them and say, may God be with you,” said one Syrian who endured hunger and cold when his own government, backed by Russia, besieged Aleppo.

Title: With Trump in Her State, Haley Finds Some Political Distance (Gently)
Text: Rumors were swirling in South Carolina early this February that Donald J. Trump would try to tear down a Republican congresswoman who had incurred his wrath.
Snippet: Nikki Haley, the former United Nations ambassador, used a well-timed endorsement of Representative Nancy Mace to get on the opposite side of the former president.

Title: President Zelensky Makes His Case for Ukraine to the Russian People
Text: The thing about the videos from the war in Ukraine in 2014 was that there were very few war videos. It was, at least at first, a small-arms war. Fighting, when it erupted, happened on city streets. As soon as shots were fired, whoever was making the video would put away the phone and run.
Snippet: in Russian.

Title: Facebook’s Parent Company Will Make Employees Do Their Own Laundry
Text: The salad days of Facebook’s lavish employee perks may be coming to an end.
Snippet: The company told workers on Friday that it will reduce or eliminate some of its famous perks as it prepares for a return to the office.

Title: Ukraine War Gives Freight Firm a New Purpose: ‘I’m Fighting This Way’
Text: A blue dot on a box means nonperishable food, ready for shipping. A red dot means first-aid items for hospitals still standing. A green dot means supplies for Ukrainians taking up arms: boots and kneepads, socks and gloves, thermal underwear and camouflage-patterned clothing.
Snippet: After Russia’s invasion, Meest-America, which specializes in shipping goods to Eastern Europe, shifted to a singular focus.

Title: Parents Relying on Ukraine Surrogates Desperately Seek Their Newborns
Text: On the day Russia invaded Ukraine, Max and his wife drove from their home in Germany to Poland, and then crossed the border into Ukraine. With fear, they moved in the opposite direction of the long line of cars that intended to flee the country and that was snarling the roads for miles.
Snippet: The Russian invasion has disrupted a thriving hub of legal commercial surrogacy. Some couples are risking trips into the war zone to get their children.

Title: The U.S. and the E.U., aiming to punish oligarchs, ban luxury exports to Russia.
Text: none of these public badges of achievement and culture will be available to oligarchs in Russia any more.
Snippet: The move will prevent any shipments of high-end watches, cars, apparel, alcohol and jewelry from reaching the country.

Title: More Cities Bombarded
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Snippet: Russian forces widened their attacks.

Title: How a Line of Russian Tanks Became an Inviting Target for Ukrainians
Text: The column of Russian tanks rumbled along a main highway to the east of Kyiv, between two rows of houses in a small town — a vulnerable target.
Snippet: A skirmish in an eastern suburb of Kyiv illustrated how close Russian forces have come as they continued to tighten a noose on the city, but also revealed their strategic vulnerabilities.

Title: U.S. Officials Say Superyacht Could be Putin’s
Text: American officials are examining the ownership of a $700 million superyacht currently in a dry dock at an Italian seacoast town, and believe it could be associated with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, according to multiple people briefed on the information.
Snippet: They say they have indications that the $700 million, 459-foot yacht, which is in dry dock in Italy, is associated with the Russian president, backing an earlier claim by a former crew member.

Title: The far right complains after the search engine DuckDuckGo vows to limit Russian propaganda.
Text: Far-right influencers have often encouraged people to use the small privacy-focused search engine DuckDuckGo instead of Google, saying that the giant search engine censored conservative ideas.
Snippet: The backlash underscored the difficulties some technology companies face in limiting the spread of Russian propaganda.

Title: Slowed on the Battlefield, Russia Widens Bombardment of Ukrainian Cities
Text: The Russian military struck Ukrainian cities far from the main battle lines on Friday, pressing its strategy of bombing Ukraine into submission as the country plunged deeper into misery and privation more than two weeks into the war.
Snippet: But military experts, citing previous Russian campaigns, say that strategy is unlikely to succeed without bloody urban fighting.

Title: Republicans Sense an Opportunity in Nevada’s Restless Latino Voters
Text: When Senator Catherine Cortez Masto and her allies unveiled their first paid ads of the 2022 election cycle, the Nevada Democrat’s intended audience was clear: the state’s quarter-of-a-million Latino voters, a critical swing vote.
Snippet: Seizing on signs that suggest Democrats are losing support among Hispanic voters nationwide, Republicans are targeting Senator Catherine Cortez Masto’s seat.

Title: Brittney Griner’s Circle Turns to a Common Strategy: Silence
Text: The detention of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner in Russia on drug charges has left her supporters searching for a road map to a resolution in what could be an especially dangerous situation during the war in Ukraine.
Snippet: Those close to Griner have said little publicly since the W.N.B.A. star was detained in Russia on Feb. 17 on drug charges. Their approach has parallels with other efforts to release Americans held overseas.

Title: Are We Facing Nuclear War?
Text: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
Snippet: Answering your questions about the threat of attack.

Title: Fed officials meet to set rates, and new data on retail sales: the week ahead in business.
Shaming Apple and Texting Musk, a Ukraine Minister Uses Novel War Tactics
Text: After war began last month, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine turned to Mykhailo Fedorov, a vice prime minister, for a key role.
Snippet: Mykhailo Fedorov, Ukraine’s youngest minister, has turned technology, cryptocurrency and social media into modern weapons of war.

Title: That Russian Business You’re Boycotting Isn’t Actually Russian
Text: blueberry-flavored, orange-flavored and the original, face-puckering unflavored version — tweeting #DumpRussianVodka and, at gay bars across the country, made do with Absolut and soda instead.
Snippet: The consumer activism that makes a vodka C.E.O. say: ‘Do you know we’re Latvian?’

Title: Hundreds of Planes Are Stranded in Russia. They May Never Be Recovered.
Text: Hope has faded quickly for a handful of Western companies eager to recover planes leased to airlines in Russia, with the authorities there intent on keeping foreign-registered aircraft within the country and President Vladimir V. Putin openly discussing nationalizing the assets of foreign businesses.
Snippet: Western companies that own the planes face little prospect of getting them back, meaning billions of dollars in losses.

Title: House Democrats Push Biden to Build a Better Midterm Message
Text: After offering her customary lavish praise of President Biden, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi got to the business at hand at a White House meeting last month on the midterm elections.
Snippet: House Democrats have been pressing the president to come up with a bumper-sticker-worthy slogan. The White House says it’s sharpening its message.

Title: What It Was Like to Work for Russian State Television
Text: For eight years, Lee Camp hosted a weekly show on RT America that aimed to satirize American politics, finding punchlines in subjects like sanctions against Afghanistan and student debt forgiveness. That ended unceremoniously on March 3, a week after Russian airstrikes began in Ukraine, when the Russian-state-funded network suddenly shut down.
Snippet: Until RT America ended abruptly, life as a journalist there was “actually so normal.”

Title: Chaos of War in Ukraine Could Fuel New Covid Surge, Doctors Say
Text: The last thing on anybody’s mind these days in Ukraine seems to be Covid.
Snippet: War has pushed Covid out of people’s minds while forcing them into crowded and unsanitary conditions that are fertile ground for the coronavirus, polio and other pathogens.

Title: Russian Scientists Face Isolation Following Invasion of Ukraine
Text: One of the glories of international scientific collaborations, besides sharing costs and brainpower, is the building of personal relationships that transcend individual cultures, traditions and political regimes.
Snippet: International collaborations are unraveling as researchers, including many in Russia, speak out against the invasion of Ukraine.

Title: Pandemic Fears Give Way to a Rush for Bomb Shelters
Text: Across a footbridge from a busy shopping outlet surrounded by verdant fields in northern Italy, workers in a nondescript warehouse are preparing for a nuclear attack, its radioactive fallout and the end of the world as we know it.
Snippet: Since Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, European anxiety has shifted from Covid to nuclear annihilation. Bunkers, survival guides and iodine pills are flying off the shelves.

Title: Arctic Security Concerns Resurface in Canada’s Territories Amid Russian War
Text: For the better part of next week, residents in Canada’s Northwest Territories may see a greater military presence and aircraft whirring about.
Snippet: Between melting sea ice and increased militarization, the Arctic is changing, and premiers in Canada’s territories say the Russian war is another reason to put Arctic security on the policy forefront.

Title: Here are the latest developments in Ukraine.
Text: The war in Ukraine expanded significantly on Sunday as Russian warplanes struck a military base near the Polish border where foreign fighters including Americans were being trained. At least nine people were killed and 57 wounded, officials said.

Title: France Cares About Green Causes, but Not Its Green Party
Text: Yannick Jadot, the candidate for the French Green Party in April’s presidential elections, walked through a small cheering crowd to a podium topped with banners featuring his face, as speakers blasted a version of “What a Wonderful World” by the punk rock singer Joey Ramone. The candidate bobbed his head to the rhythm.
Snippet: As a presidential election looms, the Greens lag far behind in the polls. Analysts say the party has failed to inspire voters and show them it can rule.

Title: Mask mandates were extended for U.S. transit, but dropped in many other settings: The week in Covid news.
Text: In an aggressive step toward normalcy, public school students in New York City returned to mask-optional classrooms on Monday for the first time since the start of the pandemic.

Title: Ukraine War Ushers In ‘New Era’ for U.S. Abroad
Text: The war in Ukraine has prompted the biggest rethinking of American foreign policy since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, infusing the United States with a new sense of mission and changing its strategic calculus with allies and adversaries alike.
Snippet: including China, Iran and Venezuela — to counter President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

Title: U.S. to Send Arms to Ukraine, as Russia Intensifies Campaign of Destruction
Text: Russian forces stepped up their campaign of bombardments aimed at devastating Ukraine’s cities and towns on Saturday, as the White House announced it was sending an additional $200 million in arms and equipment to help Ukraine, defying Moscow.
Snippet: A defiant mayor of a captured city was kidnapped by Russian troops, Ukrainian authorities say, an act that prompted hundreds to protest.

Title: With Bombings and a Funeral, the War Arrives in Ukraine’s West
Text: Men in camouflage, hardened by battle, sniffled as a Ukrainian Orthodox choir sang the haunting funeral mass. One man put his arm around another as tears welled in his eyes.
Snippet: Western Ukraine has been a safe haven for Ukrainian refugees, as well as businessmen, journalists and diplomats. But attacks in two cities pierced the sense of security in the region.

Title: The White House approves $200 million in arms and equipment for Ukraine.
Text: The White House has approved an additional $200 million in arms and equipment for Ukraine, administration officials said on Saturday, responding to urgent requests from President Volodymyr Zelensky for more aid to stave off the Russian invasion.
Snippet: With the new arms package, which officials say includes antitank and antiaircraft missiles, the Biden administration has authorized $1.2 billion in weapons for Ukraine in the past year.

Title: In a Kyiv Basement, 19 Surrogate Babies Are Trapped by War but Kept Alive by Nannies
Text: Down a dusty stairwell, hidden from the shelling that has become the grim background noise of Ukraine’s capital, Ludmila Yashenko fusses with the babies. There are 19 of them, sleeping or cooing in neatly arranged cribs, fed regularly from tubs of baby formula.
Snippet: Some surrogate mothers are trapped by the fighting as their due dates near. And newborns face uncertain fates, with many biological parents now unable to travel to Ukraine.

Title: Street battles hit a Kyiv suburb, some of the closest fighting to the capital yet.
Text: In Irpin, just outside the capital city of Kyiv, Ukrainian and Russian soldiers were fighting a street-by-street battle on Saturday, turning what was a leafy suburb just two weeks ago into a suburban battleground.
Snippet: The capture of the once affluent suburb of Irpin would potentially help Moscow encircle the nearby capital, military analysts say.

Title: How Ukrainian Paralympians Pushed Through Fear and Worry
Text: With heavy hearts and unimaginable worry, athletes from the Ukrainian national Paralympic team arrived in China two weeks ago, seeking to win medals and draw attention to the plight of their country through their athletic achievement.
Snippet: By day in Beijing, athletes raced and trained. By night, they spent time on their phones, connecting with loved ones under attack back home in Ukraine.

Title: The Russians Might Have Expected a Warm Welcome. Instead the Mayor Labeled Them ‘Occupiers.’
Text: Ivan Fyodorov, as his name suggests, is an ethnic Russian in a southern Ukrainian city where Russian is commonly spoken and where cultural and familial ties to the motherland run deep.
Snippet: The 33-year-old mayor of Melitopol, Ivan Fyodorov, encouraged defiance. Then he was arrested, and hasn’t been heard from since.

Title: Saudi Arabia Puts 81 to Death, Despite Promises to Curb Executions
Text: Saudi Arabia said on Saturday that it had put 81 people to death in what was the kingdom’s largest mass execution in years, despite recent promises to curb its use of the death penalty.
Snippet: It was the kingdom’s largest mass execution in years. In many cases, the charges involved “not a drop of blood,” a rights activist said.

Title: When You Think About Investing, Don’t Think About the News
Text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
Snippet: Our columnist spoke with a Nobel laureate, Richard H. Thaler, about how to invest for the long run even if the world seems to be going nuts now.

Title: The Week in Business: Economic Sanctions Take a Toll
Text: More than two million people have fled Ukraine in the last two weeks as Russia’s invasion of the country claimed thousands of lives and cut off access to water and electricity in some cities. In response to the humanitarian crisis, more than 300 companies have withdrawn at least some operations in Russia, according to a list kept by the Yale School of Management. Retail companies closed stores, fast-food restaurants paused operations and business services firms removed Russian partners from their umbrella networks. But some of these measures have drawbacks. They could hurt Russian civilians or other countries that are allied against Russia. President Vladimir V. Putin accused the United States of waging “an economic war” against Russia on Wednesday and the next day told officials in a televised meeting that the assets of U.S. companies that pull out of Russia should be nationalized.
Snippet: Prices for gas, food and rent are going up. Mask mandates are ending. And the Fed is expected to raise interest rates.

Title: On ‘S.N.L.,’ President Biden Seeks Help From TikTok Influencers
Text: It was reported in The Washington Post this week that the Biden administration has been meeting with popular video creators from the social network TikTok and briefing them on the war in Ukraine, an unconventional move that could help the White House in its information battle … or get it made fun of relentlessly.
Snippet: The episode, hosted by Zoë Kravitz, began with Biden briefing a group of creators about the war in Ukraine.

Title: Eastern Orthodox Leaders Are Outspoken on Ukraine War. Except One.
Text: Last week, more than a dozen religious and political leaders sat on the dais of the Ukrainian Orthodox Cathedral of Saint Volodymyr on the Upper West Side, listening to solemn prayers and fiery speeches denouncing Russia and extolling Ukrainian resistance to the invasion that began two weeks earlier.
Snippet: The Russian Orthodox Church is allied with President Putin. But in New York, some of its members are quietly anguished.

Title: U.K. vs. Oligarchs: ‘The Gloves Are Now Off’
Text: On Friday, the day after Britain blacklisted seven prominent Russian oligarchs, residents of the wealthy London borough of Kensington and Chelsea rolled a washing machine overflowing with fake pound notes in front of a multimillion-dollar townhouse belonging to the family of the president of Azerbaijan.
Snippet: Russia’s war in Ukraine has finally led the British government to go after ultrawealthy Russians in London. But curbing the flood of corrupt money will require going after more than the big names.

Title: ‘Think of Groundhogs’: For Life Advice From a Grade Schooler, Press 2
Text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
Snippet: A new hotline, an art project by a small California elementary school, was receiving 9,000 calls an hour from people seeking cheerful advice during trying times.

Title: The base attacked in western Ukraine has been a hub for foreign militaries.
Text: and has become an important logistics hub and training center for foreign fighters since Russia’s invasion began.
Snippet: The base outside Lviv that was attacked by Russian forces early on Sunday was a key link between Ukraine’s armed forces and Western militaries before the war.

Title: Brent Renaud, an American journalist, is killed in Ukraine.
Text: Brent Renaud, an award-winning American filmmaker and journalist, was killed in Ukraine on Sunday while reporting in a suburb of the capital, Kyiv, according to Ukraine’s Interior Ministry.
Snippet: An award-winning filmmaker and journalist, Mr. Renaud, 50, was killed while reporting in a suburb of Kyiv. Another journalist was wounded.

Title: Approval of travel insurance claims slows as the Omicron wave subsides.
Text: twice for weather delays and once because her travel companion tested positive for the virus. Two are still under review, and the first took nearly two months from claim to reimbursement.
Snippet: Experts say you should expect longer waits for a pay out if you make a travel insurance claim.

Title: On a Stage 5,000 Miles Away, He Sings for His Family in Ukraine
Text: Sometimes lately, when he hasn’t been rehearsing Verdi or Tchaikovsky at the Metropolitan Opera, or practicing Italian with a diction coach on Zoom, the bass-baritone Vladyslav Buialskyi takes out his phone and sends a one-word text message: “Mama.”
Snippet: At the Metropolitan Opera, the bass-baritone Vladyslav Buialskyi has become a symbol of his country’s struggles.

Title: At Chelsea, Nervous First Steps Into an Uncertain Future
Text: For the Chelsea fans who headed to Stamford Bridge for the team’s first home game since its world crumbled last week, signs of the club’s new, diminished circumstances were clear to see.
Snippet: Locked shops and rivals’ taunts greeted fans at Chelsea’s first home game since sanctions against Roman Abramovich cast their team’s future in doubt.

Title: Time is running out for civilians in Mariupol, Red Cross warns.
Text: At least 2,187 people in the coastal city of Mariupol have died since the start of the war, Ukraine’s government said Sunday, as the International Committee of the Red Cross warned that time was running out for hundreds of thousands of civilians still trapped in the besieged city.
Snippet: Russian forces encircled the city nearly two weeks ago, and as the death toll rises, eyewitnesses have reported there is little food or clean water, and no medicine.

Title: Brent Renaud, an American filmmaker killed in Ukraine, captured the human toll of war.
Text: When Brent Renaud, an award-winning American filmmaker and journalist, was killed in Ukraine on Sunday, he was there to do what he had done throughout his career: bear witness to the world’s most dangerous stories.
Snippet: Mr. Renaud’s final assignment was documenting refugees fleeing across bridges in Irpin, Ukraine.

Title: Biden Administration Fights in Court to Uphold Some Trump-Era Immigration Policies
Text: President Biden promised to unravel the “moral and national shame” of the immigration policies enacted by President Donald J. Trump. But that was hardly the position Mr. Biden’s lawyers took in a federal courtroom earlier this year.
Snippet: Immigration activists and Democrats say there is a disconnect between the president’s words at the lectern and the government’s litigation in the courtroom.

Title: The Skiing Aigners Are a Nation Unto Themselves
Text: The 2022 Winter Paralympics ended Sunday with China winning, by far, the most medals, 61, followed by the undaunted Ukrainian team and Canada.
Snippet: The visually impaired siblings and their guides accounted for more medals at the Beijing Paralympics than several powerhouse countries.

Title: Ukraine’s energy minister says power has been restored at Chernobyl nuclear plant.
Text: Ukraine’s energy minister said Sunday that power supply has been restored at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, which Russian troops have occupied since late February.
Snippet: Russian troops have occupied the nuclear power plant since late February.

Title: Ukrainian refugees find shelter, and a hearty welcome for their pets, in Romania.
Text: Viktor and Rachel Borovic were very grateful to be given a hot meal at a church in Suceava after they crossed from Ukraine into Romania, but they had to turn down the offer of a bed for the night. Their dog, Busia, and their cat, Coco, named after Coco Chanel, were not allowed to stay.
Snippet: Viktor and Rachel Borovic had only two hours to prepare to flee their city. But they were clear about what was important to them.

Title: ‘Things Will Only Get Worse.’ Putin’s War Sends Russians Into Exile.
Text: They lined up at A.T.M.s, desperate for cash after Visa and Mastercard suspended operations in Russia, swapping intelligence on where they could still get dollars. At Istanbul cafes, they sat quietly studying Telegram chats or Google Maps on their phones. They organized support groups to help other Russian exiles find housing.
Snippet: Thousands of Russians saw their comfortable, middle-class lives fade overnight with the invasion ordered by President Vladimir V. Putin.

Title: Russia Asked China for Military and Economic Aid for Ukraine War, U.S. Officials Say
Text: Russia asked China to give it military equipment and support for the war in Ukraine after President Vladimir V. Putin began a full-scale invasion last month, according to U.S. officials.
Snippet: Jake Sullivan, the U.S. national security adviser, plans to meet with a top Chinese official on Monday in Rome to discuss the war and China’s role.

Title: Booms, Smoke and Fire Signal Horror of Russian Attack on Base
Text: Hours after Russian missiles decimated a military base near the Polish border on Sunday, soldiers in camouflage were still being wheeled out of an overwhelmed nearby hospital on stretchers, many in so much pain they could only turn their heads to reveal eyes stricken with fear.
Snippet: Residents of a town near Poland’s border awoke to frightful sounds and an awareness they were no longer safe.

Title: How Does It End? A Way Out of the Ukraine War Proves Elusive.
Text: The United States accurately predicted the start of the war in Ukraine, sounding the alarm that an invasion was imminent despite Moscow’s denials and Europe’s skepticism. Predicting how it might end is proving far more difficult.
Snippet: Attempts at diplomacy have hit a stone wall as President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia refuses to engage in any serious negotiation, but his endgame is unclear.

Title: Shelling damages a revered monastery, and injures some seeking shelter there.
Text: Fighting has damaged a 16th-century monastery and cave complex that is a highly revered Orthodox Christian site for believers in both Russia and Ukraine, according to a church statement, in an incident sure to drive a deeper wedge between the Ukrainian and Russian branches of the church.
Snippet: The 16th-century monastery is one of the three most sacred sites in Ukraine for Orthodox believers.

Title: Oil Prices Drop as Market Volatility Eases
Text: Oil prices slid at the start of trading on Monday morning, a respite from the volatility of recent weeks as Russia’s assault on Ukraine grinds on.
Snippet: A barrel of oil is trading at roughly $107, while gasoline is at $4.33 on average in the United States.

Title: Russian Airstrike at NATO’s Doorstep Raises Fears of Expanded War
Text: Russia launched a barrage of airstrikes on Sunday against a military base in western Ukraine where American troops had trained Ukrainian forces just weeks earlier, bringing the war 11 miles from the border with Poland, where NATO forces are stationed on high alert.
Snippet: Russian missiles hit a military base being used to train foreign volunteers who want to help Ukraine repel the invasion, killing a reported 35 people just 11 miles from the Polish border.

Title: Maria Bakalova, Billy Crystal and other stars show support for Ukraine.
Text: Most of the Critics Choice ceremony has been focused on prizes, but the war in Ukraine has been addressed in a few ways.
Snippet: Most of the Critics Choice ceremony has been focused on prizes, but the war in Ukraine has been addressed in a few ways.

Title: Should Russian Athletes Be Barred From Competition?
Text: Russia’s Daniil Medvedev, the top-ranked male tennis player in the world, is the No. 1 seed at the big Indian Wells tournament set to finish this weekend.
Snippet: Our columnist examines whether the soft power of sport should be wielded against Russia, penalizing athletes with little or no say in its actions.

Title: How High Oil Prices Threaten a California Plastic Container Business
Text: Long before President Vladimir V. Putin unleashed his war on Ukraine, Mosharraf Khalid was already contending with an expensive, bewildering and unrelenting assortment of problems afflicting the global supply chain.
Snippet: Rising energy costs are lifting the prices of key materials and intensifying inflation, compounding supply chain disruptions caused by the pandemic.

Title: China Sees at Least One Winner Emerging From Ukraine War: China
Text: The war in Ukraine is far from over, but a consensus is forming in Chinese policy circles that one country stands to emerge victorious from the turmoil: China.
Snippet: The country’s leaders think it can shield itself from economic and diplomatic fallout and eventually be seen as a pillar of stability.

Title: How Russians See the War in Ukraine
Text: Russians and Ukrainians are deeply connected. Millions of Ukrainians have relatives in Russia. Many have lived in the country.
Snippet: As well as a military campaign, Moscow is also waging a battle over the truth.

Title: The New York Times launches a Telegram channel to deliver news about the war.
Text: To make our journalism more accessible to readers around the world, The New York Times has launched a new, dedicated channel on Telegram, a messaging platform with more than half a billion active users.
Snippet: The channel delivers reporting from our continuous live blog, where Times journalists are providing witness accounts, interviews and breaking news from the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

Title: Are Big Businesses In or Out of Russia?
Text: As Western governments ratchet up their economic punishments against Russia after it invaded Ukraine, the corporate world has paused or pulled out of operations there. But as the list of companies quitting Russia grows by the day, differences in the degree of disconnection are spurring debate.
Snippet: Companies partially pulling out of the country are under pressure to make a cleaner break.

Title: A pregnant woman photographed after a Russian strike on a maternity hospital has died, The A.P. reports.
Text: The image captured the suffering and chaos of the war in Ukraine in an instant: a pale pregnant woman clutching her belly as she was carried on a stretcher, the red-and-black polka dot sheet under her a stark contrast to the smoking soil, stripped trees and blasted-out maternity hospital around her.
Snippet: Her baby also died, the news organization said. The photo captured last week has become one of the defining images of human suffering in the war.

Title: Companies partly exiting Russia are under pressure to make it all or nothing.
Text: and as Russia’s attacks on Ukraine escalate — differences in the degree of disconnection are spurring debate, the DealBook newsletter notes.
Snippet: Some companies have revised their plans after being pushed to make a more definitive break from the country.

Title: Powell Admires Paul Volcker. He May Have to Act Like Him.
Text: To Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, Paul Volcker is more than a predecessor. He is one of his professional heroes.
Snippet: The Federal Reserve is facing the fastest inflation most Americans have ever seen. Its chair says policymakers will do what it takes to tame prices.

Title: Citigroup, the biggest U.S. bank in Russia, will pull out more business.
Text: Citigroup, the American bank with the largest presence in Russia, said it would broaden its planned withdrawal from the country because of the war in Ukraine.
Snippet: Citi will expand its exit, announced last April, and stop seeking new clients in Russia.

Title: Poland Refused to Play Russia Once. It May Have to Do So Again.
Text: One by one, late on a Friday evening, Robert Lewandowski called his Poland teammates. They were scattered across Europe, and most of them were busily preparing for club games that weekend, but his question could not wait.
Snippet: Poland’s stars cornered FIFA by threatening to boycott a World Cup qualifier. Now, as Russia appeals the decision, Robert Lewandowski, Wojciech Szczesny and their teammates may have to double down.

Title: Zelensky will address Congress in a virtual speech on Wednesday.
Text: As Russia’s offensive in Ukraine intensifies, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine will address Congress in a virtual speech on Wednesday, Democratic leaders said, a move that will likely increase growing momentum on Capitol Hill to pressure President Biden to send fighter jets to Kyiv.
Snippet: The Ukrainian president’s speech will likely increase growing momentum on Capitol Hill to pressure President Biden to send fighter jets to Kyiv.

Title: Large auto supplier warns of a financial hit from the Ukraine war.
Text: A manufacturer of auto parts that employs more than 7,000 people in Ukraine warned Monday that it would suffer a significant financial hit from the war and from sanctions against Russia, an indication of how the fighting could inflict collateral damage on the economy.
Snippet: The problems of Leoni, which makes automotive wiring systems, show the economic collateral damage caused by the Russian invasion.

Title: A Conductor on Why He Stayed in Russia After the Invasion Began
Text: As the Russian military began its attack on Ukraine in late February, the Estonian American conductor Paavo Järvi was in Moscow, leading rehearsals for a long-planned engagement with a Russian youth orchestra.
Snippet: The Estonian American conductor Paavo Järvi chose to remain in Moscow temporarily to lead a Russian youth orchestra: “I felt a responsibility.”

Title: British government announces plan to allow residents to sponsor refugees.
Text: As the humanitarian toll in Ukraine intensifies, the British government announced on Monday a program  for British residents to sponsor Ukrainian refugees,  amid widespread criticism of the country’s limited pathways for those fleeing the war.
Snippet: The program, called “Homes for Ukraine,” offers a new route for Ukrainian refugees to come to Britain, which had previously been limited to those joining family members already living there.

Title: Lithuania, a Vulnerable NATO Link, Readies for Putin
Text: At a border crossing with Poland, Ramunas Serpatauskas was waving down cars crammed with bags, blankets and often three generations of family members one recent evening.
Snippet: The Baltics, wedged between Russia and Belarus, have been likened to a modern-day West Berlin. Many here worry that if Ukraine falls, they might be next.

Title: Democrats Want Investigation Into Postal Service’s Gas Guzzlers Contract
Text: A group of House Democrats called Monday for an investigation into a decision by Postmaster General Louis DeJoy to purchase up to 165,000 gasoline-powered mail trucks over the Biden administration’s objections that the multibillion-dollar contract would undermine the nation’s climate goals.
Snippet: A plan to purchase up to 165,000 gasoline-powered mail trucks instead of electric models has angered Democrats and the Biden administration.

Title: This Year, Try Spring Cleaning Your Brain
Text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
Snippet: Five ways to soothe a mind overstimulated by anxiety, stress and streams of information.

Title: Two Refugees, Both on Poland’s Border. But Worlds Apart.
Text: On the day war broke out in Ukraine, Albagir, a 22-year-old refugee from Sudan, was lying on the frozen forest floor at the gateway to Poland, trying to stay alive.
Snippet: A young man fleeing war in Sudan and a young woman evacuating Ukraine crossed into Poland at the same time. They had very different experiences.

Title: Fox News correspondent Benjamin Hall has been injured in Ukraine.
Text: The Fox News correspondent Benjamin Hall was injured on Monday in Ukraine while reporting outside Kyiv and has been hospitalized, the network said.
Snippet: Mr. Hall is a longtime war correspondent who joined the network in 2015.

Title: The U.S. warns China not to give Russia military or economic aid.
Text: President Biden’s national security adviser met with a top Chinese official on Monday to warn against China giving Russia military or economic assistance, as the Kremlin struggles with the aftermath of its invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The Kremlin denied the report, and the spokesman for the Chinese Embassy in Washington said he had never heard of the request.

Title: A protester storms a live broadcast on Russia’s most-watched news show, yelling, ‘Stop the war!’
Text: A state television employee burst onto the live broadcast of Russia’s most-watched news show on Monday evening, yelling, “Stop the war!” and holding up a sign that said, “They’re lying to you here,” in an extraordinary act of protest against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The intervention by a state TV employee underscored how dissent is seeping into the public sphere in Russia, despite the Kremlin’s crackdown on anyone who challenges its official narrative of the invasion.

Title: How Will It End?
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Snippet: The next two or three weeks may decide whether Ukraine can survive as a state.

Title: He’s American, He Oversees Papa John’s in Russia and He’s Staying
Text: Papa John’s International said last week that it was suspending all of its corporate operations in Russia, following in the footsteps of other high-profile American brands like McDonald’s and Starbucks.
Snippet: Christopher Wynne’s company controls the franchise agreements for the 190 Papa John’s locations in the country. “At the end of the day, they appreciate a good pizza,” he said.

Title: Kyiv’s Once-Busy Streets Empty as Russia Targets Capital
Text: The Ukrainian capital feels almost empty, its wide avenues mostly deserted except for soldiers at sandbagged checkpoints on the main intersections.
Snippet: With civilian areas coming under fire and an estimated half the population having fled, the avenues of the Ukrainian capital, under siege by Russian forces, are almost deserted.

Title: Diplomacy Quickens to Halt Ukraine War or Stop Its Expansion
Text: Diplomatic activity quickened on multiple fronts Monday as Russia’s war on Ukraine entered an uncertain new phase, with President Vladimir V. Putin’s forces widening their bombardment of Kyiv and other cities, hundreds of civilians escaping the devastated port of Mariupol, and the United States warning China over its deepening alignment with an isolated Russia.
Snippet: Ukraine and Russia held a new round of talks and agreed to resume them on Tuesday, as the United States warned China about helping an increasingly isolated Kremlin and expanding the conflict.

Title: How a Murdoch Hopes to Save American Democracy
Text: Over the last decade, as America’s two dominant political parties pulled farther apart, a group of centrist-minded donors was growing increasingly frustrated.
Snippet: Kathryn Murdoch is trying to change how elections are run. It’s a work in progress.

Title: Russian Mogul Is Charged With Donating Illegally to U.S. Campaigns
Text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan on Monday accused a Russian tycoon of scheming to make $1 million in illegal campaign donations to federal and state political candidates in the United States to gain favorable licensing decisions for a cannabis business venture.
Snippet: Andrey Muraviev was indicted on charges of making donations as a foreign national to boost licensing decisions for a marijuana business.

Title: Russia Deploys a Mystery Munition in Ukraine
Text: American intelligence officials have discovered that the barrage of ballistic missiles Russia has fired into Ukraine contain a surprise: decoys that trick air-defense radars and fool heat-seeking missiles.
Snippet: Iskander-M short-range ballistic missiles are releasing a previously unknown decoy designed to evade air-defense systems, an American official said.

Title: Zelensky calls on Russian troops to surrender.
Text: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called on Russian troops to surrender in a video address posted online early Tuesday.
Snippet: The Ukrainian leader and the Pentagon have both said some Russian soldiers have surrendered or been captured.

Title: Here are the latest developments in Ukraine.
Text: Three European leaders were traveling to Kyiv on Tuesday to express the European Union’s “unequivocal support” for Ukraine and offer financial help, the Czech and Polish governments said, even as fighting rages around the city, with half a dozen loud blasts shaking central Kyiv in the pre-dawn hours. The leaders of the Czech Republic, Poland and Slovenia were traveling by train and crossed into Ukraine on Tuesday morning, officials said.

Title: Daniil Medvedev Loses a Match and No. 1 Ranking, but Faces Bigger Concerns
Text: Daniil Medvedev’s reign as the No. 1 men’s tennis player will not last long — at least, not this time.
Snippet: At Indian Wells, the Russian fell in the third round to Gael Monfils of France, as Medvedev faced criticism that Russian players should not be competing because of Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.

Title: A Chinese video blogger in Odessa challenges Beijing’s version of the war.
Text: In the southern Ukrainian port city of Odessa, Wang Jixian often starts his days by recording the sirens howling warnings to residents against Russian air attacks. It’s part of his own battle against the skewed, euphemistic depiction of the war propagated by Moscow’s crucial partner, China.
Snippet: Wang Jixian has become one of the boldest voices confronting the Chinese state-controlled media’s narrative, drawing hundreds of thousands of viewers.

Title: Impunity for War Crimes in Syria Casts a Grim Shadow Over Ukraine
Text: The Syrian police stormed her house and dragged her husband away. Her eldest son died in a rain of Syrian government shells on her hometown. So like millions of other Syrians, Hanadi Hafisi fled the country with plans to return when the war ended.
Snippet: and its dictator stayed in power. That conflict offers lessons for Russia’s leader, analysts say.

Title: The Story Behind a Defining War Photo
Text: This episode details graphic scenes and contains strong language.
Snippet: Lynsey Addario, a photojournalist, took an image that captured the new reality of the fighting in Ukraine.

Title: Prepare for Interest Rate Liftoff
Text: For much of recent history, a rise in bond yields signaled that a stronger economy was ahead. Yesterday, the yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note jumped to 2.14 percent, the highest it has been since 2019, and about four times higher than its pandemic low point in 2020.
Snippet: How high will the Fed go?

Title: Airline Ticket Sales Exceed a 2019 Milestone for the First Time
Text: Rising fuel prices may present an obstacle, but the airline recovery in the United States appears to be on track for now.
Snippet: February bookings for U.S. travel beat those preceding the pandemic, a data analysis found. Summer looks promising for the industry, if fuel costs cooperate.

Title: Coal prices rise to record levels on Russia supply fears.
Text: Prices for coal used to generate electric power have hit record levels in recent days on fears that supplies from Russia could be disrupted. Prices for thermal or hard coal recently topped $462 a metric ton before easing back to about $380, said Steve Hulton, vice president of coal at Rystad Energy, a consulting firm. He said these were record prices, well above established norms.
Snippet: Coal buyers are trying to lock up supplies amid fears that Russia could respond to sanctions by cutting off exports, an analyst said.

Title: India says it’s in talks with Russia about increasing oil imports.
Text: India is in talks with Moscow about increasing oil imports from Russia in an effort to keep spiraling prices in check, India’s petroleum minister told Parliament this week. The move comes as New Delhi is also striving to preserve its relationship with Moscow, its biggest supplier of weapons, at a time when India faces an aggressive China on its borders.
Snippet: The move comes as New Delhi is striving to preserve its relationship with Moscow, its biggest supplier of weapons, at a time when India faces an aggressive China.

Title: Intel to Invest at Least $19 Billion for New Chips Plant in Germany
Text: Intel selected the German city of Magdeburg on Tuesday for its next big chip manufacturing site, continuing a significant expansion aimed at reducing dependence on Asian factories for the vital components.
Snippet: The Silicon Valley company said it would build factories in Magdeburg, mirroring a plan announced in late January to begin manufacturing in Ohio.

Title: Oil prices fall below $100 a barrel as China’s Covid-19 outbreak threatens demand.
Text: Oil prices dropped on Tuesday, falling below $100 a barrel, as China, the world’s largest oil importer, imposed new lockdowns to combat an outbreak of the coronavirus, moves that could threaten demand.
Snippet: Gas prices in the United States were lower on Tuesday. Stock markets rose, with the gains on Wall Street led by airlines.

Title: The U.K. targets more oligarchs and Putin allies with sanctions.
Text: The British government said on Tuesday that it had imposed sanctions on more than 370 individuals it described as oligarchs, political allies or propagandists for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, a major new crackdown that brings it closer in line with the European Union on an issue that has long dogged Britain.
Snippet: More than 370 people are being penalized, including Russia’s prime minister, a former president and the Kremlin’s press secretary.

Title: ‘Minute-to-Minute Triage’: Weighing News Against Safety in Russia
Text: Shortly after Russia passed a new censorship law that effectively criminalized accurate reporting on the war in Ukraine, CNN executives on two continents gathered for an emergency video call to figure out what would happen next.
Snippet: Western news outlets are engaging in a tense debate over balancing an urgent need to bear witness with journalists’ ability to report freely under strict new laws there.

Title: Global Economy Sinks Deeper Into Turmoil as Fed Prepares to Raise Rates
Text: When Federal Reserve officials raise interest rates on Wednesday, they will do so amid an unfortunate economic reality: Many of the inflationary pressures they had long assumed would dissipate have instead lingered, and some are getting worse.
Snippet: Federal Reserve officials are set to raise interest rates to control inflation, but the return to normal they had hoped to see remains painfully elusive.

Title: A Fox News crew in Ukraine was caught in fighting, leaving two journalists dead.
Text: A Fox News cameraman and a Ukrainian journalist traveling with him were killed on Monday in Ukraine when their vehicle came under fire outside Kyiv, according to the network and Ukrainian authorities.
Snippet: Pierre Zakrzewski, a Fox News cameraman, and Oleksandra Kuvshynova, a Ukrainian journalist, were killed outside Kyiv. A Fox News correspondent, Benjamin Hall, remained hospitalized.

Title: ‘I’m Not Scared of Anything’: Death and Defiance in a Besieged Ukrainian City
