Text: Alla Ryabko stood in the courtyard of the city morgue, trembling with grief and rage. Her son, Capt. Roman Ryabko, had been killed in fighting on the first day of the war in Ukraine, but two weeks had passed and his body had not yet been prepared for burial.
Snippet: The port city of Mykolaiv is being shelled by Russian forces every day. Bodies are piled at the morgue. But residents refuse to succumb.

Title: The war in Ukraine is raising fears of a recession in Germany.
Text: Business leaders in Germany are increasingly worried about the impact Russia’s war in Ukraine will have on the German economy, Europe’s largest, where inflation, disrupted supply chains and the high price of energy are leading to fears of a recession.
Snippet: Uncertainty looms for German business leaders, who worry that the war could upend their country’s globalized, export-focused economy.

Title: Music’s Messy Digital Revolution
Text: Streaming saved the music industry from the jaws of the internet. But the complicated picture from the past 20 years shows that surviving an online revolution isn’t the only hard part. What comes next might be even more difficult.
Snippet: Streaming services bring in steady cash for the music industry, but sales are down and many artists feel left out.

Title: Zelensky’s appeal to Canada: Imagine if Toronto were Kyiv.
Text: In an emotional address to Canada’s Parliament on Tuesday, President Volodymyr Zelensky urged its members to support his call for a no-fly zone over Ukraine, asking them to imagine cities like Vancouver or Toronto being attacked, and calling for intensifying sanctions in the face of Russian aggression.
Snippet: The Ukrainian president’s emotional speech to Canadian lawmakers underscored how he has increasingly cast himself as a spokesman for liberal democracy.

Title: Ukraine’s National Anthem Reverberates Around the World
Text: Since Russia invaded Ukraine, the soaring melody of Ukraine’s national anthem has been heard worldwide, from antiwar protests in Moscow to the stages of major concert halls, from N.B.A. basketball arenas to TikTok posts.
Snippet: “Ukraine’s glory hasn’t perished,” begins the anthem, which is being played by orchestras worldwide as a sign of solidarity with Ukraine.

Title: Isla & Co. Opens in Williamsburg, Brooklyn
Text: Until 4 p.m., brunch is the main bill of fare at this new restaurant in the former Du’s Donuts space, in the arcade of the William Vale hotel in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Barry Dry and Tom Rowse, the owners of Parched Hospitality Group, which is behind the Hole in the Wall restaurants, have hired Matt Foley, a former sous-chef at Marea, to be executive chef. He’ll run brunch, as well as dinner, with an eclectic menu that includes a burger, fish and chips, rigatoni alla vodka with spicy shrimp, Thai green curry and half a chicken with roasted spring vegetables. Sticky date pudding and lemon panna cotta are the sweets. The restaurant is a spinoff of Isla in the Hotel Hendricks in Manhattan, which reopens Thursday after a long pandemic hiatus. In addition, locations of Isla & Co. will show up this year in Atlanta, Miami Beach and West Palm Beach. (Opens Wednesday)
Snippet: Vietnamese-influenced breakfast fare in Chelsea; Thai grilled skewers in Elmhurst, Queens; and more restaurant news.

Title: Officials in Mariupol struggle to account for the dead.
Snippet: The coastal city, a battleground for weeks, is under an increasingly relentless Russian assault that is taking an unspeakable toll.

Title: Russian Artists Lose the Tools of Their Trades as Companies Pull Out
Text: In a call from his car on Sunday, a photographer from Moscow explained why he was driving to Tbilisi, Georgia, having left his apartment and essentially his whole life behind.
Snippet: Creative professionals have been cut off from Western clients and from the products and services they use to make, market and get paid for their work.

Title: Biden will travel to Europe next week for an extraordinary NATO meeting.
Text: President Biden will travel to an extraordinary NATO summit meeting in Brussels on March 24 and will also attend the European Union’s summit meeting the same day, White House and European officials said on Tuesday.
Snippet: The president will travel to Brussels for the NATO session, and will also attend a European Union summit meeting.

Title: Ukraine War Shifts the Agenda in Congress, Empowering the Center
Text: The escalating crisis in Ukraine is upending policy and political thinking on both the left and the right on Capitol Hill, as an immediate threat to the global order and soaring energy prices empower the political center at the expense of the two parties’ flanks.
Snippet: With a crisis rocking Europe, the left is shelving demands for defense cuts and a swift end to fossil fuels, while on the right, Trump-era foreign policy and criticism of Ukraine are fading.

Title: Dollars or Rubles? Russian Debt Payments Are Due, and Uncertain.
Text: Russia is teetering on the edge of a possible sovereign debt default, and the first sign could come as soon as Wednesday.
Snippet: Citing sanctions, the Russian government warned it might pay foreign debt obligations in rubles. Credit rating agencies say a default is imminent.

Title: Mandy Patinkin Finds Healing in Refugee Work and Praying With His Dog
Text: winning a Tony Award for “Evita” and an Emmy for “Chicago Hope” and being the object of adoration and imitation as Inigo Montoya in “The Princess Bride” — that he likes to jest he’s getting ready to leave.
Snippet: Right when the actor thought he’d done almost everything, Ken Burns offered him the role of Benjamin Franklin, and, just maybe, held off an early retirement.

Title: A Russian TV worker who protested the war on a live broadcast is fined.
Text: A Russian state television employee who stormed a live broadcast on Monday was interrogated by the police for 14 hours and fined by a Moscow court on Tuesday.
Snippet: In a video following her sentence, the state TV worker said she had been interrogated for 14 hours and “spent two days without sleep.” She still faces a lengthy prison sentence.

Title: On a trip shrouded in secrecy, 3 European leaders travel to Kyiv to offer support.
Text: The leaders of three eastern members of the European Union traveled to Kyiv on Tuesday on a high-risk mission that was kept under wraps until after they had boarded a train to the embattled Ukrainian capital.
Snippet: “It is here, in war-torn Kyiv, that history is being made,” one European leader wrote after arriving in Ukraine’s battered capital.

Title: At least nine House Democrats test positive for the coronavirus after a party retreat and late-night voting.
Text: At least nine House Democrats have announced in the last five days that they tested positive for the coronavirus, with more than half of those cases emerging after lawmakers attended a party retreat last week in Philadelphia.
Snippet: Three representatives reported positive tests on Tuesday morning. Several others tested positive after a party gathering last week in Philadelphia.

Title: Submarine Spy Couple Tried to Sell Nuclear Secrets to Brazil
Text: In 2020, a United States naval engineer and his wife made the fateful decision to try to sell some of America’s most closely guarded military secrets, the technology behind the nuclear reactors that power the U.S. submarine fleet.
Snippet: Jonathan and Diana Toebbe pleaded guilty last month in the espionage case, but until now the identity of the nation they had approached had remained publicly undisclosed.

Title: Scenes from the Resistance
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Snippet: Mykolaiv is under daily attack but its residents refuse to succumb.

Title: The Sounds of Ukrainian Pop
Text: The Russian invasion of Ukraine is entering its fourth week, upending life, damaging cities and towns and spawning a refugee crisis. Culture, needless to say, has largely come to a standstill.
Snippet: A conversation about some of the country’s stars, the musical traditions they work within and how they have grappled with the war.

Title: European Leaders Brave Russian Bombardment in Visit to Kyiv
Text: Three European leaders staged a defiant show of support for Ukraine on Tuesday, traveling to its besieged capital, Kyiv, even as a relentless Russian artillery bombardment left apartment towers in the city ablaze, forcing terrified residents to flee into the street with only the clothes on their backs.
Snippet: The prime ministers of Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia made the trip as a show of solidarity, but it also bared divisions with other European Union members.

Title: Republican in Ohio Senate Primary Spoke Offensively About Asians
Text: The leading Republican candidate in the Ohio Senate primary employed offensive stereotypes about Asian people in a 2013 podcast, citing a widely discredited book, “The Bell Curve,” that has drawn allegations of racism and sloppy research.
Snippet: Mike Gibbons, a leading contender to succeed Senator Rob Portman, made the comments in a 2013 podcast on doing business in China.

Title: Doug Emhoff, Vice President’s Husband, Tests Positive for the Coronavirus
Text: Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris, tested positive for the coronavirus on Tuesday, according to a statement from the White House.
Snippet: Vice President Kamala Harris tested negative for the virus on Tuesday, an aide said, but Mr. Emhoff’s positive test forced her to back out of an event with President Biden.

Title: Zelensky urges more leaders to visit Kyiv after a visit by prime ministers of 3 NATO nations.
Text: President Volodymyr Zelensky thanked the leaders of three NATO member countries who traveled into Ukraine’s war-torn capital for an extraordinary meeting on Tuesday and urged others to do the same.
Snippet: The leaders from Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia “fear nothing,” President Volodymyr Zelensky said, and he urged other leaders to make similar visits.

Title: Refugee Crisis Will Test a European Economy Under Pressure
Text: Nearly everyone who crossed the Danube on the open-air ferry from Ukraine and landed in the frostbitten Romanian port city of Isaccea on a recent morning had a roller bag and a stopgap plan. One woman planned to join her husband in Istanbul. Another was headed to Munich, where her company has its headquarters. Others were meeting brothers, cousins, in-laws and friends in Paris or Sofia, Madrid or Amsterdam.
Snippet: Resettling the refugees fleeing Ukraine could cost $30 billion in the first year alone, and the permanent integration of millions of people would reshape Europe’s economy.

Title: Citing a Chevron Tanker, Ukraine Seeks Tougher Restrictions at Russian Ports
Text: Oil tankers from around the world, including several chartered by U.S.-based companies, are continuing to transport millions of barrels of oil out of Russian ports, a top adviser to Ukraine’s president said, as he made a plea to the White House to restrict all trade in Russian oil by American companies.
Snippet: A top Ukrainian official criticized companies in the United States and Greece for helping Russia continue to profit from oil despite its attack on Ukraine.

Title: Oligarchs Got Richer Despite Sanctions. Will This Time Be Different?
Text: The first time the United States government slapped his family with sanctions and locked him out of the American financial system, Arkady Rotenberg waited about eight weeks, investigators say, before buying a $7.5 million painting in New York City.
Snippet: For nearly a decade, sanctions have been little more than names on a list for wealthy Russians. Governments are working to give them bite.

Title: Why rates are going up.
Text: Prices for groceries, couches and rent are all climbing rapidly, and Federal Reserve officials have been warily eyeing that trend.
Snippet: The central bank wants a strong economy, but sustainability is the name of the game: A little pain today could mean less pain tomorrow.

Title: A Question of Default
Text: and what could happen next.
Snippet: Russian debt faces an uncertain future.

Title: Putin’s War on Ukraine Is About Ethnicity and Empire
Text: President Biden took office with the idea that this century’s struggle would be between the world’s democracies and autocracies.
Snippet: Biden’s framework of ‘democracies versus autocracies’ misses the darker source of this war, which has deep roots in Russian history and thought.

Title: Russian sanctions could create ‘supply crisis’ as oil output falls.
Text: The International Energy Agency warned on Wednesday that the global economy could be whipsawed by both disruptions to oil supplies and a sharp fall in demand resulting from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The International Energy Agency said the global economy could be whipsawed by cuts in oil supplies and a sharp drop in demand.

Title: Retail sales rose in February, but inflation is starting to take its toll on spending.
Text: Retail sales rose 0.3 percent in February from the prior month, the Commerce Department reported on Wednesday, a slowdown in spending that suggested inflation was taking its toll on American consumers.
Snippet: Sales rose 0.3 percent from January, a sharp slowdown in growth. Spending at electronics, appliance, furniture, health and personal care stores was lower.

Title: Mercedes opens a battery plant in Alabama, part of a Southern wave.
Text: The auto industry’s shift to battery power is expected to lead to job losses because it takes fewer workers to build an electric vehicle than it does to build a car with a gasoline engine. But that probably won’t be the case in Alabama.
Snippet: The German automaker, which has made cars in the state for decades, has invested $1 billion in a factory to supply the power for electric vehicles.

Title: As Russia Digs In, What’s the Risk of Nuclear War? ‘It’s Not Zero.’
Text: A major war raging on Russia’s and NATO’s borders. Increasingly bold Western military support. Russian threats of direct retaliation. A mood of siege and desperation in the Kremlin. Growing uncertainty around each side’s red lines.
Snippet: A series of shifts in Russian statements about using nuclear weapons has led some analysts to believe that the Kremlin sees a nuclear exchange as a viable strategy.

Title: A Fox News journalist who was injured in Ukraine is now ‘safe.’
Text: Benjamin Hall, the Fox News correspondent who was seriously injured when his vehicle came under fire outside Kyiv on Monday, is now safe and being treated outside of Ukraine, the network said.
Snippet: Benjamin Hall was seriously injured in an incident that killed a Fox News cameraman and a young Ukrainian journalist.

Title: Boris Johnson travels to Saudi Arabia for oil diplomacy.
Text: Stepping up the search for alternatives to Russian energy, Britain’s prime minister, Boris Johnson, on Wednesday visited Saudi Arabia in hopes of persuading the oil producer to boost output and relieve pressure on global markets.
Snippet: At home, critics had another take on Mr. Johnson’s efforts to reduce western reliance on Russian energy.

Title: What a Federal Reserve Rate Increase Means for You
Text: from credit cards and car financing to private student loans — will increase, too.
Snippet: Rates on credit cards, savings accounts and different kinds of loans move when the Fed changes its benchmark rate. Here’s what you need to know.

Title: How to Outlast 5-Minute Internet Fads
Text: We live in an online world made by Tasty.
Snippet: Hand videos by the food entertainment site Tasty reshaped the internet. The question now is what’s next.

Title: U.S. Casts a Global Net to Stop Shipments to Russia
Text: The United States, in partnership with its allies, has hit Russia with some of the most sweeping export restrictions ever imposed, barring companies across the world from sending advanced technology in order to penalize President Vladimir V. Putin for his invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: To try to halt the war in Ukraine, the U.S. and its allies have imposed the most sweeping export controls seen in decades on Russia. Now they have to enforce them.

Title: Biden announces $800 million in military aid for Ukraine.
Text: President Biden said on Wednesday that the United States would send $800 million in additional military assistance to Ukraine, shortly after the country’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, delivered an impassioned virtual address to Congress in which he appealed for more help in staving off Russia’s invasion.
Snippet: President Biden’s announcement came hours after Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, delivered a virtual address to Congress and pleaded for more help in defending against Russia’s invasion.

Title: Chinese Officer Charged With Harassing N.Y. Congressional Candidate
Text: including a candidate for Congress in New York, a California-based artist, and the father of an Olympic figure skater — in an effort to silence dissident voices, federal prosecutors said Wednesday.
Snippet: Yan Xiong, a Chinese dissident who immigrated to America and is now a political candidate in New York, was targeted by an agent of the Chinese government, federal prosecutors said.

Title: A Russian Ballet Star, Opposed to the Ukraine War, Quits the Bolshoi
Text: Olga Smirnova, who has for over a decade been a star of the Bolshoi, the Russian company whose name is synonymous with ballet, has left.
Snippet: Olga Smirnova said she was against the war in Ukraine “with all the fibers of my soul.” Now, she has joined the Dutch National Ballet.

Title: The Video That Changed the N.C.A.A.
Text: Today, the story of one TikTok that changed the N.C.A.A. forever.
Snippet: One 38-second clip showing differences between the men’s and women’s tournaments led to profound overhauls in gender parity.

Title: Putin Assails Russians Who Back the West, Signaling More Repression
Text: President Vladimir V. Putin on Wednesday referred to pro-Western Russians as “scum and traitors” who needed to be removed from society, describing the war in Ukraine as part of an existential clash with the United States and setting the stage for an ever fiercer crackdown at home and even more aggression abroad.
Snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia denigrated European and American leaders, and Russians who disagreed with him. Analysts fear his remarks could signal a new wave of repression.

Title: Volkswagen eyes U.S. market as war in Ukraine disrupts European production.
Text: Volkswagen is shifting its focus toward North America, as the fallout from Russia’s attack on Ukraine caused more supply chain headaches for the company in Europe, executives said.
Snippet: Focusing on electric vehicles, Volkswagen aims for growth in North America, though it could face tough competition.

Title: Russia’s Attack Rallies a Divided Nation: The United States
Text: After two years of political divisions and economic disruptions bolstered by an unending pandemic, many Americans say they are coming together around a common cause: support for Ukraine, a country under daily siege by Russian forces.
Snippet: Americans across the political spectrum express broad support for Ukraine, though opinions diverge on what that means and how far the U.S. response should go.

Title: The W.H.O. puts off assessing Russia’s Sputnik vaccine because of the war in Ukraine.
Text: Russia’s Sputnik V vaccine against the coronavirus will have to wait longer for a decision on emergency use authorization by the World Health Organization.
Snippet: An official with the World Health Organization said “the assessment, along with inspections, have been affected.”

Title: Zelensky’s Plea to Congress
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Snippet: Biden announced $800 million in new military aid to Ukraine.

Title: Biden Offers Protected Status to Afghans Already in the United States
Text: The Biden administration is allowing Afghans who have been residing in the United States to remain in the country legally for at least another 18 months, an attempt to provide them more stability as gaining permanent residency could take years.
Snippet: The program does not provide a path to a green card or citizenship, which many advocates say is warranted for Afghans who risked their lives to assist U.S. forces.

Title: Annotated Transcript: Zelensky’s Speech to Congress
Text: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine made an urgent and searing appeal to Congress on Wednesday to come to his country’s aid as it fights off a devastating Russian invasion, casting the war as a battle for the cause of democracy itself.
Snippet: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine addressed a joint meeting of the House and Senate to press his case for more aid to Ukraine amid devastating attacks by Russia.

Title: Spain seizes another Russian yacht believed to belong to an oligarch.
Text: Spain, which has pledged to seize the suspected superyachts of Russian oligarchs targeted for sanctions imposed following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, on Wednesday impounded the third such vessel, one of the world’s biggest superyachts, in Spanish territorial waters this week.
Snippet: The ship was impounded in the Spanish port of Tarragona pending an inspection to establish its exact ownership, Spain’s transport ministry said.

Title: As Russian Troop Deaths Climb, Morale Becomes an Issue, Officials Say
Text: In 36 days of fighting on Iwo Jima during World War II, nearly 7,000 Marines were killed. Now, 20 days after President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia invaded Ukraine, his military has already lost more soldiers, according to American intelligence estimates.
Snippet: More than 7,000 Russian troops have been killed in less than three weeks of fighting, according to conservative U.S. estimates.

Title: The Economy’s Terrible, G.O.P. Governors Say. Just Not in Their States.
Text: in their own states, in other words — the economy’s booming.
Snippet: In Maryland, Florida and other states, Republican governors have been attacking the national economy while boasting about the one in their states. Economists say it defies logic.

Title: Invoking America’s Darkest Days, Zelensky Pleads for More U.S. Aid
Text: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine invoked the memory of America’s darkest days on Wednesday as he pleaded for more military aid to combat Russia’s “inhumane destruction” of his country, directly challenging President Biden and members of Congress to help by showing a wrenching video of the carnage in Ukraine’s cities.
Snippet: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called for a no-fly zone and more weapons to combat Russia’s assault and implored President Biden to be “the leader of peace.”

Title: Teaching Resources to Help Students Make Sense of the War in Ukraine
Text: Young people all over are avidly following what some have called “the first TikTok war.” In late February, we created a place on our site for teenagers to react to the invasion, and within a week, over 900 had. This comment from Winn Godier, a high school student in North Carolina, echoes what we have heard from many teenagers:
Snippet: Articles, maps, photos, videos, podcasts and more, as well as suggestions for using them in your classroom.

Title: Hunter Biden Paid Tax Bill, but Broad Federal Investigation Continues
Text: In the year after he disclosed a federal investigation into his “tax affairs” in late 2020, President Biden’s son, Hunter Biden, paid off a significant tax liability, even as a grand jury continued to gather evidence in a wide-ranging examination of his international business dealings, according to people familiar with the case.
Snippet: The Justice Department inquiry into the business dealings of the president’s son has remained active, with a grand jury seeking information about payments from around the world.

Title: Biden calls Putin a ‘war criminal,’ in his latest verbal escalation against Russia.
Text: The rhetorical clash between the United States and Russia escalated on Wednesday when President Biden said that he believed President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was a “war criminal,” and a top Russian official said the comment was “unacceptable and unforgivable.”
Snippet: The U.S. president’s unscripted remarks echoed comments other American officials have made recently.

Title: U.S. Adds ‘Kamikaze Drones’ as More Weapons Flow to Ukraine
Text: The Biden administration will provide Ukraine with additional high-tech defensive weapons that are easily portable and require little training to use against Russian tanks, armored vehicles and aircraft, according to U.S. and European officials.
Snippet: NATO allies are focused on providing Kyiv with high-tech defensive weapons that are easy to use and move.

Title: While Scrolling Through Netflix
Text: When my children were younger, my way of communicating to them that they had pushed past my limit and needed to tidy their living areas evolved, over time, into a game. Games are fun, and they aid children in learning.
Snippet: Daniel Bodily makes his New York Times Crossword debut, ably abetted by Jeff Chen.

Title: Quotation of the Day: A Divided America Is Uniting To Support a Besieged Ukraine
Text: “We can do without gas when there are children there being killed.”
Snippet: Quotation of the Day for Thursday March 17, 2022.

Title: A Russian Rapper Brings His Banned Antiwar Message to Istanbul
Text: Only a month ago it would have been an innocuous scene in Moscow: Oxxxymiron, one of Russia’s most popular rappers, performing his latest tracks onstage with a banner behind him reading: “Russians against war.”
Snippet: The rapper, Oxxxymiron, said proceeds from his show would go to help Ukrainian refugees. Russians at the concert denounced the war but said they felt helpless to stop it.

Title: Trevor Noah: Addressing Congress, Zelensky ‘Knew His Audience’
Text: and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
Snippet: Ukraine’s president must have researched American history before his speech, said Noah (who speculated about how it “could have gone very wrong”).

Title: In Some Parts of the World, the War in Ukraine Seems Justified
Text: To an independent filmmaker in Hanoi, Vietnam, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is a “wise leader.” In Rio de Janeiro, a former restaurant owner said he was convinced that Ukraine had hired actors to fake war injuries. And a 27-year-old doctor living near Nairobi in Kenya questioned how Americans could be outraged over the Russian invasion when “for so long, they had a monopoly over anarchy.”
Snippet: In countries friendly toward Russia, people are troubled by the war and loss of life, but some say they think that Putin has a point.

Title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
Text: As one of the first art festivals impacted by the pandemic, Asia Week New York, the annual showcase of Asian arts and antiquities, is back at full strength this year. Twenty-two galleries will offer in-person exhibitions throughout Manhattan; four will display works virtually, maintaining the digital component the festival has rolled out over the past two years. In addition, six auction houses will hold a score of art sales, and major museums, like the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Japan Society, are planning a range of shows and talks.
Snippet: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.

Title: Inflation vs. Recession: The Fed Is Walking a Tightrope
Text: Even before Russia invaded Ukraine, the Federal Reserve was in a tough spot.
Snippet: American consumers already have high inflation. Because of the oil price shock and Russia’s war, the odds of a recession have increased, too.

Title: UNESCO will send body armor to Ukrainian journalists.
Text: The United Nations’ cultural agency said on Thursday that it was sending body armor and helmets to Ukraine to help protect Ukrainian journalists, many of whom have gone from covering local news to suddenly becoming war correspondents.
Snippet: The U.N. agency said thousands of Ukrainian journalists with no protective equipment or training were now covering the war. At least four journalists have been killed.

Title: Four Paths Forward in Ukraine
Text: It has been three weeks since the war in Ukraine began. The fighting grinds on and there is no clear end in sight. But what are the potential paths forward in the coming days and weeks?
Snippet: How might the war in Ukraine unfold in the coming weeks or, potentially, months?

Title: Amid Invasion of Ukraine, I.R.S. Aims to Police Oligarch Sanctions
Text: The Internal Revenue Service is pressing Congress to devote more resources to the agency as it takes an increasingly central role in the Biden administration’s efforts to prevent Russia and its oligarchs from evading the punishing sanctions that the United States has imposed.
Snippet: It wants to add agents to a 3,000-person investigations unit to help crack down on attempts by Russian oligarchs to evade sanctions.

Title: Russia appears to have avoided default as it makes a $117 million bond payment.
Text: Russia appeared to avoid a default this week after it made interest payments totaling $117 million due on two bonds denominated in U.S. dollars.
Snippet: Sanctions have isolated the country financially, driven down the value of the ruble and cut off Moscow’s access to about half its foreign currency reserves.

Title: Will Inflation Fix Itself?
Text: The Fed, as expected, raised interest rates yesterday, by a quarter of a point. It is the start of what will most likely be a monthslong, if not yearslong, campaign to tame the worst bout of inflation in decades without damaging the economic recovery that the central bank’s efforts during the pandemic helped foment.
Snippet: That appears to be what the Federal Reserve is counting on.

Title: The Bank of England raises rates again in a bid to corral inflation.
Text: The Bank of England raised interest rates to their prepandemic level on Thursday in an effort to combat rapidly accelerating inflation that has been worsened by the war in Ukraine.
Snippet: The bank on Thursday lifted its key interest rate to 0.75 percent, the third consecutive increase.

Title: War Strands Ukrainian and Russian Tourists Together in Egyptian Resorts
Text: The five-star resort on the shores of the Red Sea offers 20 all-you-can-eat restaurants and bars, a water park, a deluxe spa, nightly entertainment, snorkeling, sunset yoga and aqua Zumba.
Snippet: The tension in hotels and on Red Sea beaches is palpable, though there are also moments of compassion.

Title: Russian Court Extends Brittney Griner’s Detention
Text: A Russian court has extended the detention of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner to May 19, the Russian news agency Tass reported on Thursday, adding tension to the most dangerous moment in U.S.-Russia relations since the 1962 Cuban missile crisis.
Snippet: Griner, one of the world’s best basketball players, was detained on accusations that she had hashish oil in her luggage at an airport outside of Moscow a week before Russia invaded Ukraine.

Title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Refugees From Ukraine
Text: Special Announcement for March: The American Statistical Association is now running its annual This is Statistics Spring Contest. Students can showcase their statistical literacy and journalism skills by submitting their clear and compelling headlines for New York Times graphs in March’s four weekly challenges. To learn more, visit This Is Statistics.
Snippet: Since the start of the Russian invasion of Ukraine on Feb. 24, 2022, almost three million of the country’s 44 million residents have left the country. How big is this crisis?

Title: Some of the Tech Magic Is Gone
Text: At this point in 2021, technology was eating the world and stock markets.
Snippet: The bubble hasn’t exactly burst, but we’re no longer seeing a fantastical belief in the power of technology.

Title: Why Arnold Schwarzenegger taped an impassioned video to Russia, telling Putin: ‘Stop this war.’
Text: In an emotional video posted across social media on Thursday, Arnold Schwarzenegger debunked Russian disinformation about the war on Ukraine and told President Vladimir V. Putin: “You started this war. You are leading this war. You can stop this war.”
Snippet: The movie star and former governor of California addressed Russians and Russian soldiers, saying, “ “your lives, your limbs, your futures are being sacrificed for a senseless war.”

Title: Countries previously hostile to refugees embrace Ukrainians.
Text: As the war in Ukraine triggers a mass exodus of refugees, countries have opened their doors wide to Ukrainians, offering a warm welcome that has historically been denied to other populations fleeing conflicts across the globe.
Snippet: While the warm welcome has been applauded, some human rights advocates point to a humanitarian double standard when it comes to refugees from the Middle East and Africa.

Title: 35 companies sign on to produce generic versions of Pfizer’s Covid pill.
Text: Thirty-five manufacturers around the world have signed agreements to produce generic versions of Pfizer’s Covid pills and sell them inexpensively in 95 lower-income countries that together are home to more than half the world’s people.

Title: L.G.B.T.Q. activists in Ukraine share the fight against Russia’s invasion.
Text: To look at videos from last year’s Pride Parade in Kyiv is to peer at a joyous moment of solidarity in the quest for gay rights in Ukraine. A video on YouTube shows a cheerful crowd of thousands. Some wave flags. Some carry banners. Drag queens dance on a float.
Snippet: A pro-Russian puppet government would be less supportive of gay rights, the activists say, and incidents of discrimination would be likely to rise, as they have in Russian-backed separatist regions.

Title: Riding High in the Polls, an Aloof Macron Steps Into the Election Fray
Text: Speaking to a country still reeling from a pandemic and made anxious by war in Europe, President Emmanuel Macron of France made his case for a second term on Thursday by portraying himself as best equipped to protect the nation.
Snippet: The Ukraine war has given the French leader a strong edge and few reasons to engage with his political opponents. He held a news conference to quell criticism that he is avoiding debate.

Title: With a Fourth World Cup Overall Title, Mikaela Shiffrin Is Back on Top
Text: one day after a victory in a downhill race — Shiffrin clinched the World Cup’s season-long overall title, ski racing’s biggest prize, representing the highest achiever in a globe-trotting, six-month, 37-race marathon.
Snippet: The skier said she was “embarrassed” by failing to win a medal in any of her five Beijing Olympic events. Turns out she was in it for the yearlong haul.

Title: House Votes to Suspend Normal Trade Relations With Russia
Text: The House voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to strip Russia of its preferential trade status with the United States, moving to further penalize the country’s economy in response to the invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The bill, which still needs Senate approval, is the latest in a series of measures that lawmakers have passed to support Ukraine and punish Russia for its invasion.

Title: A Show About European Identity Opens With a Backdrop of War
Text: figures like Charles de Gaulle, the former president of France, and Robert Schuman, one of the founders of NATO.
Snippet: Jasmina Cibic’s new exhibition explores the theatricality of nation building in Europe. She didn’t expect it to have such immediate contemporary relevance.

Title: Koch Industries will continue to operate its factories in Russia.
Text: Koch Industries, the industrial conglomerate run by the billionaire Charles Koch, has said it will continue to operate factories in Russia as other companies pull out after Russia’s attack on Ukraine.
Snippet: Koch employs about 600 people in Russia through a unit that makes up a small part of its overall business.

Title: What Has Been Lost in Kharkiv
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Snippet: Russian forces are destroying Ukraine’s second-largest city.

Title: Republicans Once Silent on Russia Ratchet Up Attacks on Biden
Text: The Senate Republican news conference on Wednesday was proceeding with the usual partisan criticism of President Biden and exhortations for him to do more — much more — to bolster Ukraine’s defense when the microphone went to Senator Ted Cruz.
Snippet: Even as they praise the bipartisan congressional response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Republicans are increasingly eager to blame President Biden for the devastation.

Title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
Text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
Snippet: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

Title: Survivors Emerge From a Bombed Theater, but Ukraine’s Suffering Grows
Text: A day after a Russian strike reduced to rubble a theater in southern Ukraine where hundreds of people had been huddling for shelter, rescuers wading through the debris — even as Russian shells kept falling — began pulling out survivors one by one.
Snippet: Russia continues to devastate cities and hit civilians, as Ukrainian forces strike back and peace talks drag on.

Title: Why Vladimir Putin Invokes Nazis to Justify His Invasion of Ukraine
Text: Ukraine’s government is “openly neo-Nazi” and “pro-Nazi,” controlled by “little Nazis,” President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia says.
Snippet: a puzzling assertion about a country whose leader is Jewish.

Title: Climate Activists Flex Their Political Muscle
Text: hitting energy companies with a populist message that puts the party squarely at odds with Republicans and the oil industry.
Snippet: Environmental groups want Democrats to confront oil companies over high gas prices. And Democrats are listening.

Title: U.S. Will Punish China if It Gives Military Aid to Russia, Blinken Says
Text: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Thursday that the United States would punish China if President Xi Jinping chose to give military aid to Russia for the war in Ukraine, where Russian forces have killed thousands of civilians.
Snippet: President Biden plans to talk on Friday with Xi Jinping, who has a close partnership with Vladimir V. Putin and supports him in the Ukraine war.

Title: Sanctions against Russia may cost BNY Mellon $200 million this year.
Text: BNY Mellon, a New York bank that tracks and holds assets for many big institutions, may lose as much as $200 million in revenue this year as it stops new business in Russia and complies with a raft of sanctions imposed by Western nations aimed at crippling the nation’s economy.
Snippet: BNY Mellon has ceased new business in Russia and has “suspended investment management purchases of Russian securities,” it said.

Title: By Labeling Putin a ‘War Criminal,’ Biden Personalizes the Conflict
Text: When President Biden declared to reporters on Wednesday, almost off the cuff, that President Vladimir V. Putin was a “war criminal,” he was speaking from the heart, his aides said, reacting to the wrenching images of civilians — including children — being dragged, dead or disfigured, from ruins of buildings shelled by Russian forces.
Snippet: President Biden’s visceral reaction to the horrifying images coming out of Ukraine also reflects a broader effort to isolate the Russian leader.

Title: U.S. Calls Putin a ‘War Criminal,’ but Consequences Are Unclear
Text: A day after President Biden branded President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia a “war criminal” over civilian deaths in Ukraine, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken on Thursday echoed his assessment and said Mr. Putin would be held accountable.
Snippet: A day after President Biden’s remark, Secretary of State Antony Blinken said he agreed. Experts warned of hurdles to a successful prosecution.

Title: Kids, Covid Isolation and Learning to Endure
Text: We’re binge-buying rapid antigen tests for immediate delivery. We get all our food left at the front door and keep masks in every room. I’ve even revived the indoor exercise regimen from my 14-day stint in Australia’s remote quarantine camp.
Snippet: The virus found us, and we’re doing just fine. I think.

Title: Brittney Griner Said to Be ‘OK’ as Russian Court Extends Her Detention
Text: A Russian court extended the detention of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner by two months on Thursday, and denied an appeal from her legal team, who had hoped to have her transferred to house arrest.
Snippet: Griner, the W.N.B.A. star, has been detained on drug charges in Russia since mid-February and is now expected to remain in custody until at least May.

Title: How the War in Ukraine Could Slow the Sales of Electric Cars
Text: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has shaken the global market for nickel just as the metal gains importance as an ingredient in electric car batteries, raising fears that high prices could slow the transition away from fossil fuels.
Snippet: The price of nickel, an essential ingredient in most batteries, has soared because of fear that Russian supplies could be cut off.

Title: Cities Move to Sever ‘Sister City’ Ties With Russian Governments
Text: At the height of the Cold War, as the deep chill in diplomatic relations between the United States and the Soviet Union persisted, pairs of cities across both countries embraced an idealistic mission: to form cultural and political bonds as “sister cities.” Now, with Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in its fourth bloody week, those ties appear to be fraying as never before.
Snippet: Some city officials say ending ties sends a message condemning the invasion of Ukraine. Others say the best way to have an effect is to use the ties that already exist.

Title: Nations Should Conserve Fuel as Global Energy Crisis Looms, Agency Warns
Text: The war in Ukraine is setting into motion the first global energy crisis of its kind, and nations around the world should respond by reducing their use of oil and gas, the leader of a key international organization warned on Friday.
Snippet: The International Energy Agency said countries should encourage use of mass transit and car pooling, among other things. That could also help the climate crisis.

Title: For a Ukrainian Poet, Putin’s War Is All Too Familiar
Text: At 83, no longer a young poet, Ihor Kalynets knows something of life under Russia’s thumb.
Snippet: Ihor Kalynets, 83, spent a lifetime resisting Soviet domination. Now, he says, he’s not going anywhere.

Title: China’s Information Dark Age Could Be Russia’s Future
Text: When Russia blocked Facebook and limited Twitter this month, many Chinese internet users were surprised. Wait a moment, they said: The Russians could use Facebook and Twitter? Both social media platforms have been banned in China since 2009.
Snippet: Russia and China have the tendency to learn the worst from each other: tyrants, famines, purges and, now, internet censorship.

Title: Pope Deplores the War in Ukraine but Not the Aggressor
Text: The day after Russia invaded Ukraine, Pope Francis broke protocol and went directly to the Russian Embassy in the Holy See to appeal for peace. The next day he spoke to President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, offering him spiritual support. As the war intensified, he raised his voice against “unacceptable armed aggression” and the “barbarism of the killing of children.”
Snippet: Francis has raised his voice against “unacceptable armed aggression” without mentioning President Vladimir V. Putin or Russia. Some analysts say that he risks complicating his legacy.

Title: The Obvious Is Official: Lewis Hamilton Returns to F1
Text: Toto Wolff, the Mercedes team principal, did not doubt Lewis Hamilton would return to Formula 1 this season.
Snippet: After his stunning loss of the championship in the season’s last race, a return had not been certain.

Title: A ‘Killing Stone’ Broke in Japan. Is a Demon on the Loose?
Text: With so much going wrong in the world, should we now also worry about a nine-tailed fox demoness that may be loose in a forest in Japan?
Snippet: The rock appears in a famous legend starring a nine-tailed fox spirit. The question now is whether the fracture was a good or bad omen.

Title: War in Ukraine Prompts a Political Makeover in Poland
Text: After years of cozying up to Kremlin-friendly anti-immigrant firebrands and fulminating against the European Union, the leader of Poland’s populist governing party has taken on an unlikely new role: a standard-bearer of European solidarity in defense of Ukraine and democratic values.
Snippet: Jaroslaw Kaczynski, Poland’s de facto leader and longtime scourge of E.U. unity, is portraying himself as a standard-bearer of European solidarity in defense of Ukraine and democratic values.

Title: Is the Nickel Market Broken?
Text: and raising fundamental questions about how commodity markets work.
Snippet: The chaos in trading of the metal could have broad implications.

Title: How one energy company C.E.O. is trying to keep the lights on in Ukraine.
Text: Keeping millions of customers in Ukraine supplied with electric power amid the Russian invasion is, to say the least, challenging. Especially when the electrical grid itself becomes a target.
Snippet: DTEK, a prominent Ukrainian power company, arranges for soldiers to escort its emergency repair crews to reach damaged transmission lines.

Title: Russia’s Brutality in Ukraine Has Roots in Earlier Conflicts
Text: As Russian artillery and rockets land on Ukrainian hospitals and apartment blocks, devastating residential districts with no military value, the world is watching with horror what is, for Russia, an increasingly standard practice.
Snippet: Its experience in a string of wars led to the conclusion that attacking civilian populations was not only acceptable but militarily sound.

Title: At P.S.G., Kylian Mbappé Has to Go
Text: Only one player escaped the ire of the Parc des Princes. Paris St.-Germain’s fans whistled and jeered every time Lionel Messi touched the ball. They howled and crowed at the sight of a wayward shot from Neymar. There was no allowance in their anger for reputation, no discrimination by status. It encompassed mortal and immortal alike.
Snippet: Mbappé is a generational talent who deserves a bigger stage on a weekly basis than the one Paris St.-Germain can offer.

Title: Russian Conductor Will Not Appear With New York Philharmonic
Text: The Russian conductor Tugan Sokhiev, who recently resigned from two high-profile posts after facing pressure to condemn the Russian invasion of Ukraine, will no longer lead a series of concerts with the New York Philharmonic because of the war, the orchestra announced on Friday.
Snippet: Tugan Sokhiev, who resigned from two posts after facing pressure to condemn the invasion of Ukraine, will not perform with the orchestra because of the war.

Title: Russia’s military progress slows, but it makes gains in the south and east.
Text: Even as a missile strike on Friday hit the outskirts of Lviv, a Ukrainian city that had been spared much of the Russian assault, the latest intelligence assessments indicate that Russian forces are still struggling to capture more territory as they try to push across Ukraine.
Snippet: Britain’s defense intelligence service said that Russian forces had “made minimal progress this week.”

Title: Climate change is making armed conflict worse. Here’s how.
Text: If you’ve read the work of brave journalists in Mariupol this week, you know that the people of that city are trying to survive not just shelling by Russian forces. They are also trying to survive without water.
Snippet: Warming is “unambiguously worsening” conditions that contribute to clashes and deepen the pain for civilians, a new study says.

Title: An economic decline is coming, Russia’s central bank chief says.
Text: Russia’s central bank governor, Elvira Nabiullina, said on Friday that the country’s economy would decline in the coming quarters and that inflation would jump further as sanctions imposed after the invasion of Ukraine took their toll. Earlier, the bank’s board of directors held interest rates at 20 percent.
Snippet: Inflation and “large-scale structural transformation” are ahead, as the bank held interest rates at 20 percent.

Title: As diplomacy drags on, peace seems far off in Ukraine.
Text: Ukraine and Russia are engaged in intermittent negotiations to end a brutal war now in its third week. But despite signs of progress, Western officials have little optimism that the talks have reached a serious stage or even confronted the most difficult issues.
Snippet: Western officials have little optimism that talks between Russia and Ukraine have reached a serious stage or have even confronted the most difficult issues.

Title: Defying China’s Censors to Urge Beijing to Denounce Russia’s War
Text: When Hu Wei, a politically well-connected scholar in Shanghai, warned that China risked becoming a pariah if it didn’t denounce Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, he ignited a war of words on China’s internet.
Snippet: A persistent minority of Chinese scholars, journalists and citizens is warning Beijing against the risks of supporting the invasion of Ukraine.

Title: Stocks notch their best week since November 2020.
Text: Oil prices slid and the Federal Reserve offered investors clarity on its plan to tame inflation, triggering a rally that pushed stocks to their best week in more than a year.
Snippet: Some of the pressures that had combined to sour once-ebullient markets seemed to be easing.

Title: Biden Warns China of ‘Consequences’ if It Aids Russia in Ukraine War
Text: President Biden warned President Xi Jinping of China on Friday of “implications and consequences” if Beijing decides to give material aid to Russia to support its war in Ukraine, the White House said.
Snippet: President Biden told China’s leader, Xi Jinping, there would be consequences if Beijing gave material support to Russia, implying that the United States could impose sanctions on China.

Title: Ukraine Is Wrecking Russian Tanks With a Gift From Britain
Text: In video after video taken in Ukraine, a puff of smoke and a brief flash of light signal that another clutch of Russian troops are about to die.
Snippet: The NLAW antitank missile weighs about half as much as an American-made Javelin, costs far less and can be easily discarded after use.

Title: Kyiv’s Suburbs Become Unlikely Front Line of Ukraine War
Text: A tall woman with blonde and pink hair and a small dachshund stood out among the crowd of police officers and volunteers at the checkpoint on the edge of Kyiv. She looked as if she were out for a stroll, but she had just survived a dangerous evacuation under mortar fire.
Snippet: With savage artillery exchanges, the areas on the outskirts of the capital are the scenes of seesaw battles that have stalled the Russian advance for now.

Title: Biden Warns China
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Snippet: In a two-hour call, the president told Xi Jinping there would be “consequences” if China provides aid to Russia.

Title: Russia Targets Western Ukraine as Biden Warns Xi Not to Aid Moscow
Text: Russian forces extended their bombardments into a relatively unscathed part of western Ukraine on Friday, striking a warplane repair plant about 50 miles from the Polish border, as President Biden warned President Xi Jinping of China not to provide military aid to Russia amid a scramble of diplomatic efforts to end the violence engulfing Ukraine.
Snippet: A scramble of diplomatic efforts bears little fruit as Russia intensifies its attacks, including with a bombardment into a relatively unscathed part of western Ukraine.

Title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
Text: Good evening. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
Snippet: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

Title: Politics Still Pushes Buttons. This One Sold for $185,850.
Text: Ted Hake has seen his fair share of memorable campaign tokens since he started his auction business, Hake’s Auctions, in 1967. The peanut-shaped fishing lure with a mouth shaped like Jimmy Carter’s toothy smile stands out. There are also campaign cigars, bottles, plates and lots of ribbons.
Snippet: The political button business has been booming. A Cox/Roosevelt campaign button from 1920 was auctioned for a six-figure sum this week.

Title: Speeches by the Fed chair and a measure of consumer sentiment: the week in business.
Russia’s astronauts enter the space station in yellow and blue flight suits.
Text: yellow and blue, similar to the colors of Ukraine’s flag.
Snippet: It was unclear why the Russian astronauts wore suits the same color as the Ukrainian flag.

Title: Utility Bills Piled Up During the Pandemic. Will Shut-offs Follow?
Text: When the pandemic led to lockdowns that triggered huge job losses, people in New York City and the surrounding region accumulated a mountain of debt. For many that included utility bills. Residents of New York and New Jersey owe the staggering sum of more than $2.4 billion to utility companies.
Snippet: Moratoriums have expired on turning off utilities for customers who have failed to pay their bills, prompting fears that thousands could be left in the dark.

Title: ‘They Keep Killing Us’: Violence Rages in Sudan’s Darfur Two Decades On
Text: A soot-streaked shell is all that remains of Awatif Fadl’s house, destroyed a year ago when gunmen riding camels, horses and motorcycles stormed through Krinding, a remote camp in Darfur, western Sudan, firing their weapons and burning every home in sight.
Snippet: The resurgence of ethnically motivated attacks in the country’s restive western region has led to enormous displacement and a growing humanitarian crisis.

Title: There’s a Messaging Battle Right Now Over America’s Energy Future
Text: Climate scientists, oil executives, progressives and conservatives all agree on one thing these days: The energy transition is upon us.
Snippet: Climate scientists and fossil fuel executives use the same terms when they talk about an energy transition. But they mean starkly different things.

Title: Ukrainians Are Trickling Into the U.S. to Warm Welcomes
Text: Paul and Rose Chorney’s home near Sacramento has turned in recent weeks into a way station of sorts for Ukrainian refugees: A couple and their three children occupy one of the three bedrooms; another family of four is sleeping in a camper in the driveway; and a studio apartment is going up outside to make room for more arrivals.
Snippet: Pressure is building on the Biden administration to speed up admissions for Ukrainian refugees, but some are already making their way to the United States.

Title: The Battle for Kyiv Looms as a Long and Bloody Conflict
Text: The city of Kyiv covers 325 square miles and is divided by a broad river. It has about 500,000 structures — factories, ornate churches and high-rise apartments — many on narrow, winding streets. Roughly two million people remain after extensive evacuations of women and children.
Snippet: Ukraine’s capital is the biggest prize of all for the Russian military. If Russia tries to take control, it could lead to one of the biggest urban conflicts since World War II.

Title: Zelensky Pleads to Parliament for More Help. What Can Canada Offer?
Text: The appearance by President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine before the Canadian Parliament this week may have been virtual, but the emotions it generated were very much real. Even before Mr. Zelensky began to speak, members of the House of Commons and the Senate gave him two sustained standing ovations. When he finished speaking, he received yet another standing ovation, this one lasting for three minutes.
Snippet: The address by President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine was also a reminder that Canada might indirectly benefit from the crisis.

Title: Remains of 4 U.S. Marines Retrieved From Site of Osprey Crash in Norway
Text: The bodies of four U.S. Marines who were killed in Norway during a NATO training exercise were retrieved from the accident site, the Norwegian Armed Forces said on Sunday.
Snippet: The police said that the tilt-rotor aircraft, which was taking part in a NATO training exercise, crashed on Friday evening, killing all crew members aboard.

Title: How to Fight Inflation in Wartime
Text: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
Snippet: way back — in American history for ideas about what to do about rising prices.

Title: Putin Isn’t Yet Ready for Talks With Zelensky, Turkish Official Says
Text: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called publicly on Saturday for direct negotiations with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, but a senior Turkish official said that Mr. Putin was not ready for such talks.
Snippet: Turkey is trying to mediate between Ukraine and Russia and bring an end to the war. But a senior Turkish official said that Russia was in no hurry.

Title: Ukraine’s celebrities are dying in the war, adding an extra dimension to the nation’s shock.
Text: A male ballet dancer. An award-winning female actor. A biathlete. An actor who posted glamorous selfies on Instagram to his nearly 13,000 followers until he joined up and uploaded two final shots of himself looking stylish in camouflage.

Title: Ukraine Reminds Georgia of Its Own War With Russia. That Creates a Dilemma.
Text: When she hears the latest news from Ukraine, Tina Marghishvili, a Georgian farmer, remembers the forest her father planted. She remembers her childhood home, her cows, her family orchard — all the land and belongings that her family hasn’t seen since 2008, when Russian troops forced them from their hometown during that year’s Russian-Georgian war.
Snippet: Russia invaded Georgia in 2008. To many Georgians, that means the country should stand unequivocally with Ukraine. But the government is more cautious.

Title: For the U.S., a Tenuous Balance in Confronting Russia
Text: In the first weeks of the first major European land war of the 21st century, the United States has sent tank-killing weapons to Ukrainian forces, but not fighter jets. It is equipping embattled Ukrainian troops with lightweight “kamikaze” attack drones, but not, at least in an obvious way, conducting an aggressive cyberwar to degrade Russia’s technological advantage.
Snippet: Navigating between aiding Ukraine and avoiding an escalation with Moscow has led to a tangle of decisions and sometimes tortured distinctions over weapons and other elements of policy.

Title: Deadly Strike on Ukraine Barracks Punctuates Russian Military Gains
Text: Russian forces made significant gains in Ukraine on Saturday, advancing into the besieged port of Mariupol, destroying an underground weapons depot in the west and leaving a marine barracks in ruins following one of the deadliest rocket strikes on Ukraine’s military in the nearly month-old war.
Snippet: Ukraine said it had temporarily lost contact with officials in the strategic port city of Mariupol, and a Russian rocket attack on a military site in Mykolaiv left dozens dead.

Title: Russia claims to use a hypersonic missile in attack on arms depot in Ukraine.
Text: Russia has fired scores of guided missiles into Ukraine, but on Saturday it claimed for the first time that it had launched one capable of hypersonic speed in an attack on an ammunition depot in western Ukraine. The report could not be independently verified, but if true could be the first use of a hypersonic weapon in combat.
Snippet: The United States, Russia and China have all been racing to develop hypersonic weapons, which can maneuver in flight at more than five times the speed of sound.

Title: Spain, Seeking Better Ties With Morocco, Shifts Stance on Western Sahara
Text: In a bid to ease tensions with Morocco, Spain has recognized for the first time a plan drawn up by the African country for governing Western Sahara, a former Spanish colony that has been torn by a separatist conflict for five decades.
Snippet: Madrid endorsed a plan for limited autonomy for the territory in northwestern Africa, but the change in policy was denounced by independence groups and could aggravate relations with Algeria.

Title: Russian Rocket Attack Turns Ukrainian Marine Base to Rubble, Killing Dozens
Text: The headquarters of the 36th Ukrainian Naval Infantry Brigade based in the southern city of Mykolaiv is no more. It is now a pile of rubble, where on Saturday rescuers continued to search for bodies of missing marines.
Snippet: More than 40 marines were killed, an official said, but there were signs the toll could much be higher. At the Mykolaiv morgue, dozens of bodies were laid out in a storage area.

Title: Its offensive slowed, Russia uses long-range missiles to devastating effect.
Text: Even as the Russian ground advance on key targets including Kyiv and Odessa remains stalled, it has used long-range rockets in recent days to devastating effect against the Ukrainian military and infrastructure.

Title: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
Text: Russian forces made significant gains in Ukraine, advancing into the port of Mariupol, destroying an underground weapons depot and leaving a barracks in ruins following one of the deadliest rocket strikes on Ukraine’s military in the nearly month-old war.

Title: ‘I Don’t Have the Right to Cry’: Ukrainian Women Share Their Stories of Escape
Text: In war, things can change quickly. You look away and the kaleidoscope has turned. Suddenly the greens click out of view and the reds have taken their place.
Snippet: in whatever blurry way one can in a war — this moment in this war, three weeks in.

Title: Russian Soldiers Took Their City, Then Their Homes
Text: For days, Roman Naumenko and his neighbors at the Pokrovsky apartment complex outside Kyiv had been watching from a few short miles away as Russian forces tried to take over a nearby airport.
Snippet: As Russian forces pushed toward Kyiv, they stormed an apartment complex in a nearby suburb and held residents hostage. Some of it was caught on camera.

Title: Truth Is Another Front in Putin’s War
Text: In the tense weeks before Russia invaded Ukraine on Feb. 24, Russian officials denied that it planned anything of the sort, denouncing the United States and its NATO allies for stoking panic and anti-Russian hatred. When it did invade, the officials denied it was at war.
Snippet: The Kremlin has used a barrage of increasingly outlandish falsehoods to prop up its overarching claim that the invasion of Ukraine is justified.

Title: Russia Is Losing Tens of Thousands of Outward-Looking Young Professionals
Text: At the Lumen cafe in the Armenian capital, Russians arrive as soon as the doors open, ordering specialty coffees, opening up their sleek Apple laptops and trying to navigate a dwindling array of options for starting their lives over.
Snippet: Many of them have been streaming into Armenia, where they can work I.T. jobs remotely, at least for a while. At cafes in the capital, Yerevan, the exiles try to plot out new lives from their laptops.

Title: Ukraine War Threatens to Cause a Global Food Crisis
Text: The war in Ukraine has delivered a shock to global energy markets. Now the planet is facing a deeper crisis: a shortage of food.
Snippet: A critical share of the world’s food and fertilizer is stuck in Russia and Ukraine, sending global prices soaring and foreshadowing a rise in world hunger.

Title: The 9/11 Trial: Why Are Plea Bargain Talks Underway?
Text: Pentagon prosecutors have struggled for more than a dozen years to hold the death-penalty trial of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the accused mastermind of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, and his four co-defendants at Guantánamo Bay.
Snippet: New leadership, an ever receding trial date and pressure to disclose more information about the C.I.A. torture of the accused plotters all contribute.

Title: War Brings Out Solidarity and Defiance in Ukrainians Who Remain
Text: The historic center of Kyiv, usually bustling with tourists and souvenir stalls around its pastel-colored buildings and golden domed churches, is largely deserted these days. Shops and offices are closed, and the city, placed under curfew from 8 p.m., falls dark and silent at night.
Snippet: About two million people have stayed in Kyiv, a population galvanized by a newfound unity and its refusal to be cowed by Russian invaders.

Title: Russia Broadens Mariupol Assault as Signs of Stalemate Take Shape
Text: Firing rockets and bombs from the land, air and — probably for the first time — from warships in the Sea of Azov, Russian forces broadened their bombardment of the besieged Ukrainian city of Mariupol on Sunday and have forcibly deported thousands of residents, according to city officials and witnesses.
Snippet: The battle for Mariupol has become a grim symbol of Russia’s superior firepower and its frustration in failing to subjugate Ukraine after more than three weeks of war.

Title: U.S. to Declare That Myanmar’s Military Committed Genocide
Text: Five years after Myanmar’s military began a killing spree against ethnic Rohingya, driving nearly one million people from their country, the United States has concluded that the widespread campaign of rape, crucifixions, and drownings and burnings of families and children amounted to genocide.
Snippet: The Biden administration had been weighing the legal designation for the bloody campaign against members of the Rohingya, a minority ethnic group.

Title: Disney Shanghai temporarily shuts down as Omicron surges in China.
Text: Disney will temporarily close its resort in Shanghai from Monday in response to China’s rising numbers of Covid cases, the company announced.
Snippet: The move came amid growing restrictions on travel and entertainment across China as the government tries to stamp out the Omicron variant.

Title: With Inflation Surging, Biden Targets Ocean Shipping
Text: With inflation surging at its fastest pace in 40 years, President Biden has identified a new culprit that he says is helping fuel America’s skyrocketing prices: The ocean vessels that ferry containers stuffed with foreign products to America’s shores each year.
Snippet: The president is targeting shipping companies that have jacked up prices during the pandemic, but critics say bigger economic forces are at work.

Title: An Ancient City Transformed by War
Text: On the night before the Russian invasion of Ukraine, a musician was singing on a cobblestone street in the heart of Lviv’s old town, the glow from heat lamps casting a soft light on a yellow stone house.
Snippet: Simple rituals, like having coffee in a cafe in Lviv, Ukraine, take on a new and sometimes surreal meaning in a radically altered context.

Title: Fleeing War in Ukraine, They’re Met With Employers Offering Paychecks
Text: German companies are touting thousands of jobs for Ukrainian refugees. Portuguese firms promise language training for Ukrainians looking for work. In Lithuania, businesses are providing on-site child care to help Ukrainian women move seamlessly into the workplace.
Snippet: Job boards are overflowing with offers dedicated to Ukrainian refugees, as businesses and governments fast-track access to employment.

Title: Business Reckons With a Historic Court Moment
Text: Today, senators will begin hearings on the historic nomination of the federal appellate judge Ketanji Brown Jackson to the Supreme Court. She is the first Black woman nominated to serve on the court and the only candidate ever to have served as a public defender. Here’s what her nomination might mean for business.
Snippet: What Ketanji Brown Jackson’s nomination to the Supreme Court means for corporate America.

Title: How to Avoid Sharing Misinformation on the War in Ukraine
Text: Sorting out what is real in Ukraine and what is misinformation designed to provoke an emotional response is hard enough for professional journalists. For everyday people seeing photos and videos cascade through their social media feeds, it is even harder.
Snippet: Here are warning signs to look for before you retweet.

Title: Creating Space Command, Australia Strengthens High-Tech Bond With U.S.
Text: Two years after the United States inaugurated a military Space Force to mixed reviews, Australia has created its own Space Command to counter threats from China, Russia and other extraterrestrial powers.
Snippet: The expanded commitment to space defense reflects the reality of a new, extraterrestrial landscape for war.

Title: Powell Says Fed Could Raise Rates More Quickly to Tame Inflation
Text: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said on Monday that the central bank was prepared to more quickly withdraw support from the economy if doing so proved necessary to bring rapid inflation under control.
Snippet: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, voiced worry about inflation expectations and declared the central bank ready to do what it takes to control rapid price increases.

Title: The Man in the Olive Green Tee
Text: In the beginning, it was just a T-shirt: basic, olive green; the kind worn under military fatigues or hauled out from the bottom of a wardrobe for workouts and weekends. Sometimes it was more brown than green. Sometimes there was a cross over the heart, with a coat of arms in the center.
Snippet: How President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine transformed the meaning of a piece of cotton.

Title: U.N. Chief Warns of ‘Catastrophe’ With Continued Use of Fossil Fuels
Text: Countries are “sleepwalking to climate catastrophe” if they continue to rely on fossil fuels, and nations racing to replace Russian oil, gas and coal with their own dirty energy are making matters worse, United Nations Secretary General António Guterres warned on Monday.
Snippet: António Guterres, the United Nations secretary general, said instead of replacing Russian oil, gas and coal, nations must pivot to clean energy.

Title: How One Oligarch Used Shell Companies and Wall Street Ties to Invest in the U.S.
Text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
Snippet: Using a network of banks, law firms and advisers in multiple countries, Roman Abramovich invested billions in American hedge funds.

Title: In Tunisia, an Authoritarian’s Reform Plan Meets With Skepticism
Text: Tunisia’s president, Kais Saied, has amassed nearly absolute power over the last eight months — dismissing Parliament, arresting opponents, ruling by decree — in the name of the Tunisian people. On a self-appointed mission to rescue ordinary Tunisians from their corrupt political system and sinking economy, he called upon the people to join a national dialogue this winter in which they would help shape a new constitution.
Snippet: President Kais Saied, who has amassed nearly absolute power, launched a consultation he said would lead to a new constitution and elections. But the process has been shunned by many.

Title: W.T.O. chief calls for deeper global trade to address supply chain disruptions.
Text: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, the director general of the World Trade Organization, called Monday for addressing choke points in global supply chains by bringing more countries into international production networks, something she termed “reglobalization.”
Snippet: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, the World Trade Organization’s director general, said bringing more countries into international production networks could make supply chains more resilient.

Title: Walls, Dreams and Genocide: Zelensky’s Speeches Invoke History to Rally Support
Text: He told U.S. lawmakers that he had a dream, invoking Martin Luther King Jr. to describe Ukraine’s fight against the Russian invasion. He said to the British Parliament that his country would fight until the end, in forests and fields, a vow resonant of Winston Churchill’s exhortations against Nazism. To members of the German Parliament he spoke of a new wall dividing Europe, echoing the Berlin Wall of the Cold War.
Snippet: The Ukrainian leader, a former actor, has invoked emotional moments in the history of nations from which he is hoping to secure backing. We look at five of his recent speeches.

Title: The Smaller Bombs That Could Turn Ukraine Into a Nuclear War Zone
Text: with mutual assured destruction, or MAD. The psychological bar was so high that nuclear strikes came to be seen as unthinkable.
Snippet: Military experts say a new generation of nuclear weapons has raised the risk that Mr. Putin might introduce less destructive atomic arms into the battlefields in and around Ukraine.

Title: Myanmar’s Military Committed Genocide Against Rohingya, U.S. Says
Text: Against the backdrop of a war in Ukraine and atrocities in Ethiopia, the United States on Monday formally accused Myanmar of committing genocide against its minority Rohingya population.
Snippet: Secretary of State Antony Blinken announced the official designation. More than 9,000 people were killed in the violence.

Title: As Big Shows of Russian Art End in Europe, Some Wonder What’s Next
Text: A blockbuster show at the Louis Vuitton Foundation, on the outskirts of Paris, has been seen by over a million people since it opened in November. Known as the Morozov collection, it includes paintings by Picasso, Gauguin, Renoir and Van Gogh, as well as some of Russia’s most renowned painters. The collection, which had never before been seen outside Russia, is so important to the country that President Vladimir V. Putin personally signed off on the works traveling to France.
Snippet: Museums in London and Paris are grappling with questions about how to get art back to Russia, and whether the works will ever be seen again in Europe.

Title: Russia’s Loss of Rocket Launch Business Becomes SpaceX’s Gain
Text: OneWeb, a British satellite internet company that canceled rocket launches with Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, is turning to SpaceX to send broadband satellites into space.
Snippet: OneWeb, a British satellite internet company, turned to SpaceX’s rockets after canceling launches with Russia’s Soyuz vehicle over the invasion of Ukraine.

Title: Biden warns the private sector that Russia is exploring options for cyberattacks.
Text: President Biden warned on Monday that Russia is exploring the possibility of waging potential cyberattacks against the United States in retaliation for economic penalties imposed on Moscow for the invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The president cited “evolving intelligence” and urged companies to strengthen their defenses immediately.

Title: As Mariupol Is Bombed and Besieged, Those Trapped Fight to Survive
Text: Eduard Zarubin, a doctor, has lost everything. But he does still have his life.
Snippet: For three weeks, the Ukrainian port city has been without water, heat, electricity and all communication under a merciless Russian assault. Here’s what its residents have been enduring.

Title: ‘Hell’ in Mariupol
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Snippet: The city has seen some of the war’s worst horrors.

Title: After China’s Worst Air Crash in Years, a Desperate Hunt for Survivors
Text: Rescue workers searched a remote mountain valley in southern China on Tuesday for any survivors in the crash of a passenger plane carrying 132 people that plunged more than 20,000 feet in just over a minute.
Snippet: The plane that crashed in a mountainous area of southern China was carrying 132 people, and no survivors have been found so far, a state broadcaster said on Tuesday.

Title: Russians Pound Ukrainian Cities, as Biden Rallies Anti-Kremlin Alliance
Text: Strikes on cities across Ukraine left a patchwork of death and destruction on Monday, including one that blasted a once-bustling shopping mall in Kyiv into a smoldering ruin with one of the most powerful explosions to hit the city since Russia’s war on Ukraine began.
Snippet: A powerful explosion ruined a shopping mall in Kyiv and claimed several lives, while Ukraine refused a Russian demand to surrender the devastated city of Mariupol.

Title: For These Republicans, Supreme Court Hearings Are an Irresistible Opportunity
Text: Every senator looks in the mirror and sees a future president, the old saw goes.
Snippet: Four of the senators on the panel grilling Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson are known to have dreams beyond the walls of the U.S. Senate.

Title: In Warsaw, a Network of Support Greets Those Crossing the Polish Border
Text: Ilona Yurchenkov, 28, sits on a black chair in a sprawling expo center on the outskirts of Warsaw, a Yankees hat on her head and her cat, Mars, in a pet carrier beside her. She left her home in the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv when fighting began there, and she has been on the road for days.
Snippet: A sprawling expo center in the Polish capital has given some 25,000 refugees a safe place to recharge before journeying on.

Title: Zelensky condemns Russian attacks on protesters and children.
Text: In a video address shared online early Tuesday, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine condemned Russian attacks on protesters in the city of Kherson in the south and strikes in the Zaporizhzhia region in the southeast, where four children were hospitalized.
Snippet: ‘It was a day of difficult events,’ the Ukrainian president said in a video address.

Title: Word of the Day: demeanor
Text: The word demeanor has appeared in 185 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 12 in “How Ukrainian Paralympians Pushed Through Fear and Worry” by David Waldstein:
Snippet: This word has appeared in 185 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

Title: The Rise of the Tucker Carlson Politician
Text: say, the one that requires federal candidates to appear onscreen and “approve this message” — and then there are aesthetic rules. A candidate who’s touting education proposals, for instance, will invariably be shown sitting awkwardly in a kid-size chair, reading to elementary-school students. A promise to bring manufacturing jobs back to the United States must be accompanied by footage of the candidate, preferably in a hard hat, nodding meaningfully at someone in a factory. The candidate should always appear with people — talking, listening, shaking hands — except when speaking directly to the viewer, which should be done from a living room, with a credenza cluttered with family photos in the background.
Snippet: Two Republican Senate candidates field-test a new message honed in the cable-news studio.

Title: How Ukraine’s Outgunned Air Force Is Fighting Back Against Russian Jets
Text: Each night, Ukrainian pilots like Andriy loiter in an undisclosed aircraft hangar, waiting, waiting, until the tension is broken with a shouted, one-word command: “Air!”
Snippet: Aerial dogfights. Top Gun-style duels. Ukraine’s fighter pilots are badly outnumbered but have so far kept Russia from controlling the skies.

Title: Will Sanctioning Oligarchs Change the War?
Text: Among the actions taken by the West to punish Moscow for the invasion of Ukraine is the blacklisting of the incredibly rich and politically connected Russian businessmen known as oligarchs.
