Text: A planned benefit concert in support of Ukraine was canceled in Vienna on Monday amid concerns about the Russian-based ensemble it was to feature, MusicAeterna, which is led by the conductor Teodor Currentzis and is supported by a state-owned bank in Russia.
Snippet: Organizers said they canceled a performance by MusicAeterna after the Ukrainian ambassador in Austria expressed concern about featuring Russian artists.

Title: No More ‘Have a Nice Day’: Lviv Learns to Live With War
Text: When war came to Ukraine in February, Helen Polishchuk made some adjustments in the six-story bar she manages in central Lviv.
Snippet: Ukraine’s cultural capital, the western city of Lviv, is trying to adjust to being on the fringes of war and at the center of massive displacement.

Title: Biden Urges Modi Not to Increase India’s Reliance on Russian Oil and Gas
Text: President Biden on Monday urged Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India not to increase his country’s reliance on Russian oil and gas, officials said, part of a global effort by the United States to maintain economic pressure on Russia for its invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The United States hopes to convince India to come off the fence over Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but New Delhi and Moscow have deep historic ties.

Title: Far From Defeated, Putin Intends to Escalate War in Ukraine
Text: the first Western leader to see him in person since the Ukraine invasion — and said he came away feeling not only pessimistic about peace prospects but fearing that Mr. Putin intended to drastically intensify the brutality of the war.
Snippet: Austria’s chancellor said after meeting with Mr. Putin that the Russian president had “totally adopted the logic of war.”

Title: How a Little-Known Democrat Tries to Hold On
Text: and who can potentially tell us a great deal about Democrats’ hopes of avoiding a 2022 wipeout in the House — probably isn’t on your radar.
Snippet: Representative Tom O’Halleran of Arizona is seeking re-election as his district leans further toward Trump. His strategy? Don’t change. “I am,” he says, “who I am.”

Title: Zelensky says Ukraine takes ‘as seriously as possible’ an apparent threat of Russian chemical weapon use.
Text: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in his latest address seized on an apparent Russian threat to use chemical weapons against the remaining defenders of Mariupol, as they prepare for what he called a “new stage of terror against Ukraine.”
Snippet: A Ukrainian unit in Mariupol claimed Russian forces had used chemical weapons there. Their report could not be independently confirmed.

Title: Name, phone, address: The writing on a child’s back is now a symbol of Ukrainian parents’ terror.
Text: The mother’s hands were shaking when she started writing on her 2-year-old’s body. They trembled so much that she couldn’t write correctly on her first try, even though the information was second nature: Her daughter’s name, Vira, along with her birth date and their family phone numbers.
Snippet: A mother who wrote emergency contact information on her 2-year-old’s back has become a voice for countless Ukrainian parents forced to do the same.

Title: China Sets Aside Push to Spread Wealth in Pivotal Year for Xi
Text: For much of last year, China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, waged a fierce campaign to rein in private capital and narrow social inequalities. Regulators cracked down on tech giants and wealthy celebrities. Beijing demanded that tycoons give back to society. And the Communist Party promised that a new era of “common prosperity” was on the horizon.
Snippet: Xi Jinping’s rhetoric about redistributing wealth was aimed partly at drumming up public support. But it unnerved entrepreneurs and posed a drag on growth.

Title: Inflation Hits Fastest Pace Since 1981, at 8.5% Through March
Text: Inflation hit 8.5 percent in the United States last month, the fastest 12-month pace since 1981, as a surge in gasoline prices tied to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine added to sharp increases coming from the collision of strong demand and stubborn pandemic-related supply shortages.
Snippet: Gasoline weighed heavily in the increases, while prices moderated in several categories. Some economists say the overall rate may have peaked.

Title: Globally, inflation is surging amid persistent pandemic disruptions and war in Ukraine.
Text: Just as in the United States, policymakers in other countries have been caught off guard by persistently high inflation. Price increases were expected to ease as economies recovered from the pandemic, but surging energy and food prices have continued to lift inflation around the world.
Snippet: This may be the beginning of “a new inflationary era,” according to the Bank for International Settlements.

Title: Biden’s Climate Shift
Text: On the campaign trail and when he first came to office, President Biden had ambitious plans to deal with climate change, including promises to reduce fossil fuel production.
Snippet: The war in Ukraine has led the president to retreat on his ambitious climate policies.

Title: Nokia joins Ericsson as telecom giants leave Russia.
Text: Nokia, whose telecommunications equipment plays an important role providing internet and communications in Russia, said on Tuesday that it was exiting the country because of the invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: The decisions by the two Nordic firms signal difficulties ahead for Russia’s ability to expand and maintain its telecommunications networks.

Title: More Companies Take a Stand on Abortion
Text: Yelp, the online search and review platform, is expected to announce today that, beginning next month, it will cover expenses for its employees and their spouses who must travel out of state for abortion care, The Times’s Alisha Haridasani Gupta and DealBook’s Lauren Hirsch report. It is the latest company to respond to the Texas law that bans abortion after about six weeks of pregnancy.
Snippet: Yelp is the latest to pay for employees to travel out of state for treatment, responding to a recent Texas law that bans abortions after six weeks.

Title: Boris Johnson Fined for Breaking U.K. Lockdown Rules
Text: In recent weeks Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain has revived his fortunes at home by becoming Europe’s most aggressive supporter of Ukraine’s fierce fight against Russian invasion.
Snippet: The British prime minister had seemed to turn the “partygate” tide with his handling of Ukraine. Then came the announcement that he broke the law.

Title: Police named a ‘person of interest’ connected to the shooting.
Text: The police in New York on Tuesday evening identified a man they called a “person of interest” in the mass shooting on a crowded subway train in Brooklyn during the morning rush earlier that day that injured nearly two dozen people, five of them critically.
Snippet: The man had rented a U-Haul that the police found near where the gunman boarded the subway, the police said as they continued their search for the suspect.

Title: Western powers look into an unverified claim of possible use of a chemical agent in Mariupol.
Text: The United States, Britain and other Western allies, along with Ukraine’s government, are examining claims that Russia deployed a chemical agent that sickened a handful of people in Moscow’s unrelenting bid to gain complete control over the ruined Ukrainian city of Mariupol.
Snippet: Ukrainian commanders said “a poisonous substance” caused respiratory difficulties and neurological symptoms in a handful of soldiers and civilians.

Title: Ukraine War Pushes Germans to Change. They Are Wavering.
Text: Chancellor Olaf Scholz surprised the world, and his own country, when he responded to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine with a 100-billion-euro plan to arm Germany, send weapons to Ukraine and end his nation’s deep dependence on Russian energy.
Snippet: In just six weeks since Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced a strategic shift for his country, already doubts are emerging about how real and deep it is.

Title: Boeing’s sales rebound continues, with the 737 Max leading the way.
Text: Boeing sold 145 planes in the first three months of the year, after accounting for canceled orders, the company said on Tuesday, as airlines around the world start to lay the groundwork for a broader postpandemic rebound.
Snippet: The company had net sales of 145 aircraft in the first three months of the year as airlines got ready for a resurgence in travel.

Title: French Authorities Seize Oligarch’s Painting Before It Leaves for Russia
Text: A painting owned by a Russian oligarch that was seen by over 1.2 million people who visited a blockbuster art show in Paris will not be returning to Russia for the foreseeable future, a spokesman for France’s culture ministry said on Monday.
Snippet: A work displayed in the blockbuster “Morozov Collection” exhibition will remain in France, and authorities have their eyes on another painting in the show.

Title: Boris Johnson is fined for breaking British lockdown rules.
Text: In recent weeks Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain has revived his fortunes at home by becoming Europe’s most aggressive supporter of Ukraine’s fierce fight against Russian invasion.

Title: U.S. Report Describes a Global Retreat on Human Rights and Democracy
Text: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Tuesday that governments around the world, including in Russia and China, grew more repressive last year, as the State Department released its annual report on global human rights.
Snippet: Secretary of State Antony Blinken says repressive governments “are growing more brazen” and reaching across borders to target their critics.

Title: Ukraine says a political ally of Putin has been detained in a ‘special operation.’
Text: Ukraine’s security service said on Tuesday that officers had detained Viktor Medvedchuk, a politician and oligarch seen as the Kremlin’s main agent of influence in Ukraine in recent years.
Snippet: Viktor Medvedchuk, a wealthy Ukrainian politician seen as the Kremlin’s main agent of influence in Ukraine in recent years, had disappeared shortly after the start of the war.

Title: Ukraine Says It Thwarted a Sophisticated Russian Cyberattack on Its Power Grid
Text: Ukrainian officials said on Tuesday that they had thwarted a Russian cyberattack on Ukraine’s power grid that could have knocked out power to two million people, raising fears that Moscow will increase its use of digital weapons in a country already pummeled by war.
Snippet: Experts say the hacking, while unsuccessful, was among the most complex cyberattacks they have seen in the war so far.

Title: Putin’s defiance
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Snippet: The Russian president insists that Russia’s war goals will be achieved.

Title: Macron and Le Pen Trade Jabs and Lean Left as French Race Heats Up
Text: France’s presidential election entered a new, intense phase on Tuesday as President Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen, the far-right candidate trying to unseat him, traded barbs from afar and rubbed shoulders with voters in hopes of widening their appeal, especially on the left.
Snippet: President Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen, the far-right candidate, are in close contention as the April 24 presidential runoff election nears.

Title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
Text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
Snippet: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

Title: Putin Calls Talks a ‘Dead End’ but Limits War Aim to Eastern Ukraine
Text: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Tuesday that peace talks with Ukraine had reached a “dead end” and he falsely called the evidence of Russian atrocities in a Kyiv suburb “fake,” using his first extended remarks about the war in nearly a month to insist that Russia would persist in its invasion.
Snippet: not the whole country.

Title: Gas Prices Force Biden Into an Unlikely Embrace of Fossil Fuels
Text: President Biden came into office promising to tackle the planet’s climate crisis. But rising gas prices, driven in part by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, have pushed the environmental-minded president to do something unlikely: embrace oil.
Snippet: President Biden has had to walk a careful tightrope on energy and climate change in the weeks since U.S. sanctions on Russian oil and gas sent energy prices soaring.

Title: Panic in Brooklyn Subway: Police Hunt Gunman Who Shot 10
Text: Hours after a gunman in an orange construction vest released two smoke grenades and fired at least 33 shots on an N train in Brooklyn, hundreds of police officers were searching Tuesday night for a 62-year-old man whom police officials have linked to the shooting.
Snippet: At least 23 were injured, five critically, in an attack at the 36th Street stop in Sunset Park after a man released two smoke grenades and started shooting.

Title: The shooting suspect left troubling videos online.
Text: lengthy rants in which he expressed a range of harshly bigoted views and, more recently, criticized the policies of New York City’s mayor, Eric Adams.
Snippet: He has addresses in Wisconsin and Philadelphia.

Title: President Biden accuses Russia of committing genocide in Ukraine.
Text: President Biden on Tuesday for the first time accused Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, of perpetrating genocide on the Ukrainian people, but emphasized that was his personal view, not a legal determination.
Snippet: It was the first time the president has used the term to describe the Russia’s war. He emphasized it was a personal view, not a legal determination.

Title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Photographing the Reality of War’
Text: Featured Article: “Photographing the Reality of War” by Emmett Lindner
Snippet: In this lesson, students will learn about a New York Times photojournalist’s approach to bearing witness to the war in Ukraine.

Title: 5 Ukrainian Art Accounts to Follow on Instagram Now
Text: Social media give us responses to the Russian invasion of Ukraine almost instantly, but some of the most moving responses I’ve seen come from the young Ukrainian artists who’ve managed to make new work documenting events as they unfold.
Snippet: Artists continue to work, documenting the impact of events as they unfold to keep the world watching.

Title: Russian Tech Industry Faces ‘Brain Drain’ as Workers Flee
Text: In early March, days after Russia invaded Ukraine and began cracking down on dissent at home, Konstantin Siniushin, a venture capitalist in Riga, Latvia, helped charter two planes out of Russia to help people flee.
Snippet: Since their country invaded Ukraine, Russian tech workers have left by the thousands. They appear intent on rebuilding their lives and businesses in other countries.

Title: Pencil Cases and Air-Raid Sirens: School at War for Ukraine’s Children
Text: Across Ukraine, kindergartens have been bombed, elementary schools have been converted into shelters and in some cities like Mariupol, their grounds have even become makeshift graveyards.
Snippet: The country’s teachers are doing their best to provide lessons for the millions of school-age children whose education has been interrupted.

Title: Cruxy O’Connor and the Central Park Ambush
Text: It was a few minutes to 8 o’clock on the evening of April 13, 1922. When Patrick Joseph O’Connor came down the steps of his apartment building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, three of the Irish Republican Army’s top gunmen were lying in wait.
Snippet: One hundred years ago this week, the British spy was caught in what appears to be the Irish Republican Army’s only authorized attack on American soil.

Title: A ‘Silent Victim’: How Nature Becomes a Casualty of War
Text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
Snippet: Research on past conflicts suggests that the war in Ukraine could have a profound environmental impact.

Title: Yellen Calls on China to Push Russia to End Ukraine War.
Text: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen urged China on Wednesday to persuade Russia to end its war in Ukraine and warned that staying on the sidelines could jeopardize China’s standing in the global economy.
Snippet: The Treasury secretary told the Atlantic Council that the U.S. would press ahead with sanctions.

Title: The Next Phase of the War in Ukraine
Text: After a disastrous defeat in northern Ukraine, Russia has begun a high-stakes battle for the east, while Western allies arm Ukrainian fighters determined to stave off the attack.
Snippet: Moscow has narrowed its goals. What does that tell us about Russia’s military?

Title: Delta Air Lines sees a turn toward profit, and carriers’ shares soar.
Text: Delta Air Lines reported a quarterly loss on Wednesday as thriving ticket sales were offset by high fuel prices. But it said that its March operations were profitable and that it had been able to pass some of the higher cost of fuel along to customers.
Snippet: Delta said its March operations were profitable, despite rising fuel costs. It reported a first-quarter loss, but revenue exceeded its forecast.

Title: What We Know About the Brooklyn Subway Shooting
Text: A man who the police had identified as a suspect in the Brooklyn subway shooting, Frank R. James, was taken into custody on Wednesday, according law enforcement officials.
Snippet: The police have arrested a suspect, a 62-year-old man who has posted vitriolic rants on YouTube and criticized New York’s mayor.

Title: Britain’s inflation rate climbed to 7 percent, the highest in 30 years.
Text: In Britain, several pieces of dispiriting economic news arrived this week: Prices are rising at their fastest pace in 30 years, wages adjusted for inflation fell the most in nearly eight years and the economy hardly grew in February.
Snippet: Household budgets are squeezed as wage increases are not keeping pace with rising prices.

Title: Has U.S. Inflation Peaked?
Text: Inflation in the U.S. was running at 8.5 percent in the year to March, new data showed yesterday, the highest level in more than 40 years.
Snippet: Prices rose last month at the fastest pace in more than four decades. Some economists think inflation may be subsiding.

Title: Weaker oil demand, especially in China, might ease supply crunch caused by sanctions.
Text: The International Energy Agency said Wednesday that Covid lockdowns in China were likely to sharply cut the growth in demand for oil in that country, potentially easing a supply crunch caused by sanctions on Russia.
Snippet: The International Energy Agency foresees slower growth in demand for oil, caused by high prices and economic slowdowns.

Title: British territory freezes $7 billion in assets believed to be tied to Roman Abramovich.
Text: The economic vise is tightening around Roman Abramovich, whose assets were targeted by British authorities more than a month ago as part of the West’s sanctions on Russian oligarchs after the invasion of Ukraine.
Snippet: Jersey, an island in the English Channel, froze assets believed to be linked to the Russian oligarch, on whom Britain imposed sanctions after Russia invaded Ukraine.

Title: Israel’s Oldest Museum Takes a New Look at Israeli Art
Text: When the Tel Aviv Museum of Art’s permanent collection of Israeli art reopened in February, the first work visitors saw wasn’t even Israeli. It was a bust by a Scottish Jewish artist, Benno Schotz, who spent most of his life in Glasgow.
Snippet: with surprising results.

Title: U.S. and Ukrainian Groups Pierce Putin’s Propaganda Bubble
Text: Using a mix of high-tech and Cold War tactics, Ukrainian activists and Western institutions have begun to pierce the propaganda bubble in Russia, circulating information about the Ukraine war among Russian citizens to sow doubt about the Kremlin’s accounts.
Snippet: U.S.-backed news outlets and Ukrainian activists use Cold War techniques and high-tech tactics to get news about the war to Russians.

Title: Despite Russian Warnings, Finland and Sweden Draw Closer to NATO
Text: Even before his invasion of Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had warned Sweden and Finland of “retaliation” should they join NATO. It was, after all, Ukraine’s desire to join the alliance that he cited time and again as provocation for his war.
Snippet: The invasion of Ukraine has heightened security fears, pushing even formally nonaligned countries toward the Western alliance.

Title: ‘You would think it’s a safe place’: A nurse recounts an attack on a Mariupol hospital.
Text: When a Russian missile strike hit a maternity hospital in the Ukrainian port city of Mariupol early last month, Elena Karas, a nurse, was on the third floor taking care of 13 premature babies, two of whom had been abandoned.
Snippet: The attack last month was among the first signs that Ukraine was facing a merciless war.

Title: Etsy and the Sameness of Internet Fights
Text: This week, thousands of people who sell goods on Etsy are going on strike to protest the company’s climbing fees. And what seems to be a fight over a small corner of the internet is really one of the most enduring battles over our digital world.
Snippet: How much should the middleman get?

Title: Johnson’s Cabinet Backs Him After ‘Partygate’ Fine
Text: One said that Prime Minister Boris Johnson had “taken responsibility,” another that he had “apologized unreservedly,” while a third appealed to Britons to look at the bigger picture and cut some slack to a politician who was “delivering for Britain.”
Snippet: The support from the British prime minister’s party means he can likely ride out the immediate storm, but his troubles are not over, experts say.

Title: The U.S. has expanded intelligence sharing with Ukraine about Russian troops in the Donbas region.
Text: The United States has increased the flow of intelligence to Ukraine about Russian forces in the Donbas and Crimea, as Kyiv’s military forces prepare to defend against a renewed offensive by Moscow in the country’s east, American officials said Wednesday.
Snippet: Western officials say they expect the Kremlin to mount a major offensive in the Donbas, where Russian-backed separatists have been fighting Ukrainian forces for years.

Title: 500 Million Recorded Cases?
Text: The pandemic, now in its third year, has reached a monumental scale across the world. Countries have now logged 500 million confirmed cases of Covid-19, including more than 200 million this year.
Snippet: The real number of global infections is likely to be much, much larger.

Title: Le Pen Backs NATO-Russia Reconciliation and Reduced French Role in Alliance
Text: Rejecting a “herd-like conformity” with the Biden administration, Marine Le Pen, the French far-right candidate for the presidency, said Wednesday that France would quit NATO’s integrated military command if she were elected and would seek for the alliance “a strategic rapprochement” with Russia.
Snippet: Marine Le Pen, the far-right candidate for the French presidency, offered a worldview reminiscent of the Trump presidency. “No submission to an American protectorate on European soil,” she said.

Title: A Fed governor says the latest inflation data reaffirms the case for big rate increases.
Text: Christopher J. Waller, one of the Federal Reserve’s governors in Washington, said on Wednesday that recent economic data suggests that the central bank should raise interest rates by more than usual in May, and potentially in June and July as well.
Snippet: The central bank is contemplating a half-point rate move in May. Christopher J. Waller, a Fed governor, said inflation data may justify big increases in months to come.

Title: Arming Ukraine
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Snippet: The U.S. will send an additional $800 million worth of weapons and other security aid to Ukraine.

Title: Captured Ukrainian oligarch was a figure in the U.S. investigation into Russian electoral meddling.
Text: His name had surfaced as an influential figure in Ukraine with potential inside knowledge of Russian electoral meddling in the United States, though for years he had steadfastly denied it.
Snippet: Viktor Medvedchuk, a Ukrainian politician close to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, was also a client of Paul Manafort, the Republican political consultant and Trump campaign chairman.

Title: Biden Announces $800 Million in Military Assistance for Ukraine
Text: The United States will send an additional $800 million worth of military and other security aid to Ukraine and step up intelligence sharing, American officials announced on Wednesday, as Russian forces appeared to be preparing for a new offensive in the country’s east.
Snippet: The United States will also step up intelligence sharing as Russia appears to be preparing an offensive in eastern Ukraine.

Title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
Text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
Snippet: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

Title: Georgia’s 2018 Rematch, in a Courtroom
Text: The 2018 race for governor in Georgia ended in a bitter dispute between Brian Kemp, a Republican who was serving as secretary of state at the time, and Stacey Abrams, the Democratic challenger who accused the state of voter suppression.
Snippet: A trial is underway to determine whether Georgia’s handling of the 2018 election for governor was discriminatory, in a case brought by Stacey Abrams’s voting rights group.

Title: ‘Clear Patterns’ of Russian Rights Abuses Found in Ukraine, Report Says
Text: Investigators from almost a dozen countries combed bombed-out towns and freshly dug graves in Ukraine on Wednesday for evidence of war crimes, and a wide-ranging investigation by an international security organization detailed what it said were “clear patterns” of human rights violations by Russian forces.
Snippet: Momentum is building to try to bring war crimes charges tied to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

Title: The U.S. is considering sending a high-level official to Kyiv.
Text: The United States is considering whether to send a high-level official to Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, in the days ahead as a sign of support for Ukraine in its war with Russia, according to a person familiar with the internal discussions.
Snippet: No American official has publicly visited Ukraine since Russia launched its invasion in late February.

Title: A Russian warship is ‘seriously damaged’ in the Black Sea. Conflicting explanations emerge.
Text: A Russian warship in the Black Sea was “seriously damaged” on Wednesday, according to a Ukrainian military official and Russian state news agencies, though each claimed a different cause for the destruction.
Snippet: Ukraine claimed it was the same vessel that was famously and obscenely told off by Ukrainian troops in February.

Title: Late Night Teases Rudy Giuliani About Seized Devices
Text: and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
Snippet: Prosecutors recovered 18 devices during their current investigation into Trump’s former lawyer. “Eighteen devices? Man, that’s a lot of porn,” Stephen Colbert said.

Title: Supply Chain Hurdles Will Outlast Pandemic, White House Says
Text: The coronavirus pandemic and its ripple effects have snarled supply chains around the world, contributing to shipping backlogs, product shortages and the fastest inflation in decades.
Snippet: The administration’s economic advisers see climate change and other factors complicating global trade patterns for years to come.

Title: Hiding in Plain Sight, a Soviet-Era Air Defense System Arrives in Ukraine
Text: Driving back to his village near the Ukrainian border last Thursday, the mayor had to stop to let a train pass, and assumed he wouldn’t have to wait long. But the flatbed wagons, stacked high with military equipment, just kept coming. He waited for nearly half an hour.
Snippet: Encouraged by the United States, Slovakia “donated” a bulky but effective S-300, hoping to challenge Russian domination of the skies in the war next door.

Title: U.K. Plans to Send Some Asylum Seekers to Rwanda
Text: Britain said on Thursday that it planned to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda for processing and settlement there, becoming one of the few major powers to plan legislation that would turn away migrants without even considering their cases.
Snippet: Britain says it will fly many refugees thousands of miles to the central African country for processing and resettlement, a significant hardening of migration policy.

Title: The Best Tournament in Europe Is the One You’re Not Watching
Text: Over the course of the last year, setting out from his home about an hour north of Rotterdam, Remco Ravenhorst has followed his team to the glittering shores of Lake Lucerne and the concrete sprawl of suburban Berlin.
Snippet: The Europa Conference League was dismissed as irrelevant when it kicked off last summer. Try telling that to the clubs that can win it.

Title: David Cronenberg and Claire Denis Will Compete at Cannes Film Festival
Text: Follow our live coverage of the Cannes Film Festival’s final awards ceremony.
Snippet: Organizers announced a lineup of nearly 50 movies for the event’s 2022 edition, including 18 in the running for the top honor, the Palme d’Or.

Title: Europe’s economy is said to face severe impacts from war and inflation.
Text: The war in Ukraine is “severely affecting” the eurozone economy, the president of the European Central Bank said on Thursday. Trade disruptions and soaring energy and commodity prices are darkening the outlook for the region.
Snippet: Christine Lagarde, the president of the European Central Bank, said Russia’s invasion of Ukraine was “weighing heavily on the confidence of businesses and consumers.”

Title: Alexander Skarsgard’s Viking Dream
Text: In Alexander Skarsgard’s telling, the idea for what eventually became his latest film, “The Northman,” has its roots on a long, slender island off the coast of Sweden called Oland, where his great-great grandfather built a wooden house a hundred years ago.
Snippet: Stories from his grandfather inspired what would eventually become “The Northman.” But it took years of development and then seven months in the mud to complete.

Title: Retail sales grew in March as inflation soared.
Text: Retail sales rose 0.5 percent in March, the Commerce Department reported on Thursday, climbing for the third consecutive month as prices continued to increase across the country.
Snippet: Sales climbed for the third consecutive month as prices continued to increase across the country.

Title: Elon Musk Wants All of Twitter
Text: Elon Musk, Twitter’s largest shareholder and biggest agitator, offered this morning to buy the rest of the social media company and take it private. His “best and final offer,” as he put it in a financial filing, is $54.20 a share, nearly 40 percent higher than Twitter’s stock price before the mercurial billionaire’s purchases became public.
Snippet: The Tesla chief executive made an offer worth more than $40 billion to buy Twitter and take it private.

Title: On Poland-Ukraine Border, the Past Is Always Present. It’s Not Always Predictive.
Text: On a recent morning, I sat in the sun-filled dining room of a tidy house in eastern Poland, across from one of the most generous men I’ve ever met.
Snippet: For a Jewish reporter with Eastern European roots, one of the hardest challenges covering the war is reconciling the horrors of the Holocaust with the Poland and Ukraine of today.

Title: As two U.S. lawmakers visit Kyiv, the trip’s organizer says he hopes more officials, and weapons, will follow.
Text: In a hastily organized show of support for Ukraine, Senator Steve Daines of Montana and Representative Victoria Spartz of Indiana traveled on Thursday to Kyiv and sites of rights abuses in the city’s suburbs, becoming the first American officials to turn up since the start of the war.
Snippet: Senator Steve Daines of Montana and Representative Victoria Spartz of Indiana, both Republicans, were invited by Ukraine’s government on short notice.

Title: Europe Reluctantly Readies Russian Oil Embargo
Text: European officials are drafting plans for an embargo on Russian oil products, the most contested measure yet to punish Russia for its invasion of Ukraine and a move long resisted because of its big costs for Germany and its potential to disrupt politics around the region and increase energy prices.
Snippet: Officials are drafting a phased import ban on Russian oil products, but the measure won’t be floated until after the second round of the French elections at the earliest.

Title: Wall Street Profits Slump as War Weighs on Outlook
Text: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has only clouded an already uncertain economic outlook, banking executives said this week as they reported sliding profits and growing concerns about the state of the recovery from the pandemic.
Snippet: Bank executives are lately taking a more somber tone than the ebullience of recent quarters, when banks recorded blockbuster earnings.

Title: Anna Netrebko, Shunned in Much of the West, to Sing in Monte Carlo
Text: Anna Netrebko, the superstar soprano whose international career crumbled after the invasion of Ukraine because of her past support of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, has been invited to sing in Monaco this month at the Opéra de Monte-Carlo.
Snippet: After Russia invaded Ukraine, the soprano lost work in the West because of her past support of President Vladimir V. Putin. She was invited to sing this month in Monaco.

Title: The Russian media dismisses photographic evidence of atrocities in Ukraine as ‘fake.’
Text: State television programs in Russia have not shied away from showing images of death and destruction in Ukraine. Viewers have seen corpses in the streets of Bucha, blasted-out cars at a train station in Kramatorsk and the remains of a hospital complex attacked in Mariupol.
Snippet: Russians are being shown some of the same distressing imagery from the war as the rest of the world, but with a big twist.

Title: Ukrainians Face New Hurdle at U.S. Border: No Dogs
Text: Natasha Hrytsenko, a lifelong resident of Ukraine, had always dreamed of having a fluffy white dog. When she started working, Ms. Hrytsenko, now 30, used her first two paychecks to buy a purebred mini Maltese puppy. She brought Eddie home to the Kyiv apartment that she shared with her older sister.
Snippet: Federal health guidelines limit the entry of pets from countries like Ukraine with a high incidence of rabies. For some refugees, the rule has been devastating.

Title: Moody’s warns that Russia’s bond payments in rubles could lead to default.
Text: Russia’s repayment of foreign currency bonds in rubles could be considered a default if it does not reverse course and pay in dollars, Moody’s, the ratings agency, said on Thursday.
Snippet: The failure to fulfill its foreign debt obligation would be the first in more than a century for Russia, dealing with sanctions after its invasion of Ukraine.

Title: Russia Hits Setbacks, as Flagship Sinks and E.U. Mulls Oil Ban
Text: Russia’s faltering war against Ukraine suffered a pair of setbacks Thursday when the flagship of Russia’s Black Sea fleet sank after a catastrophic explosion and fire, as the European Union moved closer to an embargo on Russian oil imports.
Snippet: Ukraine said it hit a Russian warship in the Black Sea with its own missiles, a damaging blow to Moscow, symbolically and militarily, if its claim is confirmed.

Title: The Sinking of the Moskva
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Snippet: The flagship of Russia’s Black Sea fleet was damaged by a fire or a Ukrainian missile.

Title: Tensions Over the Ukraine War Deepen the Chill Near the North Pole
Text: At first glance, Sergey Gushchin, 50, is perhaps not a man one would assume to be the Russian consul general at the world’s northernmost diplomatic mission: ponytail, bluejeans, bass player in a punk band.
Snippet: The war and the comments of a Russian diplomat have strained relations on an archipelago in Norway where Russians, Ukrainians and Norwegians have lived peacefully for decades.

Title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
Text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
Snippet: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

Title: Gina McCarthy, Top Climate Adviser, Is Said to Be Planning Departure
Text: Gina McCarthy, the White House climate adviser, has told confidants that she has been frustrated by the slow pace of climate progress and intends to step down in the coming months, according to several people to whom she has spoken.
Snippet: Ms. McCarthy was tapped by President Biden to lead an ambitious domestic climate agenda. Associates say she is frustrated by the slow pace of progress.

Title: C.I.A. Director Airs Concern That Putin Might Turn to Nuclear Weapons
Text: The director of the C.I.A. said on Thursday that “potential desperation” to extract the semblance of a victory in Ukraine could tempt President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to order the use of a tactical or low-yield nuclear weapon, publicly discussing for the first time a concern that has coursed through the White House during seven weeks of conflict.
Snippet: William J. Burns, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, cautioned that he had seen no “practical evidence” that would suggest such a move was imminent.

Title: The Cat’s Approval Was a Good Start
Text: Even after being together for nearly two decades, Stuart Rembaum still struggled to find the words when it came to discussing a possible wedding to Jim Post.
Snippet: but not before Mr. Rembaum’s cat “sanctioned the relationship” by allowing Mr. Post to pet her.

Title: In a Week, Moving a Wedding from Ukraine to New York
Text: On a Wednesday evening in late February, Meny Stambler and Rikel Deutch talked to each other on the phone for the last time before their wedding.
Snippet: In their last phone call before they married, Meny Stambler, who is Ukrainian, and Rikel Deutch, who is Russian, expected to wed in Ukraine. Hours after they hung up, Russian troops had invaded.

Title: War Brings New Iron Curtain Down on Russia’s Storied Ballet Stages
Text: Just days after the invasion of Ukraine, Olga Smirnova, one of Russia’s most important ballerinas, posted an emotional statement on Telegram, the messaging app. “I am against war with all the fibers of my soul,” she wrote.
Snippet: Ballet has long been a symbol of Russian culture. Now it is becoming a symbol of Russian isolation.

Title: A reporter covering the war reflects on the legacy of the Holocaust.
Text: On a recent morning, I sat in the sun-filled dining room of a tidy house in eastern Poland, across from one of the most generous men I’ve ever met.
Snippet: In eastern Poland, perceptions of Russia and Ukraine are shaped by a traumatic past.

Title: Fuel Prices Send Airfares Higher, but Travelers Seem Ready to Pay
Text: A stunning rise in the cost of jet fuel has sent airfares soaring, and industry experts say they are likely to go higher. For now, though, travel-starved consumers seem more than willing to pay up.
Snippet: Supplies are not keeping up with demand, and costs may go higher, experts say.

Title: Some U.F.C. Fighters Have Ties to a Chechen Leader Loyal to Putin
Text: Khamzat Chimaev’s victory last weekend in a bruising fight served as a declaration in mixed martial arts: Chimaev, an undefeated welterweight, is quickly becoming the Ultimate Fighting Championship’s next superstar.
Snippet: Ramzan Kadyrov, the leader of Chechnya, is facing U.S. sanctions and accused of brutal abuses. Yet some fighters and others who work with the U.F.C. have kept ties with him.

Title: Faced With a Changed Europe, China Sticks to an Old Script
Text: When European leaders recently pressed China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, to distance himself from Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, he doggedly stuck to prepared remarks for the video summit, shutting down any opening for their demands.
Snippet: Europe was viewed as lacking the power and the will to contest China’s rise. But now, a harder line toward Russia has implications for Beijing.

Title: The (Really) Big Boats Have Arrived
Text: It has taken a few years, delayed by the pandemic, but formal Maxi yacht racing is coming to the Caribbean, considerably increasing the competitive opportunities sailors have to race their sleek monohull behemoths that can reach 100 feet long.
Snippet: Those enormous, pricey Maxi yachts have joined the Caribbean racing season and will be at Les Voiles de St. Barth.

Title: Growing Religious Fervor on the Right and the Illusions Shattered by Putin’s War: The Week in Narrated Articles
Text: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
Snippet: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

Title: Tanzania’s First Female President Wants to Bring Her Nation in From the Cold
Text: Shortly before midnight on a spring night last year, Samia Suluhu Hassan, then Tanzania’s first female vice president, appeared on television to announce to a shocked nation that the president was dead.
Snippet: Samia Suluhu Hassan became the only female head of government in Africa when her predecessor suddenly died. She is setting a new course.

Title: Russia’s loss of its Black Sea flagship would make capturing Odesa harder, analysts say.
Text: The loss of the Russian Navy’s Black Sea Fleet flagship will make it more difficult to gain full control over Ukraine’s southern coast and ultimately move on the port city of Odesa, military analysts say, although it is unlikely to derail Moscow’s war campaign entirely.

Title: Quiz Time on the Campaign Trail
Text: During the first week of the federal election campaign, politicians have been asked about: the price of bread, milk and petrol; the JobSeeker rate; the wage price index; the cash rate; the unemployment rate, and more.
Snippet: Several “gotcha” questions for candidates, including one that Anthony Albanese got wrong, raise deeper questions about the quality of the nation’s political discourse.

Title: How Russian disinformation spreads beyond its borders.
Text: not Russia — are to blame for Russia’s attack.
Snippet: A New York Times’ video team traveled to the breakaway region of Transnistria to find out what residents there believe about the war in Ukraine.

Title: U.S. Offers Protection to People Who Fled War in Cameroon
Text: The Biden administration announced on Friday that it would offer temporary protected status to nationals of Cameroon, shielding them from deportation and enabling them to obtain work permits, amid escalating armed conflict that has spawned a humanitarian crisis in the African country.
Snippet: Temporary protected status will allow an estimated 40,000 Cameroonians to legally live and work in the United States.

Title: What Britain’s Deal With Rwanda Means for the U.K. Asylum System
Text: The British government has announced a plan to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda, a move that prompted an immediate backlash from opposition politicians, international legal experts and human rights defenders.
Snippet: Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a plan to send some of those seeking refuge to the central African country. What effect would the change have?

Title: You Decide Which Games Matter
Text: Only a little more than a year ago, the Europa Conference League was still just an idea. It did not, in truth, even seem like an especially good idea. Explaining where such a league would fit into the game’s pecking order, what its purpose would be, hardly had the making of a compelling elevator pitch.
Snippet: The F.A. Cup and the Conference League have meaning not because of tradition or design, but when the players, and particularly the fans, decide they are important.

Title: Brazil’s climate politics are shifting. That matters for the whole planet.
Text: In Brazil, beef isn’t just food. It’s political. It’s a symbol of dignity and equality, and the price of beef is a kind of barometer of well-being in the country.
Snippet: The Amazon is emerging as a central issue in this year’s presidential campaign. Leaders have taken note.

Title: Russia’s Black Sea flagship was hit by 2 Ukrainian missiles, a U.S. official says.
Text: Two Ukrainian Neptune missiles hit Russia’s flagship Moskva in the Black Sea, a senior Defense official said on Friday, providing the first American confirmation that the sinking of the Russian cruiser was the result of a Ukrainian strike.
Snippet: Moscow claimed the sinking was an accident, but U.S. intelligence reports say the cruiser went down after Ukraine struck it with Neptune missiles.

Title: Why Ukraine War Crimes Trials Could Take Many Years
Text: The brutalities of Russia’s war in Ukraine have stoked enormous demand among Ukrainians and much of the Western world for investigations, indictments, arrests and trials for the invaders and their commanders, notably President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. Some leaders, including President Biden, have even accused them of genocide.
Snippet: Long after the fighting ends, any prosecutions and trials arising from it could be barely beginning. Here is a look at the complexities of bringing aggressors to justice.

Title: Five Science-Fiction Movies to Stream Now
Text: on ice skates. She agrees, but not because she is patriotic: Caroline has been told that a camp on the other side of the vast frozen expanse holds her daughter, who was abducted years earlier.
Snippet: This month’s picks take viewers through time loops, economic collapse and dystopian rage, with Noomi Rapace along for the journey.

Title: How Russian Media Uses Fox News to Make Its Case
Text: As Western leaders introduced sanctions against Russia for the invasion of Ukraine, Tucker Carlson, the Fox News host, said seizing personal property from Russian oligarchs went too far.
Snippet: The conservative network has appeared hundreds of times in Russian media.

Title: ‘Thank You for Not Killing Us’
Text: The first sign of trouble was when a squad of Chechen soldiers burst through the gate.
Snippet: An ordeal at a mental health facility in Ukraine illuminated the horrors of the Russian occupation in the areas around Kyiv.

Title: Biden Plans to Open More Public Land to Drilling
Text: The Biden administration announced on Friday that it would resume selling leases for new oil and gas drilling on public lands, but would also raise the federal royalties that companies must pay to drill, the first increase in those fees in more than a century.
Snippet: The president is under pressure to bring down gas prices, but any new drilling would be years away. The fees that companies pay would rise sharply.

Title: The Horrors of Russian Occupation
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Snippet: Disturbing stories are emerging of the terror inflicted on Ukrainian civilians.

Title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
Text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
Snippet: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

Title: The War in Ukraine Is Upending Biden’s Agenda at Home
Text: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has scrambled the global foreign policy landscape. But it has also upended President Biden’s domestic agenda back home, diverting the attention of the White House and contributing to rising prices that have become a top concern of Americans just months before congressional elections.
Snippet: President Biden’s domestic ambitions have gotten smaller as the war diverts the attention of the White House and contributes to rising prices.

Title: Girding for New Battle, Russia Warns U.S. on Advanced Weapons for Ukraine
Text: Stung by war losses and massing troops for a new battle in eastern Ukraine, Russia has warned the Biden administration to stop supplying advanced weapons to Ukrainian forces or face “unpredictable consequences,” American officials said Friday.
Snippet: The warnings were regarded as a sign that American military assistance to Ukraine was compounding problems for the Russians in their two-month-old invasion.

Title: Oh, Brother: The Not-Quite-Tell-All Books by Presidential Sisters
Text: In her 1921 biography about her brother Theodore Roosevelt, Corrine Roosevelt Robinson saw no harm in sharing “almost confidential personal recollections” about the late president. “There is no sacrilege in sharing such memories, with the people who have loved him, and whom he loved so well,” she wrote.
Snippet: Valerie Biden Owens is one of a handful of presidential sisters who have taken the opportunity to dish on their brothers.

Title: Prized Russian Ship Was Hit by Missiles, U.S. Officials Say
Text: The Moskva was the pride of Russia’s Black Sea Fleet, a symbol of the country’s dominance of the region and a powerful war machine that had been used to launch precision cruise missiles deep inside Ukraine.
Snippet: The sinking of the Moskva was a major blow to the Russian fleet and the most significant combat loss for any navy in decades.

Title: Travel’s ‘Great Comeback’ Has a Price: Chaos
Text: Arriving at London’s Gatwick Airport for his easyJet flight to Malaga, Spain, with his wife and 12-year-old daughter on April 4, Alasdair Crawley said it was like walking into the mayhem of the aftermath of a soccer game. The 49-year-old plumber from East London described long unruly lines of angry passengers trying to determine the status of their flights and families sprawled out across the floor eating, drinking and sleeping to get through long delays.
Snippet: In recent weeks, travelers on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean have endured long lines at airports, flight delays or cancellations, and plenty of frustration. Is this the new normal?

Title: He Envisioned a Nightmarish, Dystopian Russia. Now He Fears Living in One.
Text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
Snippet: With eight forthcoming translations of his books, Vladimir Sorokin is gaining recognition in the West just as, he says, Russian writers need to fight back in a semantic war on truth.

Title: A Case for Cautious Optimism, Now That the Markets Are So Glum
Text: The headlines about inflation have, once again, been awful. Consumer prices are rising more rapidly than at any time since 1981, and producer prices are soaring as well.
Snippet: Stocks, bonds and commodities are already pricing in inflation, the pandemic and war.

Title: Putin’s Ukraine Gamble Pivots to a Very Different Battlefield
Text: There are fields instead of city streets, farmsteads instead of apartment buildings. Open highways stretch to the horizon.
Snippet: After Russian forces were mauled in cities and towns in northern Ukraine, Vladimir V. Putin is shifting the focus of his invasion to the flatlands of Donbas, in the east.

Title: Where Russians Turn for Uncensored News on Ukraine
Text: Before Russia invaded Ukraine, the Russian journalist Farida Rustamova used the Telegram chat app for one purpose: messaging friends.
Snippet: Telegram is the platform of choice for Russians seeking to escape Moscow’s propaganda web. But can it last?

Title: War in Ukraine Has Left Eastern Europe Sleepless
Text: For the past seven weeks, Dr. Simona Neliubsiene has struggled to focus on her patients’ charts, distracted by images of bombed cities flashing in her head.
Snippet: Mental health professionals across the region say they have seen an increase in patients with intense anxiety. Some are asking for more sleeping pills, and many are making escape plans.

Title: A Nazi Soldier Stole a Watch in 1942. It Turned Up 80 Years Later.
Text: After nearly 80 years, a watch that was taken by a Nazi soldier during World War II, lost in a cornfield and later hidden in a clock on a farm in Belgium has been returned to the grandchildren of its maker.
Snippet: The watch, made as a gift in 1910, has been returned to the maker’s family in the Netherlands. It still works.

Title: The Moskva’s sinking inspires one of Ukraine’s most popular rockers.
Text: The sinking of the Russian warship Moskva is being celebrated by Ukrainians as an iconic victory, including in a new song by one of the country’s most popular rock musicians.
Snippet: Vadym Krasnooky, whose band Mad Heads had stopped performing when the war began, said his new song is meant to ‘channel all this hate.’

Title: A Russian Default Is Looming. A Bitter Fight Is Likely to Follow.
Text: Russia is ambling toward a major default on its foreign debt, a grim milestone that it has not seen since the Bolshevik Revolution more than a century ago and one that raises the prospect of years of legal wrangling and a global hunt by bondholders for Russian assets.
Snippet: The ultimate arbiter of a sovereign default is an open question but markets may have the final word.

Title: Russia Fires Missile Barrage at Ukrainian Cities and Military Targets
Text: Russia pounded military targets throughout Ukraine on Saturday, in apparent retaliation for the sinking of an important naval ship and in preparation for an offensive in the Donbas region of the country’s east.
Snippet: The strikes seemed aimed at hampering Ukraine’s war fighting capacity as the conflict shifts to eastern Donbas region, and at responding to the sinking of a Russian warship.

Title: Fighting for Her Life, Far From Ukraine
Text: When Russia invaded Ukraine, Marija Pyzhyk was still worried mainly about her 5-year-old daughter, Khrystyna, who was being treated for a brain tumor. The family lived in Lviv, the western city near Poland, far from the rockets raining down in the east.
Snippet: A 5-year-old Ukrainian girl with a brain tumor was one of several children brought for treatment in the United States after their country was invaded by Russia.

Title: The World’s Broken Promise of Asylum
Text: For more than 70 years, the world has enshrined, in national laws and global agreements, a promise that was presented as vitally important: Anyone who cannot live safely in their home country may seek refuge in another.
Snippet: Britain’s new plan to send thousands of asylum seekers to Rwanda exposes the fragile nature of the global refugee compact, which has always fallen prey to domestic politics.

Title: ‘They Are Gone, Vanished’: Missing Persons Haunt Ukrainian Village
Text: The cows wouldn’t stop screaming.
Snippet: In a Russian-occupied village, five men went off to feed cattle. Their relatives and neighbors are wondering what happened to them.

Title: The Week in Business: Housing Market Gets Squeezed
Text: Mortgage rates rose to 5 percent for the first time in more than a decade, the kind of increase that in the past spelled trouble for the housing market. But in the current climate, the impact of the higher rates is uncertain. During the pandemic, many people, with extra savings in their pockets and in search of more space, bid up house prices. That, combined with supply chain problems that slowed construction of new homes, stoked competition and made new houses hard to come by. The inventory of homes for sale remains extremely low, and there are still more interested buyers than there are houses. But if the market doesn’t feel the sting, prospective home buyers certainly will, especially those who are already struggling with the rising costs of food, gas, cars and other everyday necessities.
Snippet: Elon Musk wants to take over Twitter. Prices are still rising at a rapid pace, but even with higher ticket prices, airlines are seeing demand rebound.

Title: Pope Francis calls for peace in Ukraine and the world on what he described as an ‘Easter of war.’
Text: Ukraine hung heavily on Pope Francis’ heart on Sunday as he delivered the annual “Urbi et Orbi” (“To the City and the World”) message in St. Peter’s Square, in which he called for peace on what he described this year as an “Easter of war.”
Snippet: Instead of learning from the heavy toll taken by the pandemic, and emerging with strengthened solidarity, rivalry had prevailed, the pope said.

Title: Worshipers filled pews in Lviv on Easter Sunday.
Text: Ukrainians packed churches on Sunday for Easter commemorations that combined ancient traditions with the reality of the war.
Snippet: Commemorations in Ukraine’s small Roman Catholic community combined ancient traditions with the reality of the war.

Title: Questions deepen in Russia, days after the sinking of a warship.
Text: A video released by Russia’s Ministry of Defense purporting to show dozens of uniformed crew members from the missile cruiser Moskva standing in formation, apparently days after the ship sank, did not answer lingering questions about the fate of the vessel and its more than 500 personnel.
Snippet: A talk-show host, who usually reflects the Kremlin’s line, questioned how the ship was lost.

Title: Pope Speaks of Ukraine’s Suffering on ‘an Easter of War’
Text: On what he described this year as an “Easter of war,” Pope Francis spoke to tens of thousands of faithful in St. Peter’s Square about the “fear and anguish” evoked by the conflict in Ukraine, adding that he hoped news of suffering in Europe would also make people more mindful of similar situations elsewhere.
Snippet: In his blessing to pilgrims, Pope Francis quoted a manifesto against nuclear weapons and said conflict in Europe should bring increased attention to violence around the world.

Title: Atrocities in Ukraine War Have Deep Roots in Russian Military
Text: In a photograph from the Kyiv suburb of Bucha, Ukraine, a woman stands in the yard of a house, her hand covering her mouth in horror, the bodies of three dead civilians scattered before her. When Aset Chad saw that picture, she started shaking and hurtled 22 years back in time.
Snippet: Like the shelling of cities, the seemingly pointless, close-up killing of individuals recalls wars in Chechnya. Do they reflect intent, or only indifference, propaganda and a military culture of violence?

Title: A Visiting Team Like No Other
Text: The Ukrainian comeback attempt had come up just short, and Dayana Yastremska and her four teammates were preparing to pose for their final formal photograph at this Billie Jean King Cup qualifier.
Snippet: A supportive tennis crowd in Asheville, N.C., watched the Ukrainians nearly pull off an upset of the United States in a Billie Jean King Cup qualifier.

Title: Jim Farley Tries to Reinvent Ford and Catch Up to Elon Musk and Tesla
Text: On a recent Tuesday afternoon, Jim Farley, the chief executive of Ford Motor, took a spin in what could become one of the most important vehicles in the company’s 118-year history: an electric F-150 pickup truck.
Snippet: Ford’s chief executive is about to introduce an electric F-150 pickup truck that could determine whether the automaker can survive and thrive in an industry dominated by Tesla.

Title: Sadness and Loss Are Everywhere. Books Can Help.
Text: I was 10 when “Brian’s Song” aired in 1971 as an ABC Movie of the Week. It is the story of the abiding friendship that grew as Brian Piccolo, who was white, and Gale Sayers, who was Black, competed for playing time as N.F.L. rookies with the Chicago Bears. It’s also the story of Piccolo’s death of cancer at 26. I was a girl in Birmingham, Ala., then “the most segregated city in America,” when “Brian’s Song” reminded this country that race was not an insurmountable barrier to love.
Snippet: The saddest stories can show us how full of grace the fallen world can be.

Title: The Next Hurdle in Europe’s Energy Transition: Being More Enticing Than NFTs
Text: When Jakob Bitner was 7, he left Russia for Germany with his parents and sister. Twenty-eight years later, he is set on solving a vexing green-energy problem that could help Germany end its dependence on imported energy from Russia, or anywhere.
Snippet: Financing the next generation of green energy technologies means larger investments and getting venture capitalists to turn their attention away from “fast money.”

Title: French Candidates’ Economic Programs Hold Key to the Election
Text: As President Emmanuel Macron wove through crowds during a campaign stop in northern France last week, an elderly voter got in his face to protest one of his most unpopular economic proposals: raising the retirement age to 65 from 62 to fund France’s national pension system.
Snippet: Promising tax cuts, higher wages and changes in the retirement age, President Macron and Marine Le Pen vie for undecided voters.

Title: They’re Some of Hollywood’s Top Publicists. Just Don’t Ask Them Why.
Text: “I can’t decide what is OK and what’s not OK, you know what I mean?” Amanda Silverman said over the phone on March 1, six days into Russia’s war on Ukraine. Discussing geopolitics was not the intended purpose of the call; Ms. Silverman’s life as a celebrity publicist was. As Vladimir Putin shook the world order, she had clients to manage.
Snippet: Meet the women of the Lede Company.

Title: Rushing Against War, and Time, Ukraine Makes It to the Biennale
Text: The 78 bronze funnels were ready, the pump tested and the backdrop was almost done. So when it looked as if war was most likely coming to Ukraine, Maria Lanko, one of the curators of the Ukrainian pavilion at the Venice Biennale, was determined to get the artist Pavlo Makov’s fountain sculpture safely out of the country.
Snippet: Russia’s invasion complicated well-laid plans. But, despite the odds, Ukraine will present work at the international art showcase in Venice.

Title: Russian attack on Lviv shakes sense of security in a relatively safe city.
Text: Vlada Belau believed she had finally established a semblance of normalcy in the city of Lviv after fleeing from Kyiv, nearly 300 miles to the east, when it was bombarded in the early days of the war.

Title: To Push Back Russians, Ukrainians Hit a Village With Cluster Munitions
Text: It was in early March when the spent warhead of a cluster munition rocket landed next to Yurii Doroshenko’s home in eastern Ukraine, having dispensed its lethal bomblets over his village.
Snippet: The New York Times verified that Ukraine’s forces appeared to fire at least two of these internationally banned weapons in a neighborhood, putting Ukrainian civilians at extreme risk.

Title: Five Big Questions for Elon Musk and Twitter
Text: Over the weekend, Twitter’s board put in place a poison pill provision in an effort to block Elon Musk, who, you might have heard, wants to buy the social media platform. The maneuver will give Twitter’s management time to assess the offer and potentially invite other buyers via a sale process.
Snippet: Will he go hostile, what is Twitter really worth and more.

Title: A Russian strike hits Lviv, a city relatively untouched by violence.
Text: Russian missiles struck Lviv on Monday, killing at least seven people in the first reported deaths of the war in the western city, where hundreds of thousands of displaced people have fled to escape the fierce fighting in other parts of Ukraine.
Snippet: Hundreds of thousands of displaced people from other parts of Ukraine have fled to, or through, Lviv to escape the fighting. Then it landed on their doorstep.

Title: The World Bank slashes its forecast for global economic growth.
Text: The World Bank is slashing its forecast for global economic growth this year, citing the war in Ukraine, inflation and the lingering effects of the pandemic.
Snippet: The bank now expects the global economy to grow at a rate of 3.2 percent in 2022, down from its previous estimate of 4.1 percent.

Title: Bleak assessments of the Russian economy clash with Putin’s rosy claims.
Text: Russia’s central bank chief warned on Monday that the consequences of Western sanctions were only beginning to be felt, and Moscow’s mayor said that 200,000 jobs were at risk in the Russian capital alone, stark acknowledgments that undermined President Vladimir V. Putin’s contention that sanctions had failed to destabilize the Russian economy.
Snippet: While Vladimir Putin boasts that Russia is holding up under Western sanctions, his central bank chief and the mayor of Moscow warned that the worst was yet to come.

Title: Bank of America is confident in the economy even as its profits declined.
Text: Bank of America joined its peers in reporting lower profits for the first three months of the year but is keeping its optimistic economic outlook even as other lending giants have turned more cautious.
Snippet: The bank reported lower quarterly profits, but it expects to earn significantly more money later this year from rising interest rates.

Title: A second global Covid-19 summit led by the White House is set for May.
Text: The White House announced on Monday that it would co-host the second global Covid-19 summit next month, a gathering intended to build momentum for vaccine donations and for ending what the White House called the “acute phase” of the pandemic.
Snippet: Efforts to subsidize more global vaccinations have stalled in Congress, and new coronavirus cases are on the rise in the U.S.

Title: Citing Ukraine War, an American Resigns From Russia’s Mariinsky
Text: The American conductor Gavriel Heine has been a fixture at the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, Russia, for 15 years. He has led hundreds of performances of classics like “Swan Lake” and “The Rite of Spring.” And he has done so as a protégé of the company’s leader: Valery Gergiev.
Snippet: “There’s no way I could ever be in denial of what is happening,” said the conductor Gavriel Heine, a fixture at the prestigious Russian theater.

Title: Ukraine War Divides Orthodox Faithful
Text: IT specialists, migrant factory laborers, nurses and cleaners — decided to repudiate the full-throated support for the war in Ukraine from Patriarch Kirill of Moscow.
Snippet: Around the world, national churches, parishes and even families are reassessing relations with Patriarch Kirill of Moscow, who has encouraged Russia’s aggression.

Title: Thousands of civilians are holed up with Ukrainian troops in Mariupol, officials say.
Text: Intense fighting continued around a large steel factory in the southern city of Mariupol, in what appeared to be one of the last redoubts of Ukrainian forces in the besieged city, an adviser to the mayor said on Monday.
Snippet: Some 2,000 civilians who were driven from their homes have sheltered in a network of tunnels beneath the plant, an aide to the city’s mayor said.

Title: They Fled Afghanistan for America. Now They Feed the Newest Arrivals.
Text: Hamidullah Noori was 8 years old when his father, uncle and cousin were killed by Taliban militants in Kabul, Afghanistan. As the eldest son, he soon went to work to support his family, selling boiled potatoes and balloons from a pushcart. Violence and flight have shaped his life ever since.
Snippet: In Virginia, Maryland and Washington, D.C., established Afghan restaurateurs are reaching out to help refugees fleeing the return of the Taliban.

Title: Prominent prisoners held by both sides appeal for an exchange.
Text: High-profile prisoners held by both Russia and Ukraine, including two British fighters believed captured in Mariupol, appealed on Monday to be exchanged.
Snippet: Two British fighters held by Russian asked to be traded for Viktor Medvedchuk, a wealthy Ukrainian ally of Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin.

Title: The Battle for the Donbas
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Snippet: Russia’s offensive in eastern Ukraine has begun, Ukraine says.

Title: Ukraine Says Russia Begins Assault in the East After Raining Missiles Nationwide
Text: Ukraine said Monday that Russian forces had launched a ground assault along a nearly 300-mile front in the east after hitting the country with one of the most intense missile barrages in weeks, including the first lethal strike on Lviv, the western city that has been a refuge for tens of thousands of fleeing civilians.
Snippet: The president of Ukraine and a top national security aide said the Russian offensive, anticipated for weeks, had finally begun after a Russian missile barrage that included the first deadly strike on the western city of Lviv.

Title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
Text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
Snippet: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

Title: The U.N.’s humanitarian chief said he tested positive for the coronavirus after attending in-person meetings.
Text: Martin Griffiths, the top humanitarian chief at the United Nations, said he tested positive for the coronavirus on Monday as he was visiting the U.N. headquarters in New York from a recent trip to Afghanistan, Russia and Ukraine.
Snippet: One meeting had included the U.N.’s secretary general, but everyone in the room was wearing masks, a spokesman said.

Title: This Venice Biennale Has a New Star: Women
Text: The Venice Biennale, the world’s longest-running major survey of contemporary art, will reconvene this weekend after a yearlong postponement because of the pandemic. Barring another coronavirus surge, the 59th edition of the world’s oldest international exhibition, which opens to the public on Saturday and runs through Nov. 27, should attract hundreds of thousands of visitors.
Snippet: For the first time, a majority of the artists at the 59th edition of the longest-running survey of contemporary art will be female.

Title: The Cost of Dissidence in Russia
Text: Nearly two months into the war in Ukraine, many Russians have gone from shock and denial to support for their troops and anger at the West.
Snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin’s us-versus-them framing of the war has set the country up for a new and dark phase domestically.

Title: Netflix loses subscribers for first time in 10 years.
Text: 200,000 overall in the first three months of the year — the result of shifting economic forces, increasingly fierce competition from other streaming platforms and the conflict in Ukraine. The Tuesday announcement, plus the company’s warning that it expected to lose two million subscribers in the second quarter, sent the stock down 35 percent on Wednesday.
Snippet: The company, which had a net loss of 200,000 subscribers in its first quarter, has been facing down a lack of must-see content on its platform as competitors continue to expand.

Title: The Next Big Thing in Streaming
Text: Later today, Netflix will report its latest quarterly earnings. Analysts do not have high expectations. The streaming service’s profits are expected to drop by more than 20 percent.
Snippet: As subscriber growth slows, Netflix and others show less resistance to introducing ads.

Title: Russia’s Thrust in Eastern Ukraine Combines Firepower and New Caution
Text: Russia’s initial invasion of Ukraine in February relied on a rapid advance of tanks and helicopter assaults deep into the country — two strategies that ultimately failed and cost Moscow a significant number of casualties.
Snippet: The military campaign that Moscow said it had now begun appears much more methodical than those it pursued in the war’s first days

Title: Global Economic Forecasts Drop as Russia’s War in Ukraine Takes Toll
Text: The world economy has entered a period of intense uncertainty as a capricious pandemic and the fallout from Russia’s war in Ukraine combine to fuel rapid inflation and weigh on an already fragile global recovery.
Snippet: The International Monetary Fund’s new World Economic Outlook expects growth to slow to 3.6 percent this year. The group is one of many to slash their forecasts recently.

Title: Ukraine’s War Efforts Gain an Unlikely Source of Funding: Memes
Text: Christian Borys was at home in Toronto in February trying to find a way to help Ukrainians threatened by war when he decided to print some stickers from an internet meme: the Virgin Mary hoisting an antitank missile.
Snippet: A campaign using internet memes and merchandise has rallied international public support for Ukraine in its war with Russia.

Title: For Airlines, the Mask Mandate Couldn’t End Soon Enough
Text: For two years, covered faces in airports and on airplanes were a persistent reminder of the hold that the coronavirus had on air travel. The end of the mask mandate on planes and other forms of transportation this week marked the latest advance in the airline industry’s effort to return to normal.
Snippet: It created tensions between flight attendants and noncompliant passengers, but some travelers are worried about what comes next.

Title: Drawn and Caricatured: French Cartoonists on the Campaign Trail
Text: There is little time left until the French choose their next president on Sunday, and image is important. As media teams flutter around the two remaining candidates, President Emmanuel Macron and the far-right leader Marine Le Pen, the nation’s political cartoonists are out in force, ready to accentuate even the smallest slip.
Snippet: Cartoonists play a high-profile role in France’s political discourse, and they have been busy drawing the presidential candidates as the race approaches its end.

Title: China doubles down on coal
Text: What happens in China doesn’t stay in China. Certainly not when it comes to global warming.
Snippet: Choices being made about energy in the country right now will have profound implications for the climate crisis.

Title: Ukrainian Children and Caregivers Are Being Separated at U.S. Border
Text: After Iryna Merezhko persuaded her sister in Ukraine that her young nephew should join her in Los Angeles to wait out the war, she traveled halfway around the globe to pick him up. “I told him it would be a California vacation,” she recalled. “We would go to Disneyland, Universal Studios, the beach.”
Snippet: Under a policy designed to protect young refugees from trafficking, Ukrainian children are being temporarily removed from caretakers who are not their parents.

Title: Despair in Mariupol’s last stronghold: ‘They’re bombing us with everything’
Text: Under incessant fire from the air and with Russian troops closing in, a group of Ukrainian soldiers holed up in the besieged city of Mariupol issued a message of despair on Tuesday evening, expressing hope that their own forces would come to their rescue and demanding that the world do something to stop the Kremlin’s vicious war.
Snippet: A huge Soviet-era steel mill is where the last Ukrainian defenders of Mariupol have taken refuge as Russia’s battle to take full control of the city appeared to be entering its final stages.

Title: Johnson Is All Apologies Before Parliament After ‘Partygate’ Fine
Text: Prime Minister Boris Johnson faced Parliament on Tuesday as an awkward pioneer in British politics: a confirmed lawbreaker who misled fellow lawmakers but remains ensconced in the nation’s highest elected office.
Snippet: Though opposition politicians called him out, only one member of his own Conservative party called on him to resign.

Title: Democratic Dollars Flow Once Again to Likely Lost Causes
Text: Gary Chambers Jr. burst onto the national scene in 2020 with a viral video of him castigating the racism of the East Baton Rouge school district. Now, he has captured the hearts and wallets of young liberals with a video for his improbable Senate campaign that shows him smoking a large joint and calling for the legalization of marijuana.
Snippet: New fund-raising figures show emerging Democratic stars like Marcus Flowers in Georgia and Gary Chambers Jr. in Louisiana, with no clear path to victory.

Title: The U.S. Races to Arm Ukraine With Heavier, More Advanced Weaponry
Text: The race is on.
Snippet: Washington and its allies are scouring Central Europe and the world to get Ukraine the weapons it needs for the next phase of the war.

Title: Russia’s Strategy in the East
Text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
Snippet: Russia is taking a more methodical approach in its Donbas campaign.

Title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
Text: Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
Snippet: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

Title: More Cautious, Russia Embarks on New Phase of Ukraine War
Text: Russia plunged into a new chapter of the Ukraine war on Tuesday, intent on capturing the eastern part of the country and crushing Ukrainian defenses without the same blunders that badly damaged Russian forces in the conflict’s initial weeks.
Snippet: Despite the Kremlin’s new methodical approach focusing on eastern Ukraine, the Russian military still faces some of the same problems that hampered it after the war began.

Title: Russia rejects calls for a cease-fire to enable evacuations, saying Ukraine only wants time to arm.
Text: Russia rejected calls for a cease-fire to allow for civilian evacuations in Ukraine on Tuesday, saying that requests to pause the fighting were not sincere and would only provide time to arm Ukrainian fighters.
Snippet: Civilians, including children, remain trapped in the eastern Ukraine region of Donbas and in the devastated port city of Mariupol.

Title: Tours Argue Wimbledon Sets ‘Damaging Precedent’ in Barring Russian and Belarusian Players
Text: Professional tennis, which had been unusually united of late, is back in disaccord after Wimbledon’s bold and difficult decision to bar Russian and Belarusian players from this year’s tournament was met with strong disapproval by the men’s and women’s tours.
Snippet: The men’s and women’s tours disagreed with the major tournament’s move to exclude individual athletes from those countries from competition in the aftermath of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

Title: How The Times Has Mapped the War in Ukraine
Text: and nearly every graphics journalist at the organization, from New York to Seoul to London, has helped with the mapping effort.
Snippet: Graphics journalists use annotated maps to show readers the current state of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

Title: Feeling the Squeeze? How to Be a Thrifty Traveler as Prices Soar
Text: compounded by pent-up demand — peaks.
Snippet: Inflation is here and it’s wreaking havoc on travel budgets. Our Frugal Traveler columnist on how to strategize in a world of rising prices.

Title: In the fog of dementia, one grandmother learns again and again that her country is at war.
Text: Every morning, Olga Boichak’s grandmother wakes up at her home in western Ukraine, turns on the television and discovers anew that her country is at war.
Snippet: Millions of Ukrainians have been displaced since the war started. Many elderly or disabled people have been unable or unwilling to leave their homes.

Title: A Problem for Macron in France’s Election: ‘The Hatred He Arouses’
Text: Follow our live updates of the French runoff election between Macron and Le Pen.
Snippet: Given the choice between a president they suspect of despising ordinary people and a far-right candidate they detest, many French voters may stay home.

Title: The End of Mask Mandates
Text: Major U.S. airlines have lifted mask mandates after a federal judge ruled that face coverings would no longer be required on airplanes, trains and other public transportation.
Snippet: As major airlines and some public transit operators drop requirements to wear face coverings, further conflicts may be on the horizon.
